text.wiki:
Heraklion or Iraklion ( hih-RAK-lee-ən; Greek: Ηράκλειο, Irákleio, pronounced [iˈraklio]) is the largest city and the administrative capital of the island of Crete and capital of Heraklion regional unit. It is the fourth largest city in Greece with a population of 211,370 (Urban Area) according to the 2011 census. The population of the municipality was 173,993.The Bronze Age palace of Knossos, also known as the Palace of Minos, is located nearby.
Heraklion was Europe's fastest growing tourism destination for 2017, according to Euromonitor, with an 11.2% growth in international arrivals. According to the ranking, Heraklion was ranked as the 20th most visited region in Europe, as the 66th area on the Planet and as the 2nd in Greece for the year 2017, with 3.2 million visitors and the 19th in Europe for 2018, with 3.4 million visitors.


== Names ==
The Arab traders from al-Andalus (Iberia) who founded the Emirate of Crete moved the island's capital from Gortyna to a new castle they called rabḍ al-ḫandaq (Arabic: ربض الخندق‎, "Castle of the Moat") in the 820s. This was hellenized as Χάνδαξ (Chándax) or Χάνδακας (Chándakas) and Latinized as Candia, which was taken into other European languages: in Italian and Latin as Candia, in French as Candie, in English as Candy, all of which could refer to the island of Crete as a whole as well as to the city alone; the Ottoman name was Kandiye.
After the Byzantine reconquest of Crete, the city was locally known as Megalo Kastro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο, 'Big Castle' in Greek) and its inhabitants were called Kastrinoi (Καστρινοί, "castle-dwellers").
The ancient name Ηράκλειον was revived in the 19th century and comes from the nearby Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles's city"), whose exact location is unknown. English usage formerly preferred the classicizing transliterations "Heraklion" or "Heraclion", but the form "Iraklion" is becoming more common.


== History ==


=== Minoan Era ===
Heraklion is close to the ruins of the palace of Knossos, which in Minoan times was the largest centre of population on Crete. Knossos had a port at the site of Heraklion (at Poros - Katsambas neighborhood) from the beginning of Early Minoan period (3500 to 2100 BC). Between 1600 and 1525 BC, the port was destroyed by a volcanic tsunami from nearby Santorini, leveling the region and covering it with ash.


=== Antiquity ===

After the fall of the Minoans, Heraklion, as well as the rest of Crete in general, fared poorly, with very little development in the area. Only with the arrival of the Romans did some construction in the area begin, yet especially early into Byzantine times the area was abound with pirates and bandits.


=== Emirate of Crete ===
The present city of Heraklion was founded in 824 by the Arabs under Abu Hafs Umar who had been expelled from Al-Andalus by Emir Al-Hakam I and had taken over the island from the Eastern Roman Empire. They built a moat around the city for protection, and named the city rabḍ al-ḫandaq (ربض الخندق, "Castle of the Moat", hellenized as Χάνδαξ, Chandax). It became the capital of the Emirate of Crete (ca. 827–961). The Saracens allowed the port to be used as a safe haven for pirates who operated against Imperial (Byzantine) shipping and raided Imperial territory around the Aegean.


=== Byzantine era ===

In 960, Byzantine forces under the command of Nikephoros Phokas, later to become Emperor, landed in Crete and attacked the city. After a prolonged siege, the city fell in March 961. The Saracen inhabitants were slaughtered, the city looted and burned to the ground. Soon rebuilt, the town remained under Byzantine control for the next 243 years.


=== Venetian era ===
 
In 1204, the city was bought by the Republic of Venice as part of a complicated political deal which involved, among other things, the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade restoring the deposed Eastern Roman Emperor Isaac II Angelus to his throne. The Venetians improved on the ditch of the city by building enormous fortifications, most of which are still in place, including a giant wall, in places up to 40 m thick, with 7 bastions, and a fortress in the harbour. Chandax was renamed Candia and became the seat of the Duke of Candia, and the Venetian administrative district of Crete became known as "Regno di Candia" (Kingdom of Candia). The city retained the name of Candia for centuries and the same name was often used to refer to the whole island of Crete as well. To secure their rule, Venetians began in 1212 to settle families from Venice on Crete. The coexistence of two different cultures and the stimulus of Italian Renaissance led to a flourishing of letters and the arts in Candia and Crete in general, that is today known as the Cretan Renaissance.


=== Ottoman era ===

During the Cretan War (1645–1669), the Ottomans besieged the city for 21 years, from 1648 to 1669, perhaps the longest siege in history. In its final phase, which lasted for 22 months, 70,000 Turks, 38,000 Cretans and slaves and 29,088 of the city's Christian defenders perished. The Ottoman army under an Albanian grand vizier, Köprülü Fazıl Ahmed Pasha conquered the city in 1669. 
Under the Ottomans, Kandiye (Ottoman Turkish قنديه) was the capital of Crete (Girit Eyâleti) until 1849, when Chania (Hanya) became the capital, and Kandiye became a sancak. In Greek, it was commonly called Megalo Castro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο 'Big Castle').
During the Ottoman period, the harbour silted up, so most shipping shifted to Chania in the west of the island.


=== Modern era ===
In 1898, the autonomous Cretan State was created, under Ottoman suzerainty, with Prince George of Greece as its High Commissioner and under international supervision. During the period of direct occupation of the island by the Great Powers (1898–1908), Candia was part of the British zone. At this time, the city was renamed "Heraklion", after the Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles' city"), whose exact location is unknown.
In 1913, with the rest of Crete, Heraklion was incorporated into the Kingdom of Greece. Heraklion became again capital of Crete in 1971, replacing Chania.


== Architecture, urban sculpture and fortifications ==

Venetian constructions such as the Koules Fortress (Castello a Mare), the ramparts and the arsenal dominate the port area.
Several sculptures, statues and busts commemorating significant events and figures of the city's and island's history, like El Greco, Vitsentzos Kornaros, Nikos Kazantzakis and Eleftherios Venizelos can be found around the city.
Many fountains of the Venetian era are preserved, such as the Bembo fountain, the Priuli fountain, Palmeti fountain, Sagredo fountain and Morosini fountain (in Lions Square).
Around the historic city center of Heraklion there are also a series of defensive walls, bastions and other fortifications which were built earlier in the Middle Ages, but were completely rebuilt by the Republic of Venice. The fortifications managed to withstand the longest siege in history for 21 years, before the city fell to the Ottomans in 1669.


== Municipality ==

The municipality Heraklion was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 5 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Gorgolainis
Heraklion
Nea Alikarnassos
Paliani
TemenosThe municipality has an area of 244.613 km2, the municipal unit 109.026 km2.


== Neighborhoods ==


== Suburbs ==


== Transportation ==


=== Port ===
Heraklion is an important shipping port and ferry dock. Travellers can take ferries and boats from Heraklion to destinations including Santorini, Ios Island, Paros, Mykonos, and Rhodes. There are direct ferries to Naxos, Karpathos, Kasos, Sitia, Anafi, Chalki and Diafani. There are also several daily ferries to Piraeus, the port of Athens in mainland Greece. The port of Heraklion was built by Sir Robert McAlpine and completed in 1928.


=== Airport ===
Heraklion International Airport, or Nikos Kazantzakis Airport is located about 5 kilometres (3 miles) east of the city. The airport is named after Heraklion native Nikos Kazantzakis, a writer and a philosopher. It is the second busiest airport of Greece after Athens International Airport, first in charter flights and the 65th busiest in Europe, because of Crete being a major holiday destination with 7.974.887 travellers in 2018 (List of the busiest airports in Europe).
In April 2018, the inner space of the airport has been modernized and expanded by almost 3.000 s.m., with 11 new gates and new stores. The expansion was a donation by Hellenic Duty Free Shops.
The airfield is shared with the 126th Combat Group of the Hellenic Air Force.
A project for the new airport of Heraklion in Kasteli area is starting at the end of 2017.


=== Highway network ===
European route E75 runs through the city and connects Heraklion with the three other major cities of Crete: Agios Nikolaos, Chania, and Rethymno.


=== Public transit ===

Urban buses serving the city, with 39 different routes. Intercity buses connects Heraklion to many major destinations in Crete.


=== Railway ===
From 1922 to 1937, there was a working industrial railway, which connected the Koules in Heraklion to Xiropotamos for the construction of the harbor.
A study from the year 2000 investigated the feasibility of two tram lines in Heraklion. The first line would link the Stadium to the airport, and the second the center of Heraklion and Knossos.  No approval has yet been given for this proposal.
In the summer of 2007, at the Congress of Cretan emigrants, held in Heraklion, two qualified engineers, George Nathenas (from Gonies, Malevizi Province) and Vassilis Economopoulos, recommended the development of a railway line in Crete, linking Chania, Rethymno and Heraklion, with a total journey time of 50 minutes (30 minutes between Heraklion and Rethymno, 20 minutes from Chania to Rethymno) and with provision for extensions to Kissamos, Kastelli Pediados (for the planned new airport), and Agios Nikolaos. No plans exist for implementing this idea.


== Climate ==
Heraklion has a hot-summer-Mediterranean climate (Csa in the Köppen climate classification). Summers are warm to hot and dry with clear skies. Dry hot days are often relieved by seasonal breezes. Winters are very mild with moderate rain. Because Heraklion is further south than Athens, it has a warmer climate during winter but cooler during summer because of the Aegean sea. The maximum temperature during the summer period is usually not more than 28 - 30 °C (Athens normal maximum temperature is about 6 °C higher). The minimum temperature record is -0.2 °C
A new temperature record for February was set at 27.8 °C, reached on 15 February 2016.


== Colleges, universities, libraries, and research centers ==
University of Crete
Hellenic Mediterranean University (HMU)  (Former TEI)

Foundation for Research & Technology - Hellas
Nicolas Kitsikis Library
Vikelaia Library https://web.archive.org/web/20140605051225/http://www.heraklion.gr/en/municipality/vikelaia


== Culture ==


=== Museums ===

Collection of Agia Aikaterini of Sinai
Museum of Visual Arts


=== Arts ===
The Cultural and Conference Center of Heraklion is a centre for the performing arts.


=== Sports ===
The city is home to several sports clubs. Most notably, Heraklion hosts OFI and Ergotelis, two football clubs with earlier presence in the Greek Superleague, the top tier of the Greek football league system. Furthermore, the city is the headquarters of the Heraklion Football Clubs Association, which administers football in the entire region. Other notable sport clubs include Iraklio B.C. (basketball), Atsalenios (football) and Irodotos (football) in the suburbs of Atsalenio and Nea Alikarnassos respectively.


=== Famous natives ===

Heraklion has been the home town of some of Greece's most significant people, including the novelist Nikos Kazantzakis (best known for Zorba the Greek), the poet and Nobel Prize winner Odysseas Elytis and the world-famous painter Domenicos Theotokopoulos (El Greco).

text.quote: Museum with artifacts from all eras of Cretan history/prehistory, with frescoes, figurines & tombs.
trip: Good museum, especially in combination with the Knossos palast. Under 25 years you don’t have to pay

If you are at all interested in ancient greek history, visiting this museum is a must in my opinion. It is very well labeled and the exhibits are well presented. The building and the exhibitions rooms are very modern. We had only one hour there, which was not enough, but better

On just two stories near the central place in Heraklion you get to meet 2.000 years of history, with a couple of very famous pieces, a lot of important originals, in a very modern and bright architecture and with a lot of information. Even if you have only one hour of spare

We visited the museum on our day at Heraklion. It’s a nice set up with a lot of ancious stuff like coins, plates, jewelry, sculptures and old history I would not go there with small kids as it’s more like an “adult thing” and you need to be interested in history But we liked
Wonderful collection, a must see in Crete together with the Jnossos palace compelx site, very rich collection, prepare from history
Crete is a credle of civilization. The museum offers good overview on the history of this amazing island and is definitely great addition to your visit in Heraklion.
Excellent and comprehensive museum. Allow at least 2 hours to enjoy the exhibits. Covid safe,masks and no of visitorsper room closely observed. Well worth a visit

Even though my husband claimed he had seen enough pottery for a long time he enjoyed the exhibits as well. This museum presents a look into 7000 years of Crete civilization and is a must to visit! We spent almost 2 hours there because so many items are worth to be looked at

We were amazed at the quality and amount of exhibits on display, in this museum. Artefacts in the region of 4000 years old the designs of which almost seemed so modern...shows what we borrow and take inspiration from the past. It does feel a long walk around on a hot day but

We bought the combo tickets for Knossos Palace and this museum which I would recommend anyone with an interest in archeology and history to visit. Amazing collection of items in chronological order, some of which had been made around 5000 BC (pretty mind blowing). Excellent

WARNING!!! IF YOU BUY ONLINE, THEN PRINT YOUR TICKETS OUT BEFORE GOING! I purchased online a combi ticket with Knossos and hired a car. Started at Knossos and went around no problem. Was taking pictures and suddenly my phone screen went blank. I could not access anything on my

A museum you can't miss! So rich collections, so many iconic master pieces, specially for those who like archeology. I suggest to make it in the afternoon, after visiting Knossos palace (and I suggest the combo ticket which is so valuable)
Excellent set up - lots and lots to see so good to have a read a guide to get you to the key exhibits

Nothing to say apart that the collections are splendid and varied. Make sense with nearly 4000 years history. About details, do not book cut the line tickets on the tripadvisor as it is expensive and worthless. Had to call the operator to get the tickets and the desk lady
It is worth a trip to see so much and if for nothing else but see the 3000 year old bee pendent. This old Chao found it mesmerising.

Wonderful collection of ancient artifacts. I spent the entire day here, as there were so many interesting exhibits, and nearly every exhibit had an accompanying description that helped me understand the context. Of course the phaistos disc is a must-see, and there were also lots

This museum had good, although time consuming, COVID protocols in place. When we finally got to see the exhibitions they were very detailed and there were a lot of them. Do allow plenty of time to get round them all. We possibly made the mistake of spending too much time looking

It's an archeological museum like an other at an other ancient archeological site. Please do not missunderstand: you will see exhibits, of wich you neuer thought people 6000 years ago would have used it. But we've missed anything about the usage, the traditional live, the urban

beautiful collections of Minoan and Greek artefacts, lots in very good shape.. lots of vases and amphoraes.. some impressive clay coffins.. museum is very large and require a 2 hours visit .. entrance can be combined with Knossos palace if you buy the ticket in the museum only..

Good museum with a simple layout focusing on displaying as many of the Minoan (and later) artifacts as possible. I'd say its aimed at adults, not a lot for kids to see or do. Not a lot of interpretive art or reconstruction, you are left to visit Knossos for that. In mid August
After Knossos palace you must go to visit the museum with a lot of micenean vessels and much more. The museum is big on 2 floors and you need at least 3 hours to visit completely.

This museum holds a spectacular collection. The gallery’s are modern, well laid out and have good bilingual labels. We booked online and arrived early. Really good social distancing in place with very low visitors allowed in at one time. Can not recommend enough!
Nice museum. Worth going to. More explanation of content would help but the film was good. Staff very friendly

To breathe an authentic atmosphere about the history of Crete, you cannot miss a visit to this very interesting museum. Duration of the visit is almost two hours. I suggest to combine the visit with the Cnosso Palace; it is also possible to buy the combined ticket.

This would have been an informative and enjoyable trip if I did not have the children with me. The security guards clearly did not want the children there and constantly reprimanded them for making a noise or for pointing a finger at a glass case and, heaven forbid, had the

Really impressive museum intelligently presenting how the minoean culture was subtile and influenced all the Mediterranean world. The museography is one of the most modern and smart I saw in Europe and US. Do not hesitate to visit !
Great place to learn about the culture of this beautiful place. It was quite busy and places to eat are limited when we went.
Very nice/wide collection that displays the complete history of Crete. Also, for people under 25, entrance is free!

Excellently organized museum! We bought combined tickets with Knossos palace and the whole package gives you wonderful insight into minoan culture. We did some pre-reads with children, especially ancient stories about myths connected with Knossos, Crete (i.e. Minotaur) and we

The Heraklion Archeological Museum has an excellent collection of artefacts from the Minoan (ca. 1700 BC) civilisation which predates that of classical Greece. The collection includes pottery, jewellery, coins, mosaics, frescoes, statues and weapons and is the ideal complement

Before you go to Knossos, you must visit this excellent museum. It puts the excavations in context and opens up the fascinating world of Minoan cu!ture. Well laid out - allow plenty of time to appreciate the wealth of artefacts displayed here.

I can’t imagine not going to this museum. It’s terrific Knossos was disappointing and I knew it would be but this is why I came Greatest Minoan artifacts in the world are here I even went back it was so good
I was blown away by the intricacy and beauty of many of these relics from Crete's ancient past. Well worth the time when you're in Heraklion.

For antiquarians, the Athens museum should be the best. But I personally was thrilled more by the massive Heraklion Museum--and be prepared to spend at least three hours here--for several reasons. First, Knossos, well worth a visit, was pretty-well Disney-ed up 110 years ago by

Tons of interesting artifacts from Neolithic through Roman periods with good explanations in English. And the snake goddess! We spent over 3 hours and could have honestly stayed longer but the museum was closing.

A wonderfull museum of all the artifacts recovered from Knossos and other locations in Crete. Easy to find at the east edge of the old city and medium size venue with all the displays well shown and explained. Includes the not to be missed Phaistos disc. Head phone and guded
One of the greatest collections that I have seen from a local museum so far. The history of this island zipped in there 😄
a wide variety of artefacts, beautifully presented and notated. Well worth visiting. The building itself was worth a visit.
Spent 3 hours here, very well presented and enlightening, amazing. Then took a taxi up the road and spent 30 minutes at Knossos Palace site,.. that says it all really.
A beautiful museum, with a wonderful collection! You can really learn a lot about the early civilizations! Spacious, clean and with a friendly staff! You must visit!
A must visit when in Crete. All exhibits are amazing. Primarly from the Minoan Civilization period. Honestly one of world’s best museums.

Visit this amazing museum after your visit to the knossis site to getter understand some of the stunning artefacts displayed. Beautifully displayed visiting this museum gives one real insight into the Minoan civilization. Definitely recommend.

The museum had the entire 2nd floor closed the day we visited. Yes, it was posted but there definitely should have been a discount price that day. All the Creten frescoes and Roman pieces weren't available for viewing. It was a short visit for the rainy day we stopped in on. The

To think we almost missed this one. At the end of our trip we had overdosed on museums and almost didn't see this. Out guide at the Palace of Knossos recommended that we not miss this and she was right! Absolutely stunning exhibit items and more meaningful after having viewed

Extensive collection from prehistoric, Minoan to Roman. We went on a guided tour arranged by our cruise ship and saw the highlights of the extensive collection. Not to be missed attraction if one is interested in the history of Crete.
All the history of the Minoan civilazation is presented in a unique way. Commerce, war, art, every day life, religion and burial customs.
Modern and well presented. Cafe not open on the day we visited. Busy even out of the main holiday season.
New museum, great location, à LOT to see, all the history in front of your eyes. A must see, takes less than 2 hours to look around some of the most famous antiques.

It is not like you have a choice if you are in Heraklion. You visit the Temple of Knossos and all the original stuff was moved to the museum. But I bet the really awesome stuff went to London with Evans. So to sum up the experience. This place is clean and well maintained but I
This museum has a collection that dates back several thousand years. The displays explain the ancient history of Crete starting with the Minoans. A walk down history lane.

If you plan to visit just one museum on Crete, choose this one! It is extremely interesting - we learned a lot about the cultures living on and forming Crete som 3-4000 years ago. There are very many finds from Knossos and other cretan cultures. Should you have the opportunity,

We were only able to see the highlights of the Museum, but it was all wonderful and well displayed. There is so much to see and it is organised so you can get a taste of different developments of time.
A wealth of exquisite objects beautifully displayed. Allow a whole morning, afternoon or even the whole day to fully enjoy this museum. Definitely a must!

Well over 10 centuries of super interesting Minoan cultural information. Loads of history in this place, and at 6 euros it's not a bad price either. Check it out while you're in Heraklion before you go to Knossos.

I thoroughly enjoyed this museum. It was easy to find and well sign posted. Security was tight but I was quite happy not dragging my bag around with me. I found the layout easy to navigate and the information easily accessible in that there were plenty of English translation

There is a lot to see here but a combined ticket with Knossos (one visit each - valid three days) is extremely good value and it is worth spending time on the exhibits of particular interest rather than try and see everything

Hi all, Sorry I know my title seems a bit over the top but I've been to a lot of museums and really love Heraklion archeological museum,not only have they a massive and well-preserved/revelant collection but the layout is the Best I ever saw. We've been there with a friend

This large museum has well documented written information in Greek and English to educate the viewer of the historical era the displayed artifacts are from. The number of items in the collection is massive, and could take up to a couple hours to view if you are interested in

This really is a must see. Ensure that you have allotted enough time. I really enjoyed the chronological layout of the different rooms. The written guides introducing a room and the details of the objects really helped understand this most fascinating epoc of Grecian history
Excellent layout in chronological order and all well displayed and labelled. Would definetly recommend a visit.
Very modern building, very good explanations. The display is on two floors. There is a nice outside area with a gorgeous view of the city from a terrace. A must when in Heraklion.

We visited this museum as we wanted to see the artefacts from Knossos which we had visited earlier that day. There is plenty to see and the displays have information in English which is helpful. For adults who are interested in the history of the artefacts it is a great museum,

Having visited the archaeological site in the morning it was interesting to visit this museum to see so many of the artifacts found at the Palace. Would recommend having a guide to make the most of it
After visiting Knossos we also visited the museum to see all the things our guide in Knossos was referring to. Many things to see if a remarkable period.

I've had the fortune to visit the Heraklion Archaeological Museum twice now and hope to get to visit again! The collection and displays are incredible. I could spend hours looking at the highlights and also every item in the museum is exquisite.
Look for the model of the Palace of Knossos to see the sheer size of the place. There are many different exhibits in this museum and it is well worth it to take your time to see all that is included.
Well worth a visit! An incredible amount of artefacts on display. Visit here before going to Knossos as it will help to identify certain aspects.

Very good museum to see lots of ancient Crete art: lots of pots, jewels, figurines, weapons, sarcophagus, wall paintings. Very modern layout, very clean, a proper museum. Recommended to buy the tickets when doing the joint visit with Knossos palace as it is only €1 additional.

This was a great thing to so after spending the morning at Knossos Palace. Their collection was beautifully displayed and curated. We were sorry some of the rooms upstairs were closed. A must see when Heraklion.

A wonderful museum. Certainly popular with all tourists. It has such well written descriptions in English and Greek and other languages available on pamphlets. It is the place to see artefacts from the whole history of Greece especially Crete. A nicely sized museum so that you

Bought the package at Knossos (1€ extra for the museum) and it was great. Good complementary museum to the palace itself since it houses some of the pieces removed from there. Careful about parking around the museum, the wardens are very motivated.
Awesome place with very nice exhibits. Must do. Takes a while if you want to see it all. 3.5 - 4 hours.
This is worth making time to visit to help appreciate the complex and rich history of this island. Our guide was excellent and signage is also good and in english.
So many interesting artefacts from the neolithic especially from the Knossos site and other minoan sites. Simply unique and very well structured. One should start from neolithic and the Roman period
If you are in Heraklion, you must visit this museum. Tickets are not expensive, and there is a lot to see. Finishing not to spoil anything.

Well-organized and amazing place where you can observe the roots and development of stunning Minoan civilization. Don’t miss it!

The museum is in the center of Heraklion across the street from the Astoria Hotel. We spent several hours there looking at the ancient sculptures, pottery, coffins and jewelry. We thought it was more interesting than the Acropolis Museum in Athens.

The Heraklion Archaeological Museum is an excellent collection of antiquities. Interestingly set up by themes with great explanations of the works and culture. You can get a combo ticket with Knossos. Parking is available in the nearby area.

This museum was a real highlight of our holiday in Crete. There's so much on show and plenty space and light to enjoy it. Amazing to see the real Phaistos Disk and artifacts from Knossos right infront of us! If you are in Heraklion don't miss it.
Fun to see the history. A lot of people though and the line in was long. Nice and cold inside. A lot of things to see

Beautiful collection of Minoan (and graeco-roman) archaeological treasures. Go and see for yourself!

Europe’s ancient history presented simply and beautifully. You do not need a guide to enjoy this lovely place. The gift shop is minimal

After extensive renovation, the museum finally has the facilities needed to house such a wide and important array of exhibits hailing mainly from the Minoan civilization. Only thing I would like to comment is that I didn't find an easily accessible map of the ancient cities
Great exhibits of some of the most famous and significant historical arifacts of ancient civilizations. I am glad I can now say I saw these with my own eyes before I die.

I travel a lot and have been to many museums and honestly it is one of the best perhaps the best. Why? the layout of the museum allow for easy follow of history. The artefacts are fantastic. I was amazed at how the Minoan people were such great artisans. Definitely worth the

Heraklion (or more accurately, Heracleon) has an excellent museum, unlike anything you can find on the planet. It houses the best exchibition of Minoan art. The Minoans, at their peak, generated culture that still feels contemporary, and influenced abstract art (Picasso and the

We had just 2 hours. Not enough time! There is so much to see, so much to wonder at, such beauty & ingenuity, so well displayed. We only had time to dip in here & there, and left feeling quite frustrated at how much we missed, as we know we'll never be back. PS be careful not

One of the oldest, largest and most important museums in Greece, and among the most important museums in Europe. The Herakleion Museum is rightly considered as the museum of Minoan culture par excellence worldwide.

This is worth a visit to see the famous frescoes from the palace at Knossos. It is not the best type of museum for kids as not very interactive at all. So if you travel with kids...concentrate on the main things and try to help them engage with the artefacts.
This is fairly new and worth seeing. We were on a cruise and only had a half day in crete so we bought a combo ticket for this s=and knossos palace great value!
Must see it ! Perfect archeological museum and it was good occasion with free entrance on Saturday afternoon
You need to go there. It's a cultural journey that you must be in. It's actually accessible cause it's close to the most know square : the lion square.

An excellent museum, really well curated - taking you through the Minoan, Greek and Roman periods. Definitely recommend visiting here before going to any of the actual archaeological sites around Crete.

Visited this lovely museum before Knosses. Feel it was right way to do it. Bought joint tickets for both venues. Learnt a lot in well laid out museum. Not busy this time of year. Could have stayed longer than the 2 hours we stayed there but, it closes earlier in winter. 4pm.
You can easily spend up to a couple of hours here, very informative and well laid out. Be careful of the times in winter, as it closes at 4pm.

Very informative place, great works of art and archeological foundings. Here You can learn about Cretan (and greek) history, You can almost feel and touch it. Many beautiful subjects from minoan age, i love the FAISTOS, the bull's head and the original pieces of Knossos frescs.

On a short one day visit to Heraklion we visited both the Palace of Knossos and the Archaeological Museum. Doing both complemented each other well. We took a private tour at the Palace but did a self-tour in the museum. The museum was top-notch in its presentation and have

You just cannot go to Crete and fail to visit the Heraklion museum! You will get amazed by the findings, the detailed decorations, the drawings, the coins, and jewelry. I keep wondering what a great civilization that was! No wonder why Minoans had no enemies and their
We had a short visit unfortunately, but the collection, pieces as well as the organisation, but the staff is awfully rude, which quite spoil the visit... I advise to have at least 2hours ahead.

It is a must! We only had a half day, and I could have easily spent an entire day in there and wish I were closer so I could go back. The restaurant was not open, so I can't comment on it, but there are a lot of places to eat in the vicinity.

We went to the museum on the first Sunday of the month (Free admission). Even with the large crowds the staff kept everything flowing smoothly. Pictures are allowed (no flash). They have a lot of items from pre historic (11 century BC and earlier) times and a wonderful display
Well worth a visit shows so much of the history of Crete makes it easier to understand even if you are not a history fan.

Not at all impressive externally but surprisingly good museum inside! What you are left with is the story of the inevitable rise and fall of the Minoan civilization, from the start in the Bronze Age, through Iron Age, it’s peak and decline.. except it lasted over 1,500 years!

2 floors of stuff, the main things of interest are the Minoan-era items prior to the Hellenic era. Very interesting 'Kamares ware' pottery style I've never seen before. Also the fresco styles are unique, somewhat Egyptian-influenced. I didnt know bull-jumping was a sport!

We spent the day at this amazing museum. There are so so many wonderful exhibits to see here you really need time to take everything in. I thought the bathtub exhibit was the most amazing. It’s absolutely beautiful to be able to see all of the things that are in this museum. It
Excellent museum, showing artefacts from Knossos and other Minoan sites. Exhibits set out in a very organized way with plenty of light and space. It certainly enhanced our visit to Knossos.

This is an absolute must-visit location when in Crete. So glad we took time to see it after our visit to Knossos, it gave a much much better perspective of the Minoan civilization. Very impressive collection of artefacts, all real and authentic (not reconstructed as in Knossos),

We were on a short holiday in Crete and decided that we would like to take a day trip to Heraklion and the Palace of Knossos, We found a tour by Sparrow Travel, which suited us as it picked us up and dropped us off near to our hotel. We paid a combined ticket for the

Really enjoyed our visit after seeing Knossos, brought home the importance of the dig with some really interesting art & jewellery. All displays in French, English, German, Greek & Russian. No queuing lots of Information.
First visit to this Museum. We went on an organised tour from Rethymno with Klados. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and my niece listened intently and found the whole experience wonderful.

The exterior of the building can in no way prepare you for the amazing inside of this spacious museum, which in my opinion is easily one of the top 3 Greek museums. It will take some time to explore but it's the ABSOLUTE MUST when you visit Heraklion!
A must when in Heraklion. The exhibits of one of the most ancient civilisations in the world are spectacular. Don't miss the Phestos discus. Great renovation work.
Easy going museum in the center of Heraklion. Well laid out and interesting without being boring. Highly recommend.
This is a mst if you like history. Very well displayd, although they could work a liitle with the lights. Generous photo policy. Good explanations. Not to be missed if you are interested in history.

After visited Knosos that lacks good and scientific explanations, we also visited Archeological museum, which was great and to me it seemed like everything makes much more sense. There are two floors + usually one extra, smaller exhibition. Btw: there are some dates when they

If you like artifacts and history this place is for you. Very interesting to see how the civilization developed on Crete. I didn’t have time to go to the actual site, but felt like this gave me a good feel for the development of the early civilizations and their beliefs. Highly

One of the best archaeological museums although it doesn't have the size of the British Museum or Louvre. Every object shown is absolutely unique and notable for understanding of the importance of Crete civilization at the time of Minoans.

Spent the day touring the palace of Knossos and also this museum. They really go hand in hand as most of the artifacts here come from Knossos. I would actually stop here first if you have a choice and if you can get a good tour guide it is a major plus. Mostly pottery and

I went on a Sunday after going to the Palace of Knossos. I ended up being free entry. The courtyard was beautiful: columns, shaded with trees and lots of places to sit. A great place to sit and chill out before or after a visit to the museum. You do have to go through a little

Excellent museum, showing artefacts from Knossos and other Minoan sites. Allow two hours or more if you want to rest between exhibits. See this before going to Knossos. There is a combined ticket for both, and if you are over 65, hold and bring an EU passport with you, it's
We went all they way from Sissi to see this museum but unfortunately it was closed as the staff were on strike!
Nicely laid out and presented -top quality museum - well worth a visit! It’s a good 1-2 hour visit. Highly recommended

After visiting Knossos I wanted to see some of the frescos and other original remains The place is very well organized and is full of interesting excavations It has English explanations and you can take pictures of most items There was no guide or audio guide options which

We visited with are 6 month old and used a stroller inside. The Museum has lots to look at and the combo ticket with the archeological site does not cost much more. We first went to the museum and then the site but I would do it the other way around on the next visit.

Do not miss this museum if you go to Heraklion!! Everything is well-thought-out and you move through the museum in chronological order, which helps you to build on what you learn and do so progressively. Took 2 hours to go through all the rooms (2 floors); I took lots of pics.

An incredible wealth of artifacts and information about the past. One could spend much more than 2-3 hours here, but I found that 3 hours was the maximum amount of time before I was so exhausted that i couldn't take in any more (and I did not read every sign or look closely at
Everything Minoan you can think of. Spent about three hours here. Well organized and presented artifacts.

I have never seen anything like these artifacts. So much history and so much truth. We rented a car and saw CRETE. It was an unbelievably Amazing trip. If you visit Greece please island hop and make sure to stop by Crete and see this BEAUTIFUL island full of history and
It was totally one of the best museums I have visited. Really organized and all of its exhibits were stunning!

The exhibits are well done and displayed many artifacts. We learned a lot from the descriptions. We appreciated the free stroller to use for our baby and there is a coat check as well. The garden area outside the museum is peaceful. It was nice that the museum stayed open until

A story well told and explained of the life of human of Crete, through its objects of everyday life, art and other artifacts, with details that are worth to know. I also enjoyed very much the discovery of their civilizations, their moments, their religion, and much more.

The museum holds most of the great finds from the early civilisation on Crete. Wonderful. Early jewellery is exquisite and early writing v important as well as huge pots and tiny statues of female deities. Really valuable to go before Knossos and Malia etc. Get an idea of the

Interesting artifacts to view. You can take pictures in some areas of the museum. There are good descriptions in each area to identify what you are looking at. Also, there are museum personnel in each room who can assist with questions. If you are going to visit the Palace or
Don't leave Heraklion without seeing this incredible museum, which opened up a new world of old history for me.
Visited this museum on a recent trip to Heraklion would recommend highly. It is well laid out and extremely informative and needs at least 3/4 hours to get the best out of it. Well worth a visit.

What could I say: incredible museum, a must-do in a trip to Crete to learn the history and events that made this island. But most of all, to understand how small we are thinking to our technology comparing with what they were able to do at that time with nothing. I don't know
A very interesting and modern Museum with lots of exhibits from Cretan history. Good facilities toilets, restaurant etc,

The artifacts on display are very impressive and give an excellent record of (particularly) the Minoan history and culture. The downside for me was the the lack of explanation of the 'bigger picture'. A bit more effort explaining the context in which these artifacts were found

This museums contains a collection of all things Minoan such as jewellery, pottery, seals, art, etc, as well as some original frescos from arechelogical sites. Considering the age of the Minoan culture the displayed objects are really impressive and give an idea how advanced the
Easy to spend at least half a day here - even if you are not a history buff, just appreciate the design and art! Easy to access from Bus Station A from anywhere along north coast resorts.
Amazing artifacts from the Minoan age. Well worth a visit, preferably after a tour to Knossos Palace with a tour because everything will have more meaning.
This museum has been so improved. There is now aircon. The exhibits are well lit. There are intelligent display boards. It is great
Amazing place to visit, it was very easy to get there by bus. They have a great service. You can get anywhere by bus, just check the schedule where do you want to go. And be on time.
Has most of the finds from classical Knossos. The original murals are here although reconstructions can be seen at the site. Some prepalatial and Roman era finds too.

I'm not usually a museum person, I'll admit, but my friend convinced me to visit the Archaeological Museum with her and I'm honestly glad I did. If you go to the Palace of Knossos before, for one Euro more, you can also include a ticket to the Museum, so it's worth it to check

His museum is a must see attraction. Even if you are a clueless fool who loves only celebrity culture you should come here just to see how little we have developed in 5000 years. The museum is stuffed full of magnificent artefacts from the Minoan culture, many of which were

The museum focuses on the Minoan and Roman periods of Crete's history. The Minoan component is particularly well-presented, and is an essential complement to a visit to Knosssos or any other of the Minoan sites in the region. The museum is easily accessible. Tickets to visit

My husband and I just went to the Heraklion Archaeological Museum this afternoon, and were completely impressed with both the size and scope of the collection, and its presentation. The museum begins with the Minoan civilization, that began around 7000 B.C. and ended around 1100

We had a great time exploring the elaborate collection of the museum, they have a lot of beautifull pieces that help you visualise the life in the old civilisations. If you plan on visiting the Knossos palace site within 3 days it’s worth buying the combo ticket, saves you a lot

I you are in Crete even for one day, a visit to an Archaeological museum is a must. The building seems to be newly renovated, spacious halls, amazing artifacts on display with English commentaries. Highly recommended!
The museum is light,airy and spacious and boasts an amazing collection of Minoan artefacts which are displayed well...

16 euros gets you a combined ticket for the museum and knossos which you can spread over 3 days. It's basically full of artefacts from 5000 bc to the Roman period but specialising in the Minoan period up to 1450bc. If you like pots this is for you. Seriously some impressive

This is really one of the best places in the world to see an extensive collection of Minoan art and artefacts. This is now housed in a modern purpose built museum which overlays some historic ruins in the grounds. If you plan to visit Knossos buy a joint entry ticket for
It was one of the best local museum I have visited. Great ancient objects. Very good architectural project and lovely display. You will need at least two hours.
Just when you think that you can't learn anymore about Ancient Greece or be overwhelmed with ancient artefacts you visit the Heraklion Archaeological Museum and you're still blown away!!!

More than 4.500 years of history till today very interesting!!! The staff have to be more friendly and helpful!!! I recommend to everyone who like the history of Crete and not only!!! It's a must to visit..

Visit Knossos first. We had a private guide and she was able to relate the objects to our earlier visit to Knossos. So much to see. Some of the exhibits were spectacular including the jewellery, religious objects and burial baths.
immense quantity of well-presented ancient Minoan artifacts, including the most important from Knossos palace....

The ruins of Knossos near Heraklion are impressive, but they have no museum, you only see footings and the ruins of buildings, many restored in the early 20th century. To truly see Cretan culture - from the earliest times through the Minoan civilisation to the time of the Romans

This is a must visit after the Knossos Archaeological Site.....there is so much to see and so many exhibits are in amazing condition considering their age. Make sure you purchase the combo ticket which gives you entry to both.

Spent about three hours. The artefacts were fabulous and so well preserved! What a civilisation were the Minoans. Exhibits set out in a very organised way with plenty of light and space. A MUST visit!
Oldest stuff I have seen. Mind blowing massive collection of statues, artefacts, ancient writing back to 5 centuries BC. Loved the economics records. Minoans rock!

We visited this museum in October 2018. The collection of rare artifacts is unbelievable. The exhibition is very well organised. Although it was busy with many German groups we could find a chance to approach every showcase we were interested in. One recommendation for tourists

We did things the opposite of the tours. we saw the museum first and then Knossos. We like this better because we feel we can place the items in the museum better when we go the site. This worked out well in this case as their is a scale model in the museum. It is very well laid
Made two trips to the Archaeological Museum - there is a lot to see. It is all very well presented. Can be crowded.

A very well organized display with some world class highlights. The exhibit includes English captions, well lighted. Even the last video/slide exhibit on the history of the Minoan archeological digs and the main players in creating the museum held a lot of interest. It certainly
There is a lot to see. It puts a visit to the ruins of Knossos Palace into context and is very interesting.

If you have been to some of the archeological sites on the island, this gives you a great insight of the arts and crafts. Some of the pots and figurines are so beautiful, it is hard to imagine they have survived for such a long time. Enjoyed it very much!
Incredible iconic artifacts of ancient crete. Amazing stuff. Recommend a tour with Ionna Glyptis to get full and correct context; the wall plaques are useful, but not always complete or accurate.
interesting and very well laid out. with good information for each display, definitely worth a visit.

I'm very glad I visited the museum (which was included in my 8 euro OAP ticket for Knossos. Seeing all the Minoan artefacts enhances the whole Knossos experience. The highlight for me was the Minoan draughts game. But all the pottery and jewelry were also remarkable. I didn't

I believe the museum had just completed a multi year renovation and it is beautiful. You can spend as much or as little time as you would like here depending on how you pace yourself. The collection is vast and beautiful.
Amazing way to complete ones visit of Knossos. Visit in that order. Only negative is the pushy tour groups
Great collection of ancient artefacts. I really liked the amphoras with the animals painted on them! Excellent!

This place is a treasure trove of Ancient Greek artefacts and is a great thing to do after visiting Knosos All the artefacts are displayed in different rooms with signs explaining their importance If you like the ancient world go here!

I absolutely loved this visit; definitely worth a go. Immerse yourself in the local history and culture. Very inspirational early art and crafts on display. A strong sense of centuries of life gone by and local specificity.

For an extra 1 euro we added a visit to this museum to our ticket price at the Knossos site. After spending about 3 hours wandering around Knossos we made the effort to drive into Heraklion and visit the museum where all of the ACTUAL artifacts, including frescoes that were
this museum is a treasure for the world and the humanity Every piece is unique and beautiful is a visit worth

There was so much to see and it was good to be with a Guide who was able to explain the exhibits in more detail . The fact that most of the artefacts were thousands of years old and that some had been painstakingly pieced together was amazing . It was a wonderful place to visit

We enjoyed very much the marvellous artifacts. Exhibitions are pretty well organized. It would have been an interesting visit, if there hadn't been so many noisy groups, all led by screaming guides. What a pity for such an important museum.

The museum itself is beutiful! We didn’t have a guide! And I strongly recomend that, otherwise all you do is looking on clayfigures, statues, tools and so on, without any background! We ordered combined tickets for 16 Euros, because we Will visit Knossos later! A single ticket
This is a very interesting museum with a lot to see and read about. If you are visiting Knossos or going this is the place to see all the artifacts from there.
We only managed the ground floor as time was limited. Interesting museum with lots of Minoan artefacts on display.

Absolutely wonderful museum so much to see & take in will definitely return next time I am in Crete. You could easily spend half a day or more to fully see all of the superb exhibits. Cafe was closed when we got there (quite late on a Saturday afternoon) so can’t comment on
A lot you can see and learn about ancient history of the Crete. Only thing that was missing is , you can't buy book or a catalog about the current or the past exhibitions.
One of the greatest museums in Greece with a huge collection of Minoan Art. Went here on a guided tour after a Knossos visit.
The museum included so many artefacts from Minoan times. It was quite busy while we were there but this did not pose a problem. Toilets could have been cleaner.
So important and so beutiful museum exhibits, everyone must visit this Museum! Infact, you can spend there all the day!

Huge museum. Welcome cool temperatures from the heat of the city. Lots of very interesting exhibits and well laid out. Bags are scanned on the way in and liquid sprays etc (we had a sunscreen in our bag) are kept on entry and returned to you via a cloakroom ticket system as you

Great displays , well thought out and presented . A must for anybody who appreciates history and the achievements of the Minoan civilisation . You could easily spend a couple of hours in the museum . The museum is Airconditioned and well lit .

The place to visit. Great archaeological museum with unbelievable artifacts. Very good organized museum on 2 levels. Excellent presentation. No problem to take photos. Don't forget to visit Knossos palace at the same time.
google: Reading previous comments I wasn't sure if visiting it is a smart decision especially considering relatively high price. As the Knossos was eliminated from our must-see list (due to the information that the half of it is closed for …

One of my favourite museums in the world! Very well curated and well explained. We were short of time and didn't get to see the rest of the last few rooms but the museum did a fabulous job to bring history to live. Definitely worth a visit when in town

Quite interesting. especially the pottery
A bit more signs to show the second floor entrance. Maybe not an issue normally, but in corona times the places was pretty empty... So no flows to follow

text.quote: This restored fort built by Venetians in the 16th century has dramatic views & artifacts on display.
trip: The fortress is very impressive from the outside, and you can enjoy great views of it from different points in Heraklion, without visiting. But if you have a little time, I would definitely recommend visiting it from the inside - the entry fee of EUR 4 is well worth it. On the
An important site to visit. Interesting insights to Cretan history and good viewpoint for the harbour.
If you are into medieval maritime history it is a must see and walk along the long quayside to the lighthouse on the levy, very interesting and nice site

A great place to get a glimpse of the old town. The fortress dominates the port and offers the most amazing views to the modern city and to the vast sea towards north. After the port there is a 2km strip of land/port that you can walk and enjoy the view of the city all the way

Friday 28th August and we were sightseeing and exploring in Heraklion. It is impossible not to see this massive 16th century Fortress which dominates the entrance to the Old Harbour. We did walk up to the Fortress, had a look and continued walking along the harbour wall.

We could see the fort from our hotel and had already added it to our list for the holiday €4 for over 25’s cannot be beaten (under 25’s need to prove with a passport) and it’s mostly open even with Covid precautions in place 👍 Spent a great hour wandering around and got some

Fortress looks really interesting however inside is museum that I haven’t decided to visit but also ticket needs to be bought if you want to approach to the construction. For free you can look only from the embankment

you dont have to be a history buff to enjoy walking round Castello del Molo. visit the roof to get panoraic views of Heraclion. A little disappointed as was charges full price for a 69 year old as England was no longer in the EU ?

It is a nice port. Nice view to the sea after arriving from the port. Careful drive is extremely important because the poice will fine you for almost everything. The city is not that nice, so we decided after a short walk to take the road and drive to the beaches.
well rebuild, excellent exposition, nice personnel, pleasant in hot weather, view to the port - 1 hour is enough
The best place in Iraklion of course. Nice to go for a long walk there especially in the morning. Be carefull with big waves ))
A fascinating insight into Crete and Heraklion's history, well worth a visit. A good way to fill up a morning or afternoon.
This is a small castle which is very well maintained from the outside - I believe that you cannot enter it anymore. Very beautiful building and great place to have a walk in the evening.

This is a fantastic castle situated in the harbour. It was blowing a gale when we arrived and the high walls made a very good wind break. At €1 concession entrance it was well worth a visit. There were several levels to explore, some with sparse furnishings and one area I

Beautiful well kept fortress near the Heraklion harbour. It was a lovely walk from the ship to the fortress, not far away, to visit an interesting Venetian fortress. You can see the lion of venice as soon as you're approaching the walls. Beautiful location, full of history.

The castle was a welcome surprise after the disappointment of Knossos. Well maintained with a massive interior that was nice and cool. The top was incredibly hot, but some of the best breezes and views are to be found up there. The entrance can be a little hard to find, as

From our cruise ship we can see this eye catching 16th century fortress and from the port its just walking distance. This was our first place to explore in Heraklion. The fortress has different rooms to exhibit artefacts and cannons. There were explanations of how this sea port
Great view of the city and of the sea from the exterior of the fortress but also very interesting exhibition of findings

In the early 13th century, Candia (modern Heraklion) and the rest of Crete fell under the control of the Republic of Venice. Initially the Byzantine walls remained in use, and they underwent various modifications. Following the fall of Constantinople in 1453, the expanding
Large and largely empty fortress. Sparse documentation on the areas but worth a short visit. Good views from the top.

The Castello del Molo situated at the entrance to the old Port of Heraklion is in a good state of repair despite having been built in the 16th Century by the Republic of Venice. We made a brief study of its fascinating history which includes the long siege of Candia and
We rented a car for the whole day trip. The city is interesting with many places to eat local food. I have my camera always with me. Castello del Molo is a great photo stop place.
Visited here on day trip to herkalion only 2 euros to go in. Some nice views off the top well worth a visit
Some artifacts inside. Nice view from the top. Interesting construction. Doesn't take too much time to visit, so if you are in the area, definitely visit!

Interesting defensive fortification and it is explained well in the narrative posters. It is really large and the view from the first roof is worth the climb up. The as been some type of defensive fortification there since the Minoans. During the Ottoman Period there was a
This fortress, destroyed by the merciless Otomans in the 17th century, is now in a good shape. Great views from the top

Spent an 1.25 hours here while trying to find a filler activity before dinner. The presentation of the history of this castle was well done. We could roam around most of it. All the displays are in Greek or English ... and it was only 2 E/person

It was great to be able to go into Koules to understand the layout etc. We didn’t realise it was also so well set up as a museum, focussing on the events affecting the building. It was wonderful. It was also peaceful, because most people seemed to miss the small entry sign and
There is some great history about this location. It’s too bad there is more artifacts that could be associated with it. Over all a must see if you are in Heraklion.

Sitting at the entrance of the Venetian harbour of Heraklion is Castello del Molo ("Sea Fortress") otherwise known today as Koules Fortress. Being part of the line of defence of the port in the past, this fortress holds plenty of history and totally worth the €2 entrance fee!
Nice old fort to walk around and get nice views of the city, harbor and port from the top of the walls.

It is just €2 to go inside the fortress. It was interesting (and cool) inside. Lots of information. A video is playing giving more of the history (a little too long for my liking, but there are seats.) Beware! The toilet is on the top floor and take your own paper.

We visited Heraklion Marina and saw the harbour walls and thought we would explore more. Considering that this is so old it is well preserved and maintained. It lovely to walk the length of the walls and view the comings and going of the marina and ferry port.

The Catello del Molo is an impressive fortress that overlooks the ocean and even has roof access. It also is a great walk for people looking for some exercise, but be sure to bring water and to wear sunscreen. Also, I would not try to get on the wall. It's fairly tall and the
Didn’t pay to go in but enjoyed the walk around and along the harbour area. Nice building some pretty views
Good place, and interesting. Part of city history. Great view from top. And not so busy and crowded.
Nice place to visit for everybody. The view from the top is amazing, great to take photos or just look at the beutifull Heraklion city
Wonderful wonderful wonderful wonderful wonderful place nice place for kids a lot of fun thank you very much about helping to do fun

Visited the Castillo del Molo today . Built in the 16 th century . The views from above we’re breathtaking. There are many “holes in the wall “ picture opportunities, a photographer’s delight . Entry was free today . Various rooms in the castle have various images , information

Fortress built in 16th century is located within the Old Venetian port. There’s a sign post indicating the entrance which is on the right of pathway, or continue to end of sea wall on the left. Entry fee only €2. It’s cool inside the chambers with no trip hazards, clean and

Really interesting place to go! Only €2 for adults and students go free! Had a great time exploring this fortress and it was amazing going to the roof and looking at the views! This is a must see in Heraklion!
Very nice fortress, with an interesting museum to visit inside. 2€ ticket and you can enjoy both the inside and the views over the harbour from the rooftop.
Larger than I expected Well done, all info in english as well as Greek Good to read of the city history Nice roof area to view the harbour and city Value at only 2 euro each
If you are in Heraklion you must check out this. But be aware that there is a 2,2 km road each way, in the sun with no shade - so bring good walking shoes, sunscreen and water.

It was interesting to see this fortress that was able to hold off invaders for 21 years -and only then to fall because one of the people who worked on the defenses defected to join the invaders. It was also interesting to see how the wall leading up to the fortress created a

It is small, but definetely worth the visit. The entrance is €2,- and children are free. Upstairs on the terrace you have a beautiful view over te sea and harbor. And inside you can see all the canons and read about the history.
Well worth the 2 euro entrance fee just for the atmosphere inside the massive stone walls. Very well presented and a great vantage point across the port

Bring your walking shoes AND water... it's about 2.2km each way... it gets hot in the afternoon with very little shade... so apply sunscreen. There's WC along the way so you are in good company! Nice sea breeze.

There aren't many sites in Heraklion after visiting Knossos and the museum, so why not take a stroll down to the sea and watch tourists get drenched by the spray from waves, stare at the countless shades of blue, and walk along a beautiful castello. The breeze is a nice change
It's cheap to go in and has nice views at the top. However, I didn't think there was lots to see and read about.

I cannot resist any castle or fortress ; and this one is a beauty. Additionally it is really easy to access and a pleasure too : the walkway to it and the pier further down is a gathering place for the young people of Heraklion, especially late afternoon. Good fun to watch it

We had short stay in Heraklion. Originally we were headed for Knossos, but ultimately decided against it and opted to spend time here instead. We all enjoyed our time taking pictures and wondering about. Very nicely preserved with information throughout as well as a video.
This is where we used to start our afternoon walks. The views are great, of both the sea and the city. And the walls of the fortress provide a nice backdrop for photos.

The second most interesting place in the city. After visiting the archaeolgical museum it's a good idea to walk downtown towards the harbour and finish the visit in this stronghold. It's a Venetian castle well restaured and with interesting information inside. The price is cheap
Nice place. Really beautiful castle. The staff is really kind. The best place for photos! The ticker is only 1€!
beautiful place to visit. You can walk there to empty your mind.... but sometimes people do not take care of it and they throw rubish and trashes...
The (albeit skewed) historical perspective at Koules makes it a reasonable way to pass the time, but the superstar here is the unforgettable view from the top of the castle.
Nice view from the top of the building. Cool inside. Old history. Cheap prize to walk inside. It is worth it!
We really enjoyed our stroll to the port and visit to the Castello. Views are really beautiful and sea breeze enjoyable!

Was stunned by the prices to go inside this castle we had recently been in my opinion ripped off by a museum in piskopiano so was expecting a pricey tag to go inside i was shocked to see it was €2 each adult to go inside we wondered in and found our selves up stairs with the sea

A Venetian Fortress, used in the defence of the port of Heraklion. Excellent exhibition display inside & superb views from the outer, upper area. Well deserving of a visit

I really enjoyed my time visiting the Koules Venetian fortress - an iconic feature of the Heraklion port. With a nominal entry fee of €2, you can enjoy a good hour or so wandering around, with amazing views over the port as well. A must see if you're in Heraklion.

Spent about an hour here one morning. Cost is 2€. Indoor exhibit is neat, outside is less of an exhibit and more of an outlook. Very pretty building.
Enjoyed our visit, although quite a bit of restoration work was still being undertaken. Some interesting exhibits and amazing views. Would not recommend for those with mobility issues.
Only 2 euros for entry. Has some great views from the top. Nice and cool inside although not much to see there. Worth a look if you are in the area.
The views were amazing and alot of interesting history for very little entry price. Steps were step to the top but views were worth the climb

A big fort guarding the harbour. There is a lot of information on display in English, plus a video, so you do get a full story. The restoration seems to have been done successfully, and we really enjoyed this site. Well worth a visit.
One of the most beautiful sights I've ever seen. It has to travel to Crete to learn the history of this island

This is a great site with a lot of information, and just to go in and see the thickness of walls and structure is worth it! Lots of information posted in English, and the views from up top were fantastic!
I can’t say any more than that really! Disappointed not to be able to access it. Despite website opening times there was no one to even ask what time it opened!

Beautiful views, cute dogs and a great chance to stretch your legs walking along the see wall. Great opportunity for photos.

Good to find out about the fortification There are cannons that have been recovered from shipwrecks which in interesting. Nice view over the harbour. Probably of more interest if you know more about the history.

To be honest I wasn’t sure wether to pay to visit, but very glad I did. Really good value, pay the extra to go to the top it’s very cheap and great views. There are toilets on the roof top if you need them.

Great place to visit with the family, fantastic views of the bay and marina. Be warned though the entrance is only on one side and if you walk upto it from the wrong side you will find yourself having a long walk around! Entrance fee is a few euros and its definetly worth

Having read about Koules on Trip advisor, we were keen to visit. If travelling by car, there is parking in the neighbouring port car park for €3. This is a 5 minute walk from Koules and a good base to leave the car to explore other sights. Entry was €1 each as it was November -

Lovely paved road that leads to Coule Castle. It’s open and you can go up and enjoy the view of the port and city. You can walk run take your kids and animals for walkies. In the entrance you ll find delicious pop corn and nuts to buy. Worth visiting!

At the end of 25th August right on the water, you cannot miss it. It is very well preserved and the views from it are great. For a single euro, you cannot pass up on a way to spend an hour, if you have the time. Note: It can be windy, so dress appropriately.

2 euros seems excellent value, but as an OAP this was reduced to just 1. The ground floor was well presented with a lot of historical information. Sadly the disabled lift was out of action, so I had to struggle up almost 40 steps to see the view from the battlements. Well worth
It's a place full of history . The view is amazing you can see the whole town of Iraklio and take some nice photos a.
This castle was restored by the local authorities as we were informed and it is really interesting and worth to visit. It is nicely lighted in the interior and from the terrace the view is amazing.
Neat place to see. The views from the top are great. They need to repair/replace or add some hand railings for easier climbing of steps.

We went about an hour before sunset and was the best time (not so many people)! You will need around 1 hr to see and read everything. Place was clean, very spacious inside and you do not feel castrophobic. Don't forget to go to the roof of the Castello, best place to look at

Superb Venetian fort in great condition with nice views of the harbour and the adjacent town of Heraklion. For two euros plus kids go free this is a bargain! Nicely renovated interior with some interesting visual displays and info boards in Greek and English! Views from upper

Venetian castle, beautifully restored and lit to showcase its local history as a fort in the 1400s. Very affordable entrance, make sure to visit & enjoy the beautiful views from the terrace.

Only 2e entry and a very informative museum to the history of Heraklion and Crete. Great toilets too.

Very cheap (2 Euro per person) with cool atmosphere inside. From the roof there are great views of the sea, the port, the marina and the whole city. Excellent potential for amzing pictures of the above or persons you like. Even in a very hot day it keeps an internal low
It was €2 or 3 per person. Very interesting attraction. The view from up top was great. It’s a nice place to view Heraklion from.

It was a very pleasant walking and learning about the cretans, venetians and turks fights for those lands.
For just €2 you can enter the fort and learn some facts about Cretan history. You can go to the top and enjoy the view. A cool expierence.
We went to visit this fortress which is down by the marina. It was very interesting and a really nice walk.

a nice walk at night to see the castello, just be careful not a lot of light, close to nice restaurants, shopping and hotels
Great place to visit. There is a lot of content inside the fortress to see. Good opportunitiy to learn something about Heraklion hostory without using google/wikipedia Entrance is only 2 eur.

It’s a nice one hour program in Heraklion, Crete. The view is really nice and planes are starting and landing all the time (airport in the near). The port is nice too and some really nice restaurants are not too far away ;)

Hey will love this place. Only €2 entry for adults and it will keep them occupied with lots of nooks and crannies to explore. The history of the castle is told for the adults in boards around the various rooms. The story is fascinating, well worth the admission fee. Also there
Wonderful structure, exhibits, and views. A venue must if you are visiting this lovely Greek city. A 21 year siege against the Ottoman Turks!
Nice Venetian fort well restaured and interesting. Affordable entry price : 2€ (High season) A lot of nice pictures to be taken from the terrasse (Great views)

Amazing corner of this city, just out of time. Wonderful building, seeble from the distance. In my opinion one of the most iconic things here.

... by the fishing boats. If you like the sea, walking along moored fishing boats and the such tjis is a must-do in Heraklion (not a day-filler, though: maybe 30 min)

Lots of interpretive panels to explain the history of the fortifications. Great views for taking photos of the city. Cheap parking near the port terminal to the east

Walked passed the castle after dinner, therefor it was only to be viewed from the outside. And then it is just a massive old building. Nothing special done to make it attractive in the evening unfortunately.
We fell in love with this castle. Beautiful views. Better than anything else we’ve seen on Crete. We want to move in lol
Really surprised by this Castello but certainly not disappointed. Well worth the visit with some interesting aspects

you can't help seeing it wherever you are in town-avoid crowded hours-wear comfy shoes and take lots and lots of photos
Nice fort, amazing to realize it is a couple centuries old and has survived a lot of historical events. View from top over the city is very nice.

Built by the Venetians in the early 16th century. Old ships, filled with stones were sunk to create a platform on which the Koules Fortress was built. Nicely restaurated.

With just 2 euros you can imagine a little the lives of people who lived in 1600 . You can also go to the top of the fortress to have a nice view.

Lovely old castle and part of the local history and the defence of the port. Simply striking and worth taking time in this old town to view.

I have visited Koules several times and always loved it. The building is so historic, athmospheric and you can almost travel back in time when you are there. The displays and location are impressive and it is a nice walk by the sea just to get there. I would really recommend it

Wow what a nice piece of history to visit, not only cheap to enter but nicely laid out. You can really feel like you are there when it was first built, and only a short stroll from the centre of town with a large cheap car park nearby at the port.

Great place to visit in Heraklion, 2Euro entrance fee, loads of information inside and lots of history, Theres lovely views from the top of the harbour, There a few benches inside and there are toilets available.

Especially for the modest entrance fee worth a short stop. On top some nice and ugly views of the harbour. Below cannons and bullets. Nicely rebuilt over the past years.

Nice walk next to the sea. A Must see attraction!! Really enjoyed that walk with my wife and we highly recommend walking to Castello during the evening.
We were lucky to visit the Castello del Molo in late April before the crowds arrived. Enjoy a beautiful walk out to the site and then the site itself. Well worth the walk. Beautiful

This castle/fort is beautiful! On a great day it looks amazing on the water! Architecture is simply beautiful!
A typical fort on the edge of the Harbour, the have just done it up inside and out, must have cost a fortune.

Can’t complain, cheap to look around a nice piece of history in a pretty run down city! Definitely worth a visit. Lovely views from the top.

3 euros full price and 1 for seniors. An easy walk around with plentiful well written displays inside. Clean and usable public toilets inside. Good views from the parapets. All in all this is an impressive construction.

A wonderful place at a very good price. Must visit it, Wonderfully well maintained bu the govt. This castle must have been hard to conquer for enemy forces in its era. Pretty well defended it must have been in its time.

My husband and I visited the fortress on our honeymoon. The fortress has a reasonable entrance fee and well laid out information. We enjoyed walking through the inside of the fort and learning about all the centuries of history. A great spot to visit and wander through, with
