Nice and probably must visit when in Crete. The exposition is hard to read so make sure you watch the videos of the site before or after. Don't hesitate to take small kids it can be done with a stroller. Very good fruit juices at the entrance
Very impressive place but be prepared to queue to get in. Under 18 and students, bring a photographic ID to get free entry.
A glimpse of history. Well maintained. Must visit. Non EU students have a discounted fare of EUR 8 for a joint ticket for the palace and the Archeological museum. Please don't forget your ID cards :p

Knossos is the largest archaeological site on Crete and has been called Europes oldest city. Palace complex of extreme beauty was built by  unknown builders. The oldest settlement is about 7000 BC. The palace of Knossos probably was the …
15 euro each... Its been a delusion, i was aspect something more. 15 euro are too much.

Awesome walk through history. The tours are definitely worth while, but also allow yourself time to see everything at your own pace too. Those perfect picture moments are hard to come by due to the amount of guests, so be patient or be …
Very proud we visited this magnificent palace.
If ancient Greek history interests you then this is a must
15 euros to get in. If you have a guide for 4 people its other 100 euro. Takes about 1 and a half hours to walk around .I've been to better places of interest around Europe
If you travel to Crete, must go to this place. The visit doesn't take too long. Archaeology fans would love it. Entrance is free for European Union students.
Fantastic ruins of a Minoan palace!! If you like archaeology and Greek mythology, this is a great place to visit.

We'll, it's Knossos, but it's also a reconstruction in plaster and colours of what the archeologists who explored it thought it COULD have been. Other Minoan ruins throughout the island are more honest. A guide can make things livelier perhaps.
A great day out.  The ancient ruins are wonderfully preserved and renovated and you get a real sense of the opulence and high standards of the ancient Greeks.

Fantastic site! Excellent service from the stuff!
Proud to be greek!
Old.  Too restaured

The temple is in very bad shape as it is very old and all there is left are old stones.
So old that even the landscape is not what it used to be: the temple was built next to a river that doesn't exist anymore.
A lot of what you see has …
Amazing!!!
Amazing site for ancient history lovers. Get here early as it gets BUSY!!! Organise a guide if you can or if not definatley get the guidebook.

A must see place if you visit Crete...very well presented. As ever the Greeks grossly undercharge their visitors.... if this was anywhere in northern Europe they would be charging three times as much. A great opportunity to take some money off the rest of the EU being missed!
Truly stunning piece of archeology. Would recommend acquiring the services of an authorised guide to get the most out of your visit.

Knossos palace being one of the most famous and important landmarks mentioned in history books of Ancient Greece along with the it's crucial role in Greek mythology, should hold a special place in every tourist's heart that decides to visit …

Incredible place, not because of the ruins, but because of the history behind!
Children under 18 can enter free of charge, students can use a picture of the student's id and enter free. Adults 15 €.
Fascinating historical site!
Spoiled by large organised groups of tourists with their own guides, groups which are disregarding towards individual tourists like myself and my wife.
Quite an interesting to see the old palace plan in 3D :) Though most part of it was recreated in modern days.

Where does Arthur Evan's dream end and the reality begin? His flights of creativity may have altered the site permanently, but at least we have this amazing foundational city that inspires just as much wonder as before it's discovery.
If like history it's a great place.
One of the most important European archeological sites. Definitely worth visiting. If visiting in summer, better have a hat and water.
Amazing. A wonderful experience of ancient history.

Amazing knossos palace, has interesting literature dotted around explaining the history. But be aware it can get very busy so go early morning. Also sometimes the layout can be a bit confusing making you way out but you work it out in the end.

This is one of the oldest archaeological sites I have visited so far. The palace is amazingly well thought out and craftly build. The remains show existence of a civilisation very advanced for their times.

Get the combined ticket for the palace and the archeological museum, which are valid for 3 days. My visit ~5pm on a weekday in May was fantastic for seeing a very empty palace venue, where I could read every plaque undisturbed, did not have …
Kinda disappointing.

Great place to learn a bit more history of the Minoan period in Crete. Evans (The British excavator) did an amazing job restoring some of it so we can have a better idea of what it used to look like. Recommended that you get a guide, they …

Highly disputable reconstructions of a fascinating site. The whole concept needs to be rethought, including on site guidance. It is a shame to reconstruct or rather reinvent the past in situ instead of next to it.
It's a must when you visit Crete. It's the perfect place to know the history of the island. It's not cheap, 15€ the entrance + 10€ the guided tour, but its worth the visit.

On a busy day it feels a bit rushed with the amount of people and guides. You'll be waiting a while in the queue if you're on your own. Unfortunately areas that used to be visitable have been closed off so not as much to see as there used to be.

Nice place to visit just before midday or later in the afternoon when it's not as hot, tourist usually come around midday, free parking just before the entrance, you can buy tickets online and download them on the phone before you get …
Gregory was a fantastic guide. Do not go in without a guide!!!! €10 per adult on top of entrance fee of €15 per adult.  All children free for the guide and entrance fee.  Money well spent.
Very interesting, worth a visit.

Beautiful, historically very important site with lots of history to offer. It gets very hot so bring a hat, sunscreen and even an umbrella. There can be many queues to enter and see small rooms which may or may not be worth the wait due to …
What a beautiful place. Been there late April and absolutely loved it. Would definitely recommend even if you are not massively into History.

text.quote: Prominent Orthodox place of worship built in the 19th century, featuring ornate religious art.
trip: I never expected a church with such an impressive interior in Heraklion, but here you are. Only a 5-10 minute walk from the lions place (just up the bazaar street and turn right into the fish street and continue for 300 m) this is really impressive inside. A lot of details to

Friday 28th August we were sightseeing and exploring Heraklion. It took a bit of figuring out what was going on here  but finally figured it out that there were 2 churches here. Firstly there was a small Church falling into disrepair and was fenced off so it was not possible

A must visit with a beautiful exterior and interior. The interior has some really amazing frescoes and stained glass windows. The chandeliers in the interior are just magnificient. There is also a very historical clock which to me was very unique.
Stopped in Heraklion on our recent Cruise. A visit to the Cathedral of St. Minas will not dissapoint. Stunning Interior and a dramatic Exterior. Not to be missed.

We found this cathedral only by chance as we were heading back to our car, near the waterfront. It wasn't mentioned in our tourist leaflet. The outside is very solid and robust and inside it is very beautiful. It has the most lovely painted ceilings and wonderful use of light

It was built over the time period of 1862-1895. The construction was interrupted during the Cretan Revolution of 1866–1869. The church has a cruciform architecture with a central dome. The floor plan of the church has external maximum dimensions 43,20 m length and 29.50 width. A
Great frescoes. Not mentioned in our guide book but well worth a visit. Just off the central shopping area.
This amazing Cathedral was so beautifully decorated but still with a peaceful atmosphere, even with all the tourists

This church did not get a mention in the top 10 of Heraklion, but we wandered there for a look. We approached it from the side and thought it was shut as there were metal fences around (early October 2019). It was definitely open. Stain glass windows (modern) and inside it is

The Church of Ayios Minas, which is the largest church in Crete. An outstanding building taking up most the square. The interior is striking with beautiful decorated and detailed wall and dome frescoes. Amazing chandelier and stained glass. Do not miss.
I almost missed it, but luckily found it. Very nice inside but also outside. Worth to go for a visit.
Such a magnificent church, it’s a must see, it has beauty, grace, power and an imposing feel, the architecture and design are incredible

It is dedicated to the patron saint of Heraklion City, St. Minas and is the largest church in Crete. This stunning Cathedral is located in old town, in the heart of Heraklion. It is very grand on the outside with a spacious piazza in front. It is impressive to look at from the
When we visited this it was a baking hot day so we went inside just to cool off. Inside it is beautiful and not just cool!
There are no words to describe this amazing church! The iconography is so beautiful. Saint Minas is patron saint for the city of Heraklion.
Very grand on the outside but also looks amazing and detailed on the inside. Worth going inside to see it.
Located in old town on the pedestrian thoroughfare sites this beautiful church , go inside as the internal walls are beautifully painted.

Had to go to the Cathedral, although had to ask for directions, as not signed, and one map was all in Greek, the locals just call them all churches, so we went to a City centre Greek Orthodox church, which was the wrong one, but more interesting than the cathedral.

If you travel 18 km south out of Heraklion to the village of Agios Mironas then you will see even better things. The small forecourt is cool and inviting with plenty of shade and lots of flowers in pots. There is a well spring to which people come to fill up bottles and

A stunning cathedral with amazing interior in the heart of Heraklion. We attended the Megali Friday services there prior the Greek Orthodox Easter and there were thousands of people in the procession. Definitely a place not to miss at Heraklion
This church simply is amazing to look at from both the outside and the inside as well. It did greatly impress me with its art and crafting.
Worth a quick visit. Located in the centre. Next to it is the Christian museum St Aikaterini. Negative is that outside are Roma, not Greek Gypsy beggars that have proffesion to ask for charity...

The Agios Minas Cathedral is a striking Orthodox temple and the seat of the Archbishop of Crete. It is dedicated to the patron saint of Heraklion City, St. Minas. It is the largest church on the island. It is impressive to look at from the square and its interiors are equally
If you are walking by stop in for a look. Peaceful surroundings with beautiful frescos. Warm atmosphere.

Had a quick look at the Cathedral during a brief walk around Heraklion. It's a fair size and has a nice piazza in front which makes the building loom more impressive. Internally very nice with painted ceilings and icons/statues and other Greek Orthodox parafanalia.

When you are a tourist in Greece you must go at least to one church as the Greeks are very faithful in their religion. Saint Minas church is a good place to pray or to admire if you are a tourist. It's location makes it even more convenient for a visit

Agios Minas is a lovely building. Beautifully decorated inside. Unfortunately the alter is hidden as is the Greek Orthodox tradition. Unfortunately the much smaller original church of Agios Minas next to the cathedral was shut when I visited. My Tip: There is a toilet

I came across the cathedral by accident having got lost. Outside was one of its bells. The cathedral is impressive both outside and inside. The highlight was the view up to the dome with it's paintings.
It is well worth a visit. The main area to really appreicate is the roof above your head which is excellent

This is one of the largest Cathedrals in Greece and the biggest on Crete. The building has an impressive facade and once inside it is typically ornate although some of the ceiling artwork is relatively modern. Just in front of the Cathedral there's another tiny church - this is

Pretty piece of architecture worth your visit. It also offers some fine male singing in the early hours of weekend - we lived around and song of Greek people woke us up sometimes to catch the beautiful day.

The cathedral is small and very ornate. The ceilings are particularly interesting. It is however a 19th century) building. More interesting –just off the square in front of it - is the tiny Church of St Minas, the predecessor to the cathedral which is older (early 18th I

this is a very beautifull church with a lot of beautiufll paintings inside as its common for orthodox church,it also has a ver interesting history with a few nice legends about the saint during the urkish ocupation and the battle of crete in 1941 :)

We made a trip specifically to the cathedral of St Minas or “Agios Minas” to see the beautiful ceiling paintings. This church is breathtaking. Despite being fairly small, every corner of it is adorned with beauty. An active place of worship as well, worth a visit if in

One of the many gorgeous Byzantine churches in Heraklion, St. Minas Cathedral dominates the square, and energizes the area during feast days. It has a very interesting theological bookstore next door, which has some gems for book collectors, some jewelry, and some souvenirs.

The cathedral is ornate and gorgeous, among the most beautiful churches in all of Greece. Fantastic examples of several branches of arts: frescoes, architecture, large-size stained glass, woodwork, ironwork, etc.
This is a beautiful cathedral in this lovely old town/city in Crete. It is elegant with good architectural features and sets the town off really well. It is worth checking out.

This cathedral was dedicated to the Patron Saint of Heraklion and is one of Greece's largest churches. It also contains a wonderful collection of religious icon paintings in addition to having an extremely beautiful interior.

A place of quiet reflection in a big bustling city. It has the most stunning murals covering the ceilings which must be seen to fully appreciate. Sit and take in the beauty of his building and have a quiet moment before re-entering the modern world.

We stopped by to observe the children and masses of people at the service on a Sunday evening. The area outside the cathedral was lively and inside was packed. Obviously a place of worship for the local citizens.

Words simply cannot describe the splendor. After seeing churches in Greece over 14 years of travel we were not prepared for this! One of the most beautiful ever! Arguably THE loveliest we have had the pleasure to see. Do not miss.
Spend some quiet minutes admiring the icons and magnificent chandeliers. You may read the origins and history of the Cathedral.

The seat of the Archbishop of Crete, the Greek Orthodox Cathedral is dedicated to Saint Menas, the martyr and the patron saint of Heraklion. It was built in the 19th century as the largest cathedral on Crete, a stunning structure with even more fascinating interior.
Outside the cathedral there are a few caffe where you can sit and relax enjoing the view! Plenty of space for children to play around

Not the largest or more imposing cathedral in the world but the interior is superb with stunning ornamentation - huge chandeliers. painted ceilings, large stained glass window. Definitely worth a visit.

The first time we discovered St. Minas, we were a bit lost and looking for a cafe to sit and take a breather. Roaming the outer edge of the city center, we strolled down many a narrow alley, then there it was, one of the grandest churches we'd ever seen. Situated on a

This cathedral is gorgeous! The location is great! You can sit outside sip on some coffee and people watch! Kids usually are feeling birds outside on the steps... it really is beautiful and worth a stop!

I found this Christian Orthodox Cathedral to be the most attractive of all the Cathedrals and churches we saw in Heraklion, or on the whole of Crete actually. From the outside it is imposing, tucked away in old Heraklion close to some good restaurants. Inside it is beautifully
It is a huge cathedral church in the center of Heraklion. It worths a visit there. You usually find it open during day.
Small but Amazing. if you have 15 min, you need to look. Reconditioned, colourful, clean. Saint Minas is the most beautiful church in Heraklion.

Amazing to look at inside but it is more of a working cathedral than a tourist attraction. Plenty of people trying to get their prayers done whilst I was walking around in my flip flops. I can only apologise.

The Cathedral of Saint Minas is the most prominent Christian Orthodox church of Heraklion city. It is devoted to St. Minas, the Saint Protector of the city and is located within the center of old Heraklion. The temple was built between 1862 and 1895 A.D., although a smaller 17th

While you are in town go for a quick visit to it feel some peace and rest there for a short time learn and enjoy the place was for free so there is nothing to lose and do as we did add it to the list while you are in Heraklion

If you like ecclesiastical architecture this is a cathedral not to miss if you are in the area. It is based on the standard domed and arched Greek Orthodox Church, but is so much more grand. This is a truly stunning piece of architecture completed with gorgeous art inside. My
Lovely old building, interesting and worth a visit. Well cared for. There is a dress code as one would expect in buildings of this nature.
A very impressive building close to the centre of town and easy to see. Its history is just as interesting as the rest of Crete.

This cathedral is beautiful (from the outside). I haven't been inside but even just looking at it from the outside is worth it. Some cafes nearby to sit and look at the cathedral from (although I haven't tried them so can't comment on them!).
If you have extra time and want to get a good look at the Orthodox churches in the region, this is beautifully appointed and worth the time to have a moment's peace and light a small candle...

He may have been born, raised,died in Egypt, never visited this city in his lifetime but he did visit after his death(so that he would hunt the Turks who were planning to slaughter those praying inside the church)

I rather liked this Cathedral, which is quite small, and not old as the previous buildings have been destroyed by earthquakes. Has some striking, but probably not very exceptionally well painted murals.

This is a very interesting Cathedral, and if you are CoE and find Catholic churches different, this is definitely a notch above that! VERY decorated, extremely cluttered and full of beautiful surprises from relics to effigies. The painted ceiling and vault are a must see! There

Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, and no doubt there is always someone who has seen bigger and better. This is a place of special interest to me, as two of my friends were married here. It is small for a cathedral, but there are some lovely frescos and icon examples. The
I have visited this place few times and I want to visit it again. Very beautiful inside and outside and not far from the centre of the city.
Thanks to our guide we look at this temple. Very well maintained with many beautiful frescoes and icons.
Very nice cathedral in Heraklion; when you visit this church, don't forget to be dressed for a visit in a church ! no short and low cut, no shoulders free.
Nothing special, not worth the time to get there. Normal church with nothing special inside. Nothing to also around the church

The walls are absolutely covered in gorgeous icons from nearly top to bottom. There's also a nearby church bookstore filled with all kinds of books and other Orthodox goods if you want/need to purchase anything.
Worth a side trip, though there are more historic churches in Heraklion, partly for the surrounding area and partly for the cathederal itself. Massive exterior and impressive interior.
a real strange place amongst this very run down city, the lovely coloured glass is stunning in it's own simplicity

I'm not aficionado of churches but it's worth stopping in. The decorations are elaborate and intricate and even if you aren't religious worth seeing. It only takes a short stop and easy to find wandering around the centre of the town.

We loved seeing the paintings on the ceiling! WOW! We spent a good time looking at them! We all lit a candle and toured the church, the wrought iron was also magnificent. Outside the church is a WWII bomb that never exploded near the old church. Some say it is a miracle.
beautiful church Clean and respectful A holy place and very calming Visit and light a candle and do some reflective prayer
Not as big as other cathedrals I visited, but still very very impressive. Went there just before the last supper service & it was buzzing with worshippers & tourists alike.

Saint Mines is,by local saying, the saint of whole island of Crete.As living human he fought against ottomans,and there I s rumor that he was seen during the German occupation of the island in 1940s.For sure visit this cathedral,especially if you are religious.
At the center of Heraklion, you can visit the Cathedral of St. Minas for a peaceful pray. beautiful architecture from the inside to the outside.. A very charming place... Loved it very much.

It's a nice cathedral to view from the outside, both from the side shown in the cover photo and from the front (one quadrant to the right in the cover photo). More importantly, it is in excellent condition on the inside. The frescoes that cover the walls and ceiling seem to

wonderful young church, amazing painting on the roof! a bit beside the main path, close to market street with several bar/cafes along to have a drink (better as in the main road) pls respect the church, not enter with incorrect clothes
Free to come in, beautiful church with a nice square in front of it with pigeons which you can feed (bring smth with you)
This is stunning bit of architecture and breathtaking piece of design. Everything is ornate, inspiring and awesome, in the true sense of the word.
we didn't go in as service on but its certainly impressive from the outside has a Spanish feel to it just lovely nice photo stop as head into the centre of Heraklion
One of the biggest churches in town, with 2 other smaller churches by each side. Nice architecture and a big square in front full of pigeons! Right in the heart of the city.

The best and most known typical Greek church in the city! Very nice icons and paintings, a magical ceiling to gaze at, if you want to really pay attention to the details then you need to spend at least a hour inside. Around it is a big square with small shops to drink and eat

If you like typical Greek churches with their ikons, colourful painting and almost byzantine structure, then this is for you. In the heat of the day, it was a most welcome relief to step into this wonderful cathedral, although you may get a stiff neck from staring at the
Beautiful church. A must while visiting HEraklion, with lots of icons inside. Many stained glass windows.

We always visit Heraklion when we come to Crete and after walking around the historic sites and completing our shopping, we always retire to Ekaterina Square for half an hour's peace and quiet. The magnificent cathedral sits in an elevated position between two other churches,
The cathedral does not look particularly interesting from outside, but inside is another matter completely. It is elaborately decorated, and the stained glass is quite atmospheric.
Well worth a look, beautiful high painted ceilings and chandeliers. Solitude from the hustle and bustle outside

Impressive from the outside with its dome and towers and even more so inside, with the entire ceiling area covered in vibrantly coloured frescoes. Even though relatively modern - 19th Century - it is definitely well worth the visit.
The name Cathedral is a bit misleading when compared to other European style Cathedral seeing as this one is quite small in comparison. Still, it is peaceful with few visitors and quite beautiful.
Very worth while visiting this location. It is one of the sights that you must visit to appreciate the history of Crete

In my visit in city heraklion was obligation to see major church of minas, patron of Island. Very modern church as I read, from end of 19th century was build in beautiful byzantine style. Very nice interior with lot of iconics make you feel divine touch
If you're into visiting cathedrals, then this is the one to see while in Heraklio..church completed in 1895 and is also the seat of the Archbishop of Crete.

Great church we visited on our way to the historical museum of Crete . Free entry! When you entered it has a fantastic atmosphere. So different to Catholic Churches I saw in the past. Amazing place . Recommended

This is a beautiful church and well worth a visit to view the icons/frescoes and general beauty why I rated it very good HOWEVER -don't light a candle, we observed them being removed in handfuls after being lit and then thrown disdainfully into a box. i always light a candle for
Right in the middle of Herklion. Nice church with a big history. Dress conservatively. Great to drink a coffe at the plate nearby

This is a nice big church located just in the west side of the city. A lot of local people were visiting the church. The building is really impressive, esspecially for the location in the heart of the city.
Your usual Orthodox Cathedral, still a very impressive building in the center of Heraklion in the pedestrian area, worth to enter and visit.

The Agios Minas Cathedral architecture is fascinating; it’s not like most Byzantine Churches but has a unique modern look, the shining red Domes are very impressive; the two Clock Towers add to the beauty of this religious structure; the Cathedral stands out wherever you go on
It's a must visit while in Heraklion! It's a beautiful church which actually. An be spotted from a distance. The paintings inside are beautiful. And the chandeliers are majestic!
you can see the differences in the orthodox christian church. especially this church, which is the cathedral church of the city

Lovely church, brilliantly decorated, peaceful and cool. Please remember that even though they welcome visitors, it is nevertheless an active place of worship, please make sure you are dressed appropriately (ladies, that means no bare shoulders!), turn off the flash and sound

Aghios Minas is worth visiting for its history, architecture and the religious wall paintings. Its Crete's biggest church Cathedral of Heraklion city. If you are lucky enough to be there during litougy (Sunday morning) or wedding or baptism evenings (Friday to Sunday) it will be

It was very interesting to experience how the Orthodaox Easter is celebrated. On Good Friday there must have been thousands of people of all ages visit the cathedral. At about 10pm there was a procession round the nearby streets to the Lions Square where the procession halted.
the inside is as nice as the outside and is only matched in its granduer by st stephens ballisica in budapest. even the children were in awe of the paintings around

A majestic church that is best to visit on Sunday early morning in order to witness the divine liturgy with the outstanding chanting of Ioannis Damarlakis. The portraits of the saints on the temple, the walls and the ceiling are worth the visit. The church is the cathedral of

A great landmark in Heraklion, St Minas is the protector of the town. Lots of stories about it, including the unexploded WWII bomb near the building - taken as an example of the effectiveness of the saint's protection! Definitely worth seeing if you are in town.

The church of the "City Protector", St, Minas was protecting the christians from the Turks during the occupation of the island. The old, small church was the first one and is mentioned in Nikos Kazantzakis books, also with some of the legends of protector St.MInas. Next to the

This orthodox cathedral has one of the most beautiful ceilings I've ever seen. As for me, it looks more beautiful, than st. Titus cathedral. Also If you'll have a minute to visit this Cathedral, take a closer look at the chandeliers, which are just awesome!

The best part of this Cathderal are the wonderful paintings on the ceilings. I'm under the impression that this is not a particularly old church which may be why the frescoes are still so rich in colour and intensity.

Step inside this piece of religious history and take a look at this religious iconic church which is a unique sight that could easily missed if not found in busy Heraklion of people rushing everywhere and intense heat of the day
The painting on the ceilings etc., very beautiful. Also very typical of Greek churches. The square outside it has some nice cafés to wile away an hour.
Herakleion is a small city, and this is one of the smallest cathedrals I have seen. It's not worth going out of your way to see.
the walls and ceiling are painted with beautiful scenes from the bible. Gold chandliers hung from the ceiling. IT is free to visit, and only a ten minute walk from the main square.

I was surprised by the scale of this beautiful building, not that it is large for a cathedral but it is very large compared to small traditional orthodox churches. The exterior is simple but the interior is elaborate with icons and detailed motif and massive chandeliers with

I reached the cathedral walking some good 10min away from the madness of Morosini fountain square with all it's tourists to be welcome by some good Cretan calm and closed shops unlike the shops with booming music located near Morosini fountain. Due to the late afternoon,

While Agios Minas (Cathedral of St. Minas) is not a very old cathedral (built 1862-1895), it is a very fine example of the style in which churches and cathedrals are built and decorated in Greece.With a capacity of 8,000 people it is also one of the largest cathedrals in Greece.

A jewel set in a strange place. I found the city itself a strange place in general with pockets of beauty that were easily stumbled upon. This being one of them. The city itself is steeped in history, but is lost in piles of grafiti and often uneasy atmosphere. Bit be patient
Impressive and attractive architecture in a pretty, quiet square. Didn't go in as there was a service on.
In some ways it is a very typical Orthodox style church however the Byzantine style art near the altar is gorgeous. I enjoyed my visit even though it was for a short time.
This cathedral is gorgeous inside and out, so be sure to pop in toappreciate the byzantine style art that covers the walls and decorates the domes.
We could not manage to be on time to go inside the Church. However, it was beautiful from outside, late in the evening. The structure is in the heartof Heraklion town, in the Central area.
Traditional ortodox Church atmosphere, dark, not hot... whispering and paaying old ladies in black... sweet feelings

Beautiful cathedral situated in a lovely square away from the crowds and noise of Heraklion - recommend a visit near sunset when huge flock of sparrows come in to roost in the trees - there are a couple of tavernas to sit and relax.

The cathedral is just massive. It's an amazing structure, makes everything around it look so small. Looking inside, its windows are decorated with colored glass and its walls & ceiling are all covered with paintings. It is worth a visit, both, during daytime and nighttime. Even

Visit of St. Minas cathedral was the top of my visit in Heraklion. Walking thru crowded main street, being annoyed by strange sellers of strange stuff, was quite tiring for me. Therefore I really enjoyed calm moments in the cathedral, observing the roof paints and lighting the

My brother and I passed by the cathedral by car when we were looking for a parking spot in the centre, then we searched for it on maps just to see it again. I've been twice to Greece and have seen a lot of amazing cathedrals, but this one is definitely the most beautiful one I
A lovely place. Must visit again. So much beauty and history in the city center. The old church in the back is very nice as well.

We always make for Ekaterina Square whenever we visit Iraklion; it's a peaceful enclave in a bustling city and you would never believe you were just a hundred yards or so from the noise and traffic. The square has a few restaurants and some benches beneath jacaranda trees from
Magnificent cathedral, very large, wonderful decorations and paintings. One of most beautiful cathedrals i seen.
what a celebration and the church is well worth a visit for a look around. there are lots of smaller churches in the town and its well worth doing a visit of them all
Nothing to deal with art but if you have the opportunity to see an Orthodox priest in black you will be able to understand why Greek churches are almost the only renewed buildings.
Seems it always calm at Cathedral of St. Minas. If you are walking for a long time at Hiraclion, than go to Cathedral to have a rest for your feet and sole.
This was our first visit of an orthodox church and it was very impressive for a catholic. Beautiful ornamentations.
not a big church fan but that one is very impressive outside and inside.specially the inside with all the icons and all the details on the walls and the decoration..

Easily reached by foot from anywhere in the old town area, but in a quiet part of town not much frequented by tourists, it seems. Very good example of a Greek Orthodox Basilica (as far as I can tell, as a non-expert). Hammered silver panels with the characteristic cut-outs
In an interesting part of town. Many lovely murals but not a lot of atmosphere. Shame about the graffiti near the church.
This is a beautiful church which is well worth a view if you are in the area. It is not something I would go out of my way to see though.
no words describe how beautiful this church is!!!! simply amazing!!! would definitely recommend going here if you go to Crete!

I love this church.. We had the local taxi drivers take us to their favorite historical site.. It was this church. It was beautiful inside and it is right near the market. The back of the church near the rectory was actually hit by a bomb during the fighting in WW ll. I have

Amazing experience. A little hard to find without a map. Church is by market. Beautiful paintings on all of the ceilings and walls. Really breathtaking. Bring cover for shoulders and legs to be respectful.

This, over one hundred years old , impressive cathedral is a classical example of the byzantine architectural style. It Is one of the biggest churches in the Balcans. Excellent inside decoration with byzantine style frescoes
Take the time to visit this cathedral. The frescoes are quite modern and very beautiful.

Awesome church that almost got bombed during the war? I'm not sure this is the name of the church actually, but if this review does interest you, then please try to locate the church I am referring to. It's just on the outskirts of the main shopping market in Crete. There are

text.wiki:
Heraklion or Iraklion ( hih-RAK-lee-ən; Greek: Ηράκλειο, Irákleio, pronounced [iˈraklio]) is the largest city and the administrative capital of the island of Crete and capital of Heraklion regional unit. It is the fourth largest city in Greece with a population of 211,370 (Urban Area) according to the 2011 census. The population of the municipality was 173,993.The Bronze Age palace of Knossos, also known as the Palace of Minos, is located nearby.
Heraklion was Europe's fastest growing tourism destination for 2017, according to Euromonitor, with an 11.2% growth in international arrivals. According to the ranking, Heraklion was ranked as the 20th most visited region in Europe, as the 66th area on the Planet and as the 2nd in Greece for the year 2017, with 3.2 million visitors and the 19th in Europe for 2018, with 3.4 million visitors.


== Names ==
The Arab traders from al-Andalus (Iberia) who founded the Emirate of Crete moved the island's capital from Gortyna to a new castle they called rabḍ al-ḫandaq (Arabic: ربض الخندق‎, "Castle of the Moat") in the 820s. This was hellenized as Χάνδαξ (Chándax) or Χάνδακας (Chándakas) and Latinized as Candia, which was taken into other European languages: in Italian and Latin as Candia, in French as Candie, in English as Candy, all of which could refer to the island of Crete as a whole as well as to the city alone; the Ottoman name was Kandiye.
After the Byzantine reconquest of Crete, the city was locally known as Megalo Kastro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο, 'Big Castle' in Greek) and its inhabitants were called Kastrinoi (Καστρινοί, "castle-dwellers").
The ancient name Ηράκλειον was revived in the 19th century and comes from the nearby Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles's city"), whose exact location is unknown. English usage formerly preferred the classicizing transliterations "Heraklion" or "Heraclion", but the form "Iraklion" is becoming more common.


== History ==


=== Minoan Era ===
Heraklion is close to the ruins of the palace of Knossos, which in Minoan times was the largest centre of population on Crete. Knossos had a port at the site of Heraklion (at Poros - Katsambas neighborhood) from the beginning of Early Minoan period (3500 to 2100 BC). Between 1600 and 1525 BC, the port was destroyed by a volcanic tsunami from nearby Santorini, leveling the region and covering it with ash.


=== Antiquity ===

After the fall of the Minoans, Heraklion, as well as the rest of Crete in general, fared poorly, with very little development in the area. Only with the arrival of the Romans did some construction in the area begin, yet especially early into Byzantine times the area was abound with pirates and bandits.


=== Emirate of Crete ===
The present city of Heraklion was founded in 824 by the Arabs under Abu Hafs Umar who had been expelled from Al-Andalus by Emir Al-Hakam I and had taken over the island from the Eastern Roman Empire. They built a moat around the city for protection, and named the city rabḍ al-ḫandaq (ربض الخندق, "Castle of the Moat", hellenized as Χάνδαξ, Chandax). It became the capital of the Emirate of Crete (ca. 827–961). The Saracens allowed the port to be used as a safe haven for pirates who operated against Imperial (Byzantine) shipping and raided Imperial territory around the Aegean.


=== Byzantine era ===

In 960, Byzantine forces under the command of Nikephoros Phokas, later to become Emperor, landed in Crete and attacked the city. After a prolonged siege, the city fell in March 961. The Saracen inhabitants were slaughtered, the city looted and burned to the ground. Soon rebuilt, the town remained under Byzantine control for the next 243 years.


=== Venetian era ===
 
In 1204, the city was bought by the Republic of Venice as part of a complicated political deal which involved, among other things, the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade restoring the deposed Eastern Roman Emperor Isaac II Angelus to his throne. The Venetians improved on the ditch of the city by building enormous fortifications, most of which are still in place, including a giant wall, in places up to 40 m thick, with 7 bastions, and a fortress in the harbour. Chandax was renamed Candia and became the seat of the Duke of Candia, and the Venetian administrative district of Crete became known as "Regno di Candia" (Kingdom of Candia). The city retained the name of Candia for centuries and the same name was often used to refer to the whole island of Crete as well. To secure their rule, Venetians began in 1212 to settle families from Venice on Crete. The coexistence of two different cultures and the stimulus of Italian Renaissance led to a flourishing of letters and the arts in Candia and Crete in general, that is today known as the Cretan Renaissance.


=== Ottoman era ===

During the Cretan War (1645–1669), the Ottomans besieged the city for 21 years, from 1648 to 1669, perhaps the longest siege in history. In its final phase, which lasted for 22 months, 70,000 Turks, 38,000 Cretans and slaves and 29,088 of the city's Christian defenders perished. The Ottoman army under an Albanian grand vizier, Köprülü Fazıl Ahmed Pasha conquered the city in 1669. 
Under the Ottomans, Kandiye (Ottoman Turkish قنديه) was the capital of Crete (Girit Eyâleti) until 1849, when Chania (Hanya) became the capital, and Kandiye became a sancak. In Greek, it was commonly called Megalo Castro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο 'Big Castle').
During the Ottoman period, the harbour silted up, so most shipping shifted to Chania in the west of the island.


=== Modern era ===
In 1898, the autonomous Cretan State was created, under Ottoman suzerainty, with Prince George of Greece as its High Commissioner and under international supervision. During the period of direct occupation of the island by the Great Powers (1898–1908), Candia was part of the British zone. At this time, the city was renamed "Heraklion", after the Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles' city"), whose exact location is unknown.
In 1913, with the rest of Crete, Heraklion was incorporated into the Kingdom of Greece. Heraklion became again capital of Crete in 1971, replacing Chania.


== Architecture, urban sculpture and fortifications ==

Venetian constructions such as the Koules Fortress (Castello a Mare), the ramparts and the arsenal dominate the port area.
Several sculptures, statues and busts commemorating significant events and figures of the city's and island's history, like El Greco, Vitsentzos Kornaros, Nikos Kazantzakis and Eleftherios Venizelos can be found around the city.
Many fountains of the Venetian era are preserved, such as the Bembo fountain, the Priuli fountain, Palmeti fountain, Sagredo fountain and Morosini fountain (in Lions Square).
Around the historic city center of Heraklion there are also a series of defensive walls, bastions and other fortifications which were built earlier in the Middle Ages, but were completely rebuilt by the Republic of Venice. The fortifications managed to withstand the longest siege in history for 21 years, before the city fell to the Ottomans in 1669.


== Municipality ==

The municipality Heraklion was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 5 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Gorgolainis
Heraklion
Nea Alikarnassos
Paliani
TemenosThe municipality has an area of 244.613 km2, the municipal unit 109.026 km2.


== Neighborhoods ==


== Suburbs ==


== Transportation ==


=== Port ===
Heraklion is an important shipping port and ferry dock. Travellers can take ferries and boats from Heraklion to destinations including Santorini, Ios Island, Paros, Mykonos, and Rhodes. There are direct ferries to Naxos, Karpathos, Kasos, Sitia, Anafi, Chalki and Diafani. There are also several daily ferries to Piraeus, the port of Athens in mainland Greece. The port of Heraklion was built by Sir Robert McAlpine and completed in 1928.


=== Airport ===
Heraklion International Airport, or Nikos Kazantzakis Airport is located about 5 kilometres (3 miles) east of the city. The airport is named after Heraklion native Nikos Kazantzakis, a writer and a philosopher. It is the second busiest airport of Greece after Athens International Airport, first in charter flights and the 65th busiest in Europe, because of Crete being a major holiday destination with 7.974.887 travellers in 2018 (List of the busiest airports in Europe).
In April 2018, the inner space of the airport has been modernized and expanded by almost 3.000 s.m., with 11 new gates and new stores. The expansion was a donation by Hellenic Duty Free Shops.
The airfield is shared with the 126th Combat Group of the Hellenic Air Force.
A project for the new airport of Heraklion in Kasteli area is starting at the end of 2017.


=== Highway network ===
European route E75 runs through the city and connects Heraklion with the three other major cities of Crete: Agios Nikolaos, Chania, and Rethymno.


=== Public transit ===

Urban buses serving the city, with 39 different routes. Intercity buses connects Heraklion to many major destinations in Crete.


=== Railway ===
From 1922 to 1937, there was a working industrial railway, which connected the Koules in Heraklion to Xiropotamos for the construction of the harbor.
A study from the year 2000 investigated the feasibility of two tram lines in Heraklion. The first line would link the Stadium to the airport, and the second the center of Heraklion and Knossos.  No approval has yet been given for this proposal.
In the summer of 2007, at the Congress of Cretan emigrants, held in Heraklion, two qualified engineers, George Nathenas (from Gonies, Malevizi Province) and Vassilis Economopoulos, recommended the development of a railway line in Crete, linking Chania, Rethymno and Heraklion, with a total journey time of 50 minutes (30 minutes between Heraklion and Rethymno, 20 minutes from Chania to Rethymno) and with provision for extensions to Kissamos, Kastelli Pediados (for the planned new airport), and Agios Nikolaos. No plans exist for implementing this idea.


== Climate ==
Heraklion has a hot-summer-Mediterranean climate (Csa in the Köppen climate classification). Summers are warm to hot and dry with clear skies. Dry hot days are often relieved by seasonal breezes. Winters are very mild with moderate rain. Because Heraklion is further south than Athens, it has a warmer climate during winter but cooler during summer because of the Aegean sea. The maximum temperature during the summer period is usually not more than 28 - 30 °C (Athens normal maximum temperature is about 6 °C higher). The minimum temperature record is -0.2 °C
A new temperature record for February was set at 27.8 °C, reached on 15 February 2016.


== Colleges, universities, libraries, and research centers ==
University of Crete
Hellenic Mediterranean University (HMU)  (Former TEI)
 MBS College
Foundation for Research & Technology - Hellas
Nicolas Kitsikis Library
Vikelaia Library https://web.archive.org/web/20140605051225/http://www.heraklion.gr/en/municipality/vikelaia


== Culture ==


=== Museums ===

Historical Museum of Crete
Natural History Museum
The Battle of Crete and National Resistance Museum
Nikos Kazantzakis Museum
Lychnostatis Open Air Museum
Collection of Agia Aikaterini of Sinai
Museum of Visual Arts


=== Arts ===
The Cultural and Conference Center of Heraklion is a centre for the performing arts.


=== Sports ===
The city is home to several sports clubs. Most notably, Heraklion hosts OFI and Ergotelis, two football clubs with earlier presence in the Greek Superleague, the top tier of the Greek football league system. Furthermore, the city is the headquarters of the Heraklion Football Clubs Association, which administers football in the entire region. Other notable sport clubs include Iraklio B.C. (basketball), Atsalenios (football) and Irodotos (football) in the suburbs of Atsalenio and Nea Alikarnassos respectively.


=== Famous natives ===

Heraklion has been the home town of some of Greece's most significant people, including the novelist Nikos Kazantzakis (best known for Zorba the Greek), the poet and Nobel Prize winner Odysseas Elytis and the world-famous painter Domenicos Theotokopoulos (El Greco).
