text.quote: Bustling, taverna-lined square centered on a 1600s Venetian fountain with 4 water-gushing lions.
trip: This famous Venetian Fountain of the Lions is located in one of the busiest areas of Heraklion The fountain was constructed to bring unlimited drinking water the City. It was opened on 25 April 1628, which is the feast of Saint Mark, patron saint of Venice. The main feature
Its so beautiful!but so crowded .you can enjoy coffee soft drinks or meal nearby.its crowded every time of the Day
The iconic monument of the city centre. In function, a little card explains the meaning and origin of the fountain. Many Many restaurants, bars, shops all around
Impressive fountain with an interesting history. Close to other sights so do take a look. Plenty of eating places around
Well a nice fountain in a square with many coffee and bar places around... Not much more to say. The fountain is on behalf of the defender of the city against the ottomans..

We had a free hour in Heraklion, and I spent nearly half my precious time at this fountain, photographing it from every possible angle, walking around it, etc... It is located in the middle of a small square, which is probably the geographic centre of the city. Great for photo

This is one of the most beautiful fountain found in the centre of the old city of Iraklio. There is a history to this fountain - which makes it a must see. Good to view it during both day and night time where it nicely lit. Close to the Town Hall.

We found the fountain by chance whilst walking through the city and almost walked right by it. We did manage to get a photograph without two many tourists around. Apparently was built in 1628 by the Venetians to bring fresh spring water to the city via an aqueduct.

The Lion's Fountain is a Venetian fountain full of history with four lions, water gushing from their mouths. It is a wonderful landmark of Heraklion old town, surrounded by restaurants and souvenir shops. It is a busy place for tourists and locals as well. They even has few

It dates back to the Venetian era and is more commonly known as Lions Square, or "τα Λιονταράκια", "The Lions". It features four lions supporting the main basin and is easily found in the pedestrian street in the center of the old town, near the Loggia (the Town Hall) and St.

This is situated in a popular central atmospheric locality in Heraklion, but we didn't consider the fountain itself to be one of the finest examples. Hence the reason we have given it an average rating, but the locality is great. There are ample cafes, bars, restaurants and
As other reviews, a nice setting and nice area to walk around and take in the atmosphere, cafe's, shops and people watching..
We saw this fountain many times as we wanrered around the Tourist area. Most places can be found from this fountain as it is quite a landmark.

Not sure about reviewing a fountain so this is more about the actual square it is located in. The fountain itself was constructed in the 1600s by the Venetians and is quite pleasant to look at and photograph. The square is an open space in the centre of town flanked by some
The Lion’s fountain was, to us, the hub of Heraklion. People spend time sitting in the restaurants that surround it, and there is always a ‘buzz’
This is the most central spot in the old town of Heraklion. The fountain is surrounded by stores and restaurants (mainly ice cream and yogurt bars). It’s a great place to spend some time chilling.
In the central shopping area so hard to miss. Nice fountain overlooked by restaurants, bakeries and bars for a bite to eat or drink,

This is a great place to sit and relax have a sweet desert and a drink. Watch the pigeons and people. I was happy to see the foundation was in operation as well Amazing to think how 400 years ago the people of the city got there water from this exact fountain
Good place to just hang out and use as a meeting point when walking around the shopping area. Everyone knows where it is so you can use it to regather if you separate from your traveling companions.

The lion s fountain is one of Heraklion s trademark. If u get lost unjust search for the lions. It’s the center of the city. Around it there are loads of bars n gyros places coffee shops. U can go downwards to the sea and find nice taverns with great view or go upwards and

I visited this fountain on a Saturday evening stroll . This square is surely a cross road for shoppers, both locals and tourists alike . After the shopping sit and rest a little and people watch at this square and fountain . It becomes extremely busy as the evening progresses

Nice fountain and situated right in the middle of the shopping bar quarters in old town Heriklion. Fun to walk by, take a pic and keep going. Don’t know the history behind it but definitely a show stopper! Worth a quick visit and take out frappe.

Surrounded by eating/drinking establishments on 25 Augustou Street. A relaxing area to rest whilst admiring the decorated fountain comprising eight cisterns and decorated with stone figures from Greek mythology, nymphs, tritons and monsters.
On a Friday evening we sat and watched the passing parade. Many people were dancing and a band was about to play.
Very nice fountain in thd old town, along with the othet Venetisn sites that were left. Can be crowded.
Great place to visit. Very busy in the weekends and right in the middle of shipping. Lots of place to eat around.
Since you will be already there walking the famous 25 August street, it is something that you can see and admire. However we could not find any information in regards to the monument.
Loved this pretty ancient square. There are lovely cafes all over with excellent salads and it’s a great spot to get out of the sun and people watch.
Very disappointing Dirty, unkept, no lighting at night What a shame to promote a venue and fail SO badly Not sure what else to say, you will pass it as you walk around

You have to visit that place ! Is the Centre of the Down Town ! Also you have to visit the Kirkor Bougatsa (typical Crete sweat ) exactly opposite from Morosinis Fountain ! One of the most popular places in Crete !

This is a well known fountain and a good landmark and meeting place. The beautiful Venetian fountain, built in 1628 to bring drinking water to Heraklion from Mt. Juktas 15Km away. The fountain is decorated with scenes from Greek mythology, mainly Tritons, dolphins and nymphs.
Nice fountain and that’s about it. But for some reason this fountain is the it place when it comes to taking your holiday photos. Bonus; Great ice cream shops next to it

Love this thing! It’s got lions firing water out of their mouths, it’s old and it’s still going and I think it’s pretty charming. I’d recommend sitting in one of the restaurants facing it and have a bougatsa and a drink and just stare at it. Stare at it and keep staring. watch
...the area around the fountain is full of busy busy restaurants serving lunch, dinner and desserts. If you roam around, you will find some fast food eateries such as souvlaki and gyros.
We randomly stayed one night near the port, and decided to walk around the lion fountain area. Tons of cool shops and restaurants! There was even some live street performance music which was fun.
Nice fountain in the middle of town. Small plaques to show age and provenance. Not surrounded by tourist restaurants. Worth a look as you pass by

This is where people should begin their discovery of Heraklion because it's right in the centre and surrounded by some great restaurants and coffee shops that let you sit and watch the people going by. From here you can visit the Central Market on 1866 Street which I just loved
This is a beautiful old fountain and a great place to orient yourself while exploring the city. The restaurants surrounding the fountain are all pretty good, especially the bougatsa (cheese pastry).

Old, run down, and pretty dirty. Not much water flowing through the fountain, and at night it is literally crawling with cockroaches. However, it occupies the central spot of one of the busiest pedestrian areas of downtown Heraklion, and it remains an icon of the city that you

The Lions Square is an interesting spot for two reasons. Firstly its historical importance as an Arab slave market, residence of the Byzantine governor, Palace of the Venetian Duke, residence of the Ottoman Vizier and finally memorial square for Eleftheriou Venizelou, the great

This fountain is a historical landmark, but is also the center of a very busy square. We wandered around the evening we were here and had the best Gelato nearby! There are many restaurants too, and even a Starbucks if that's your thing. You could spend an hour or more just
Nice place to take a picture and thats all. Nothing interesting to coment of this Venetian fountain.

Located in old town on the main pedestrian thoroughfare is this beautiful fountain. Also around the fountain you will see a few panels of glass on the ground giving you a small view into the past & what is under the paving.
The fountain is located on the pedestrian street leading to the port and is s very popular place to take pictures.

A real sense of Italy and Renessaince art in Crete. The fountain is really wonderful, you can admire the sculpture complex of lions and floral decoration, while the redeveloped place is a great spot for hanging around.

We passed this fountain frequently and it is a good landmark for knowing where you are in the pedestrian section of Heraklion. I would not go find the fountain as a destination, but if you are there, you are in the midst of the bustling old city with shopping and outdoor cafes

Morosini Fountain is one of the most well known landmarks in Heraklion. It is extremely well preserved for its age and is worth a visit and a photograph. It is surrounded by lovely cafes and a favourite of ours was Fyllo...Sofies with its friendly, helpful staff and delicious
This is a well known fountain and a good landmark and meeting place. Its a great place for a photo op. My husband and I had drinks close to the fountain and it was lovely !
This was a beautiful fountain in the heart of the pedestrian area which provided a good landmark in the search for restaurants! There are many streets that seem to converge here.
This is in the center of so many incredible places to eat and shop! We found so many amazing things just walking around!

Beautiful historic fountain that’s really worth a visit surrounded by some really nice places to eat and admire the historical surroundings. If you face the fountain with Dedalou behind you the path to the right will take you down to the harbour, the path left takes you further

Built in 1629 by General Proveditor Morosini, this fountain with 4 lions sending jets of water into 8 sculpted basins bearing mythological reliefs sits in a shaded square within the pedestrian area of the old town. The vibrant atmosphere of the area is due to many cafes, shops

It's a fountain! People congregate here to have photos taken. Why? And there are children accordion players (often chased by police on bikes) and adults selling weird playdoh/squishy fruits. I don't think it is a must see.
Nice venezian treasure in our town.our story.beautiful and wonderful.i see it every day 2 and 3 times

Good , well preserved fountain. Has a history behind this. A small replica of Lions Fountain was also built in Chania which was the earlier capital of Crete. Walking distance from Heraklion city centre.
This is a good central spot in the city to get your bearings. So much to see with market one way and harbour the other. Lots of shops and cafes.

Dating back to the early seventeenth century, the fountain stands on a circular basin. The central basin has several lobes carved with freizes from Greek mythology. In the center stand four proud lions symbolizing Venetian power with water spouting from their mouths. The lions
If you are in Heraklion don't miss to make a picture. Around this place you will find a lot of possibilities to have a nice coffee, try the frape, or have a lunch.
A great focus for social mingling of shoppers tourists family groups. Loads of coffee bars and ear to everything else, once you’ve found it!
This is just a beautiful fountain in the middle of a lovely area, bustling with tourists and places for lunch. It is a gorgeous fountain though!
The perfect spot for people watching and a cafe with friends or an ice cream in hand. A part of a very lively square in the heart of old town.

Its a nice place and good Meeting point however I found the fountan not very impressive to be around. A lot of tourists meet there as it divides the main road towards the harbor and market so this is a good place for orie tation

Lions square is the most known point in the capital city of Crete,the well know "Big Castle" ,Heraklion City ! It's known as Lion's fountain or Morosini fountain ,from its creator Francesco Morosini !
Pretty area, lots to do and see in the area. There were several people trying to sell flowers or balloons in this area that would run away when law enforcement showed up.
A lovely fountain the the middle of Heraklion, surrounded by cafes and restaurants. A pleasant place to take a break.

For us Morosini fountain was a great way to find Heraklion’s central point and walk around to discover and enjoy vibrant coffee shops, terraces and local cuisine. There are also many small shops similar I would say as a bazaar. I would recommend starting your stroll through the

We arrived at the same time as all the tours and could hardly see the fountain. We strolled down to the harbour on our return it was very peaceful. Lovely just to stand and watch and listen to the water.
Historical fountain of the city of Heraklion, in the heart of the city with several bars, restaurants and shops nearby!
Cute area to stop and get a snack or coffee. Good walking district. The fountain is also really nice.
This was a nice area to click off a few photos while my hubby went to get some Bougatsa nearby. It is a nice central area in town.
Lovely pace to watch the world go by which is what we did drinking coffee sitting opposite this lovely fountain on a sunny day.. Bliss

It’s in the middle of many cafes, ice cream shops and juice bars. So if you want to walk around, making this as your landmark / destination wouldn’t hurt. We took a nice picture. Not a big deal. You’ll spend less than 5 minutes here.
Standard fountain, in a nice cobbled setting in downtown Herkalion. Wouldnt go out of your way to visit, but if you are passing by while shopping or grabbing a bite to eat take a look.

You can't be in Heraklion City and miss top be there, because it is really in the heart of it... Surrounded by excellent options of having caffee or food but please do NOT miss the traditional Bougatsa with cream or with chese (sugar and cinnamon added is a must) at Kir-Kor...
It was lovely sitting near the Lions Fountain. Such a tranquil sort of setting amongst the throng of noisy tourists of which I was one. A place to sit and people watch, rest and re-energise.
This is the main feature in the urban landscape of Heraklion. Aroubd this fountain you will have the better restaurants and coffes.
Surrounded by cafes and restaurants in the heart of the city center. Great spot for a photo op and people watching.
Nice fountain in a central Hiraklion city. Venizelos square. Touristic ways. Open in 1628 for applied needs. There were fresh water for the citizens.
A pitty it took us ages to find due to the amout of souviner shops and restaurants around we nearly missed it! Nice fountain that needs some love.

The fountain is located in Lion's Square in the center of Heraklion where there are numerous cafes surrounding the square. It was designed to bring drinking water to the Heraklion citizens in the 17th century.

The citizens of Heraklion (and Crete) are exceptionally proud of Morosini's Fountain and rightfully so. It's an excellent example of Venetian stone carving and is centrally located in the old part of Heraklion. Surrounding the fountain is an area with small cafes (some more

Very attractive fountain in Heraklion town center with four water mouthpieces streaming into semi round bays so that users could approach without getting splashed yet put their hands out and wash. Built by the Venetian who purchased the town for a thousand pieces of silver they
This is the heart of this beautiful town with so many places to dine and roam around and plenty of people to watch and boutiques to visit. I loved this place.

If you're in Heraklion you'll probably stumble upon this fountain, surrounded by bars and bakeries, get yourself a phillo pastry with cheese and honey and enjoy the view (and probably the nice weather).

Located in the heart of Heraklion, you can't miss this fountain. There are tons of restaurants surrounding it that you can grab a seat at one of them and eat or drink something and people watch. It is a really pleasant area.

The Lion fountain is beautifully sited in the centre of the old town, at the end of 25th August street, only a few yards from the Loggia. The fountain is symmetrical and to a casual glance the four faces are identical.
This was a cute fountain in the city center. If you are strolling the streets shopping or searching for something good to eat, stop by for a photo op.

The fountain and the surrounding area combines history and modern.. A nice place to meet friends.. to have a meal or coffee at the evening.. or simply so sit around and do nothing.. just relax and watch the people walk by.. You can't visit heraklion without visiting this area..
This fountain is in the middle of a square with lots of places to eat around. It’s a nice area to visit.

Found this little gem when revisiting Heraklion recently in the middle part of the city and acts as a natural meeting up place with shops, market and cafes nearby. Very impressive history and architecture. Would recommend a viewing.
Nice little fountain that we came across during a leisurely wander around Heraklion city, and it does work and makes an interesting photo stop!
Old fountain in a square. Only takes a few minutes to see in the shopping district. Worth a quick stop.
easily found in the shopping street, lovely to look at & a great photo opportunity, worth a quick visit.
This is a lovely and very popular fountain in the centre of the old town close to the Town Hall. It is surrounded by cafes and restaurants and was incredibly busy with visitors and locals alike.
I loved this fountain. It is like city center with lots of restaurants and coffee shops. its lovely place to rest, have refreshments or take nice pictures.
A surprise structure you come across when exploring the streets full of shops, restaurants and cafes.

Definitely worth seeking out these lions....reviewers say easy to find.....we were obviously looking in the wrong place!! Take plenty of photos as they actually look more photogenic than they first appear.
and carvings on fountain. Water was transported from the hills for the locals. Clever technique as ever. Lions were apparently much older than the fountain.

Central to the square is the four lion fountain. The square is officially “Eleftheriou Venizelou Square” (after a Greek prime minister) but known as Lions Square / Fountain. It’s a small feature in the middle of a densely populated restaurant & café square. Directly opposite

Okay by now you have read the other reviews and wonder why you come here. Well it’s the Bougatsa ! Watch Anthony Bourdain ( yes he went to Chania, and they have a crunchy version) but none the less it’s awesome here. Get a seat facing the fountain order your Bougatsa , coffee
On our way to the archeological museum we passed this fountain! It is beutiful, however a fountain amongst others! But if you are near, do go and take a look!
This is a fountain with history which you can read about. It looks like it has been cleaned up and the great thing is it works with water coming out of the lions mouths.
This is just a general fountain in the town square which is easily found. You definitely do not need to go on a tour or anything to see it.

This is an attractive old Venetian era fountain in the centre of the town in Heraklion. I think the area is known as Lion's square. Surrounding the fountain are lots of restaurants and bars and this is a good place to have dinner looking out at the fountain and watching the
Took local bus to the centre ,walked all the way to the harbour ,passing this lovely fountain and other city monument ,plenty places to have a drink or snack, very busy !

Fountain is kind of nice but it is located in a busy square where you can try Greek cuisine. Do try banana ice-cream, but do not take more than one scoop (unless you are gifted by almighty with a large bottom to store all the calories).

A walk through the city center is a fun way to spend some time, enjoy drinks or a meal of any time. The fountain is an interesting monument but not exactly unique. You certainly would’nt go to this area only to see the fountain, but it is an nice addition to your walk.
Situated in city centre, admist cafe and small bars. Should tie in when visiting other areas of interest as stands alone
Have a look by all means, but nothing spectacular. It's handy to use as a reference point when negotiating the market and eateries.
This was a nice fountain in a square surrounded by deveral restaurants. We had dinner there one night and the fountains were lit up and very pretty.

The fountains were lovely to sit around and enjoy our packed lunch from the hotel Heraklion is a wonderful place full of the architecture wonderful fountains wonderful Methodist churches, and lovely places to sit and watch the world go by.
Attractive fountain in a busy square at the top of the Main Street and near the market. Great place to pause for food and drink
We visited this place at night and in the morning - lots of people eating out in the surrounding cafes, taking pictures. A nice place to come and enjoy life
Beautiful, historic fountain. The square around it is ideal for grabbing a cafe table and relaxing. Great vibe around the Lion’s Fountain. Lots of shopping and food around.
This is the meeting point for everyone in Herakleio and the most busy place in the town from where you can visit almost any restaurant bar and coffee.

Lovely historical fountain situated near the end of the markets. Wind your way up the street and then rest your feet at a little cafe , purchase an Ouzo with free nibbles( usually) and watch the world go by. Its fun to watch the birds bathing in the top tier of the fountain.
Nothing wrong with the town but coming from Rhodes, this town lacks the wow factor. My tip is to tour the walls and get out of the tourist area.
Heart of the city, this old fountain lays in the city centre. Very well saved, it's a wonderul spot for relax and pictures!
Other than a meeting point across the Loggia and the library, not worth visiting. Stroll down the street to get to the old port & fort (not much left).

Everyone who has visited Heraklion seems to know Lions Square, making it an extremely popular meeting point. The Morosini Fountain is set at its center, beautiful but slightly weathered from the many years in the same post--since 1628, according to informational text at the
This place offers typical coffee shops and restaurants around it. It offers a soft breeze on hot summer days
We enjoyed an outdoor lunch at a cafe near the Lion Fountain. A little boy about four years of age took a swim in the fountain and provided entertainment when his head bobbed up above the side.

Its sad how nothing extra ordinary is done to show off the beaughty this place has to offer. We living in the i information age and it would be nice if technology is used to explain this rich in history fountain. That is what also makes it beautiful for me.

This fountain left by venetians is now in the heart of movida in ancient Heraklion; it is situated in the middle of a liveful place with plenty tavernas and restaurant; most of the people present in this place minds their own business also not considering the beautiful fountain

This is where you sit to enjoy a morning coffee or evening glass of wine. Most of the dining establishments' seating faces out to the fountains for a view. The fountain itself is not impressive, except when you consider its age. But the music, the shops, the street scene, and
centrally located in the heart of the commercial district- enjoy an ice-cream nearby and let your thoughts travel you back in time

My husband and I visited the Morosini Fountain when we stopped in Crete on our Mediterranean Cruise. The fountain was built in 1629 and features four lions with water pouring from their mouths. It's a good central landmark to orient yourself amongst the shops and cafes. We had
Located on the Eleftheriou Venizelou Square (more commonly known as Lions Square). Providing 1000 barrels of water a day it solved the problem of supplying Heraklion with water.
The fountain is at a good cross roads in the old city. It makes for an easily findable meeting point for a group.

It was in the center of town. VERY photogenic statue. It was just difficult to take a picture because of either the foot traffic or people lounging. It's not in a secluded area where tourists are limited to viewing. It's a part of the town.
Butiful place, a lot of local people's and tourists. Music lights good waives. Nice please to have drink coffee or raki, ice cream etc.
It is just a fountain, but the shopping and the gelato make this destination a score of a 3. There are a lot of places to eat and stroll, so the area is a good location to spend the afternoon.

We stopped here to eat our ice cream, there's a single bench shaded by a tree, allowing a view of the fountain and a little people watching. There were railings in 1910 and they lions used to spout water, but that has all gone. Never less , a nice place to stop for 15 mins or so

THIS beautifully restored fountain sits at the centre of Heraklion's busiest square. It's construction was ordered and supervised in 1628 by Francesco Morosini, a man who managed to bring spring water to parched Heraklion via a series of channels and pipelines. The cistern is
In the center of the old historic city, you can find this place surrounded by restaurants. There is still water and you can cool down yourself. Beautiful restauration work done here.

Great to see and make photographs from in Heraklion. From this fountain are many different roads and way to go. Useful to use google maps or your own map to decide wher to go. If in a large group, this is a very good meeting point.

The fountain takes its name after the Capitan Generale Francesco Morozini. During his rule, the aqueduct was constructed to water the town of Heraklion. The aqueduct was inaugurated on April 25th, 1628, i.e. on the feast day of Saint Mark, the protector of Venice. The tank of
A centrepiece worthy to see. Photogenic and centrally located. Reminds me of a typical European fountain.

It is hard to miss the fountain when in the area. Take a moment and examine the well preserved ( over 400 years! ) bas relief carvings, such fine examples of the Venetian occupation. The back story on the aqueduct leading to the fountain and the physics is quite fascinating!
This is a nice place to sit and relax. If you have a coffee takeaway it’s even better! There are only 4 benches around it and it’s always occupied. There are many cafes around it too.
You cannot miss this fountain right in the center of the old town. It's beautiful and the spot is great for people watching while eating gelato from nearby place

The central square of the city is well-known for the famous fountain, designed in the 17th century, by Francesco Morosini and the engineers Corner, Monnani and Basilicata as the final section of the 15 kilometers long Heraklion aqueduct. The fountain is decorated with the scenes

What a great city centre! An historic fountain with beautiful surroundings and a ton of historical buildings as well as cafes serving great Crete food which is slightly different than Greek food! There are wide walkways and shopping areas with the possibility of spending

This is the central fountain, the most cosmopolitic place on Heraklion. The big market street ends there as well as it has many other businesses arround. On your trip there be sure to check it out and enjoy the local products arround it.
Heard a lot about that fountain. I expected being bigger! But it's really nice and with many cafeterias and shops around.

The centre of Heraklion, it has a wonderful mix of old and new with this stunning working fountain that is hundreds of years old compared to the modern coffee shops surrounding it. Its a great place to relax and grab a drink. Also very near to the main shopping strip. A
The place is full of shops you can sit enjoy a coffee while viewing the fountain, its the center of heraklion and i think everyone goes by there

Located about half way up the main pedestrianised street of the old town and surrounded by bars and restaurants. The fountain itself is pretty enough without being anything starting but it’s a good area to sit and watch the world go by over a drink.
That is the center of Heraklion everyone goes there to meet up and get a coffee, there are lots of cafeterias nearby and all of them have nice view!
Whilst smaller than expected still lovely & very well located in centre of town. Spend time at one of the many cafes watching the world go by

This was a 18 minute walk from our hotel and it was a nice place to visit. There was a LOT of people there in the evening and it was fun to people watch. Most of the shops were already closed, however, we’ll probably go back in the morning to check them out. Nice place.
This fountain which is almost 500 years old is worth a look and surrounded by restaurants and places to eat. It is on a walkway with many streets converging on it so you cannot miss it.

It's not the most impressive fountain in the world however when you take into account it's 400 years old then it deserves to be appreciated. Situated in a delightful pedestrian square it's a great focal point while sitting at a cafe enjoying a glass of wine or coffee.

The Morosini Fountain, decorated with bas relief figures that want you to look more closely, is a beautiful reminder of the Venetian era in Crete. When it was commissioned in 1628 by the same Venetian Governor, General Francesco Morosini, who commissioned the nearby loggia. It

If you go in Heraklion you have to pass Lions Fountain.Krini Morozini is one of the best monuments in Heraklion and the reason of built was to provide water to heraklion people from Mountain Giouhtas 15km away! You have to visit!
The fountain is the center and working perfectly, nice shops nearby to eat drink shop! The sign gives information and difficult to miss

Nice fountain, although usually too popular, and surrounded by tourists all trying to get the same 'unique' selfie. Keep an eye out for the beggers in the daytime/evening and the numerous feral dogs roaming in the late evening/early morning
This fountain is in a great location! Perfect meeting spot to walk to restaurants or cafes! Beautiful when functioning!
Meet your friends here and go in any direction for delicious traditional food. Or walk downhill to the harbor.
You’re bound to encounter this while walking the city, so no need to make it a destination. The best part of visiting it is that there are many restaurants and shops nearby.

Beautiful fountain from 1629 made by order of Cretan governor venetian aristocrat Francesco Morosini. Even it is vey nice decorated by the lions (symbols of Venetian republic) and well decorated by sea allegories on base it held in past two functions - necessary supling by water
This fountain just appears from nowhere and you seem to be in another age. You will find it for sure if you walk around the city.
The place where all people, the place where most of the restaurants are around or in a walking distance. Variety of bars as well around.

This 17th century Venetian fountain sits in Lion's Square, which is the heart of Heraklion's old city and from which fan out numerous pedestrian streets chock-full of restaurants, cafes and ice-cream vendors. Not to be missed.

This fountain is the hub of Heraklion activity. Everything seems to emanate from here. Cafes, hundreds of shops, historic landmarks, everything in the city center is only steps away from this lovely spot. We don't have to recommend, you will end up here anyway.

Besides the meeting-point appeal of the Lions Square (officially Eleftheriou Venizelou Square), its value as a tourist landmark is increased by Fontana Morosini, the work of the Provveditore Generale (Superintendent) Francesco Morosini and the engineers Zorzi Corner, Raffaello

Don't expect anything owesome, but the lion's square is the center of the town center. Once you are there, you have to try the traditional "bougatsa" (a special kind of cheese pie) in the nearby cafes and just take your time watching people go by...
Ancient fountain decorated with lions that is easily accessible from the cruise terminal. Worth a short walk to get a few photos and experience to locals going about their normal activities.

Interesting remainder of the Venetian past of the city - the fountain is actually bigger than you'd expect. It is the central meeting point on the main drag. Oddly enough, situated among all the hubbub of shoppers and restaurant goers, the benches offer a respite and let you
The fountain is nothing fancy or special, but it serves as a central meeting point / landmark to help navigate the area.
This is an interesting and pretty fountain, but not worth a detour. Just take it in as you walk up past the Loggia towards the cathedral.

Don't miss this. Amazing to think dates to Venetian times! In great condition. A great place to use to get your bearings geographically, and also as a meeting point. Lots of cafes and restaurants surround this so a great eating place as well!
As fountains go, it's nice enough. There are plenty of restaurants around, so it makes a decent spot to take five and regroup after walking the slightly disappointing sightseeing walks.
The water in the fountain was very dirty when we were there. Tourists do not care about where they throw their garbage. It looks very old and nice.
The fountain is surrounded by cafes, yes you pay more if you eat in the square and there are more places beyond, but if is a great place to people watch.
Lovely feature that's still in use and working order. You can admire the feature from the very numerous small coffee shops around the square.
Walked past it a number of times but only really noticed it one evening when some local dogs took to bathing in it. Very cute. Seems to be a meeting place given its central position .

Officially called the “Fontana Morosini” but known to all as the Lion Fountain. This is a fountain at a busy pedestrianised crossroads at the heart of Heraklion, dating from 1628 and built by the Venetians. As its name suggests it contains statues of lions with water gushing

In the centre of a delightful pedestrianised mall in Heraklion there is a circular space surrounded by shaded tavernas and ice-cream parlours, and another popular rendez-vous, the Morosíni Fountain. This Heraklion landmark was built in 1628 by the Venetian governor Francesco

The Lion's Square Fountain (which everyone in Crete knows it as) is one of the most important monuments bestowed on the city by the Venetians during their rule. The square on which is it situated has a long and significant history through Arabic, to Byzantine to Venetian times.
Worth a visit if you stroll around the city. Have a seat in one of the many bars and restaurant and take a drink or a bite to eat. And watch all the people passing by on the square.

The Morosini fountain stand in the centre of the city in a very fascinating square. The fountain is also called Lion's fountain because there are the sculpture of some lions. The fountains is quite large and very attractive.

The Lions fountain is found midway in the pedestrians walk away. Lots of restaurants and cafés surround the fountain... it can be quite busy in the evening so if you want a table on the walkway you probably need to get there early. Lots of shops... fun and activities!
In the city centre the fountain is surrounded by tavernas from the 1920’s and is worth a look. It’s a selfie spot and doesn’t take long to see.

It is one of the many attractions of Heraklion, Crete. There are many coffee shops and taverns around to have a rest and enjoy a coffee or meal. It is in a walking distance from the castle and the Archaeological museum
The square gets busy, but it’s a well maintained and beautiful piece of history surrounded by coffee shops, restaurants and stores. Great place to relax and do some people watching!
Historical spot in the center of Heraklion! We enjoyed our walk around the city center! It's a great point in the city
Always surrounded by throngs, the Morosini Fountain is a hub of activity in Heraklion. Lots of pubs and restaurants in sight. If solitude is what you seek, try going at 7 am.

This fountain is wonderful due to its layers of stonework and the fountain itself has many outlets of water pouring, each with their own interesting parts. It's a great location along the main shopping street (25th August Street) surrounded by cafes, shops, take away places.

Typical tourist tat.with shop after shop selling olive oil and sponges.very crowded .every shop you stop to look the shopkeeper pounces .a bit off putting .fountain was nothing spectacular with graffiti seats surrounding it..

We have visited this place for lunch and shopping there and we love the vibe of the place and there you will find lot of places to dine and to do shopping. You will enjoy the vibe as well as ambiance. Must visit place for tourist.
Lovely fountain in the centre of heraklion where you can sit and watch the world go by. Lots of bars and restaurants to sit in the shade, where you can enjoy meals or waffles, crepes and drinks
Can't really say much other than it's a water fountain with water coming out of the mouths of the lions. That's it.
Most people stop here for a photo opportunity. Lots of things going on around the fountain, great place to sit and eat ice cream while people watching.
On a hot day the sound of the water in this elegant fountain was a cooling delight - it's worth walking past and stopping for a photo.
Lively fountain set in centre of Heriklion surrounded by food outlets. Would miss it if not looking fot it specifically
I just happened upon this after having a bite for lunch. Took a photo and carried on walking. Nothing amazing.

In the center of Heraklion city you can found this monument. Its size and architecture is remarkable but i should say that needs immediate restoration and cleaning. Its too bad that is so neglected by the authorities...

If you are walking throug the center of Heraklion, this is a nice place to hang out. You have many activities around the fountain. In the night is a verry active area, is a great place to meet and take photos.
A fountain in a shopping area. Not a whole lot to say about it. Took a few pictures. Easy to find. Central location.
in the centre of heraklion crete town ,meeting place for many years....many shops arround and the main market is close,olso the port

We visited Crete and had walked around for awhile before we came upon this wonderful Plaza. There were lots of tourists walking around and restaurants and shops and coffee bars and ice cream and balloons for sale. There were all ages there with lots of strollers. We stopped at a

Its a nice photo op for a couple of pics, we felt that while its nice to look at, its not at all well maintained with very less and dirty water flowing in it and also there are so many eatieries surrounding it and very close to it that doesn't help. So, take a couple of pics
We found this fountain nice to look at and use as a photo opportunity. It is a good place to use as a meeting point.

We came across this fountain as we were walking the streets in Heraklion town. It was a historical fountain beautiful and well maintained in the middle of this pedestrian area. Surrounded by restaurants and cafes it is worth a stop!
Beautiful, great history. In center of shopping and restaurants. Lots of street performers at night.
Beautiful and similar to the lions fountain in Alhambra. We visited it with snall kids and was good. Good to see it!
Beautiful old fountain and great place to watch the world go by. Visit Melba Salt & Sugar for the best ice cream and the friendliest staff then sit back and soak in the atmosphere
300 year old fountain from the Venitian times in Crete. Adds to the atmosphere of this area. Nice lights in the evening.

Head for the Morosini Fountain if you want to visit Heraklion's old town. This old Venetian drinking fountain is now surrounded by cafe and bars but remains an impressive sight in its own right (although it is now mostly dry). One of the must see sights in Heraklion !
The fountain is nice and in the main hub of Heraklion. It contains lion statutes and looks very nice.The fountain didn't have any water in it when we were there.
Just a fountain. Interesting, but nothing more. Go there if you got time and fancy a short walk, tak a picture and just move on :)
Nothing there except a dirty unkempt fountain. Cheap restaurants etc around it. Not worth walking to!
I always visit this place when I go to Heraklion. Nice place for a walk or drinking a coffee. Go there, you will not be disappointed.
Walked around the square and the part of the old town. Nice location with many choices for coffee or food. Overall nice experience and a good meeting point for friends.
Nice place. Lots of restaurant around. Beautifull Greek old roads as well all around. Also is located in central of old town. Highly recommended.

We stumbled upon this fountain when we were exploring the town and I do think it is too highly rated... There isn't really anything that special about it other than it having 4 lions. It is a nice area to visit, but not worth going out of your way to see it :)

It was being cleaned when we saw this but it was still lovely. It was good to see how they cleaned it with the little tools they had and the difference it made after that section was cleaned. All around are eating places but we went to Chop Chop just up a smal alley way and near
We were strolling around & came upon the fountain. Lot of character & surrounded by lovely eateries of all varieties.

We didn't go out of our way to visit this attraction, we were staying in Heraklion town centre and came across it on one of our walks. Pretty and nice to look at. Disappointed as there was litter in it, I guess some tourists or even locals don't care where they leave there
Nice place in the middle of city center! Very visible in the main square in the town. Must visit! Around the fountain you will see a lot of shops and restaurants.

Right at the Morosini fountain, you got several good restaurants. We ate at one of the Greek taverns (can't remember the name, but it's right near the fountain) The variety of things to eat is large and it seems that anyone will find something to eat there with very reasonable
Went here alot! just couldn't stay away, very clean, friendly people, food was good along with beautiful weather
This place of the city is a great place for a walk . Nice coffee shops and great restaurants in the area. Very nice place to have a drink and people watch.
Musicians, tourists and locals all gather around the fountain. Lots of fast food and ice cream places around it. Good restaurants are a few blocks further afield.

We enjoyed sitting and staring at the lovely fountain which was built during the Venetian era of Crete while nibbling on small bites and sipping coffees from the local cafes in the square. the fountain is right in the heart of the central hot spots in town and each to find and

A Venetian monument which recalls the 4 centuries long rule of Venice in Crete before the long siege and finally fall to the Ottoman Turks. Locals and tourists alike enjoy refreshments or a meal in the surrounding cafes and indulge in people watching. A very pleasant place to
Beautiful fountain water feature with carved lions in the town centre. Best to come early morning for photos, before the crowds arrive.

Beautiful spot that had an old band playing when I was there. Very fun and relaxing atmosphere. Only downside is the people who approach you and relentlessly try to sell you "authentic" sunglasses and other crap

The fountain is surrounded bu food, lots to see or eat. It may be ancient but the fountain itself is very unimpressive, apart from age. Water dribbles out as if to indicate what it used to do a long time ago. Not one to go out of your way to, but worth a look if in the area.

Go early & you may get the square to yourself & enjoy the fountain. Any other time & it's buzzing, surrounded by bars etc It has a lovely atmosphere though & the noise of the fountain makes you feel cooler than you probably are!
You ll love it as a part of your walk in Heraklion go sit and relax have a drink and take a look on it quick and simple but u ll love and the good thing it's for free .

We sat by the fountain, serenaded by musicians, watching tumblers perform, and eating crepes and waffles that were delicious. You do get pressured to buy things from the occasional trader, but mostly it is a lovely spot for lunch.
Nice fountain, lovely lions, one of the most popular places in Iraklion. On the way from Venetian harbour. It is possible to say that is a heart of the city.
It is very nice looking and a good place to observe Venetian architecture. The condition is good and hard to take a picture as it is surrounded by modern buildings.
A great place to meet friends. Surrounded by restaurants, cafes and museums. Everything you need is within 30 feet of the fountain. A great place to get a hotel near.
We visited the Lion fountain in Heraklion on a day trip. It was the perfect spot to sit and watch the world go by and have a snack and a drink. Charming.
This lovely fountain is the centre piece of a lovely little square. Worth a photo as you pass by, just a shame it wasn't working.
Well worth a visit and it's in the middle of shops and taverns all very friendly. It's a unique historical feature of Heraklion although when we were there it was not working still worth a visit
I think it was under reconstruction when we were there, it looked liked it needed it and it seemed to look a little tired. Hopefully it will look better when the renovation is complete

The fountain was not working and was under construction. But it would have been neat to see as it was so old. What was fun was the market street nearby...just across the intersection. Tons of our touristy stuff but fun to walk up and purchase some plastic souvenirs. ;)

The fountain looked abandoned and dirty when we visited Heraklion in May. There was no water in it. We were quite disappointed as it was mentioned in our travel book as a must see in Heraklion. Heraklion as a whole is quite disappointed as well. We spent 2 hours there and it

A pro-EU rally decided to descend on the square, blowing whistles and sounding air horns. (Gosh, the Greeks like a noisy demonstration). I imagine it to be a lovely spot for a cooling glass of Crete white wine in more peaceful circumstances. When we were here the fountain is
a great sculpture,in a great area for shopping,eating.the fountain where not working when we visit ,but still a nice.
The center for restaurants in Heraklion, or just lazing around. A lot of people, fun and animated. The fountain itself is beautiful and cool in a place that can get quite hot.

The Four Lions or Morozini Fountain is one of the city landmarks right in the centre of Heraklion. It was build from Frantsesko Morozini in the 1600s to bring fresh water to the city from a spring 10 Km away. Enjoy the Venetian architecture and admire the craftmanship. What

Certainly not worth going out of your way to see, but if you are in downtown Heraklion, walk to the fountain and take a photo. Built by Venetians in the 14th Century, it still functions and is attractive.
Absolutely nothing special about this fountain. They are currently doing restoration work so there wasn't much to see
We went the second week of May and were unable to see the true beauty of the fountains due to restoration work being carried out. Not sure how long this will take to complete.
This fountain is worth seeing, and is a very busy meeting point in Heraklion, but if you miss it, your trip isn't ruined.
Right in the heart of town surrounded by bars and restaurants. It's a great place to sit and have a beer and watch the world go by. Busy all day and night
Found this after wandering up one of the main shopping streets. Nice enough, plenty of bars and shops around it. Was under renovation when we went. If you're nearby then it's worth seeing.
Worth seeing if you're passing nearby but nothing really out of the ordinary. Water was very clean but the fountain doesn't work.

The center of the heart of the city of Heraklion. A nice and picturesque square with plenty of cafes all around !!

Located in the middle of the old part of town. Nicely lit in the evening with a lot of bars and restaurant in the neighbourhood.

In a run down city this is a masterpiece all n its own, quite easy to find, I used google mapping and found it easy

Beautiful place, surrounded by cafes and stores. A place to stay and watch the old greek people. A good place to visit.
NIce fountain in the middle of the pedestrian area. Reminds me of Italy Surrounded by cafes and stores

Had a coffee break in one of the many cafés surrounding the fountain. The weather was perfect & was ideal as a stop over in between shopping.

very nice fountain in the main shopping road. lots of bars along there, gets really loud and crowded at evenings/nights better visit in the afternoon and drink a cafe frape, fresh juice or fresh made lemonada here, more empty in the afternoon/siestatime

Nice fountain surrounded by bars and restaurants. A good place to meet or sit, have a drink and watch the world go by.

a touch of history of Crete,,,looks romantic, many meetings place for lost people:) surrounded my restaurants and cosy coffee shops, very well preserved,,,or restored

Located in a quite busy square, this foutain gives a nice touch the place. You can sure enjoy it from one of the cafes nearby or by walking by.

Beautiful fountain in the middle of town, nice area to stop and have a bite to eat and a drink and watch the world go by.

text.wiki:
Heraklion or Iraklion ( hih-RAK-lee-ən; Greek: Ηράκλειο, Irákleio, pronounced [iˈraklio]) is the largest city and the administrative capital of the island of Crete and capital of Heraklion regional unit. It is the fourth largest city in Greece with a population of 211,370 (Urban Area) according to the 2011 census. The population of the municipality was 173,993.The Bronze Age palace of Knossos, also known as the Palace of Minos, is located nearby.
Heraklion was Europe's fastest growing tourism destination for 2017, according to Euromonitor, with an 11.2% growth in international arrivals. According to the ranking, Heraklion was ranked as the 20th most visited region in Europe, as the 66th area on the Planet and as the 2nd in Greece for the year 2017, with 3.2 million visitors and the 19th in Europe for 2018, with 3.4 million visitors.


== Names ==
The Arab traders from al-Andalus (Iberia) who founded the Emirate of Crete moved the island's capital from Gortyna to a new castle they called rabḍ al-ḫandaq (Arabic: ربض الخندق‎, "Castle of the Moat") in the 820s. This was hellenized as Χάνδαξ (Chándax) or Χάνδακας (Chándakas) and Latinized as Candia, which was taken into other European languages: in Italian and Latin as Candia, in French as Candie, in English as Candy, all of which could refer to the island of Crete as a whole as well as to the city alone; the Ottoman name was Kandiye.
After the Byzantine reconquest of Crete, the city was locally known as Megalo Kastro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο, 'Big Castle' in Greek) and its inhabitants were called Kastrinoi (Καστρινοί, "castle-dwellers").
The ancient name Ηράκλειον was revived in the 19th century and comes from the nearby Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles's city"), whose exact location is unknown. English usage formerly preferred the classicizing transliterations "Heraklion" or "Heraclion", but the form "Iraklion" is becoming more common.


== History ==


=== Minoan Era ===
Heraklion is close to the ruins of the palace of Knossos, which in Minoan times was the largest centre of population on Crete. Knossos had a port at the site of Heraklion (at Poros - Katsambas neighborhood) from the beginning of Early Minoan period (3500 to 2100 BC). Between 1600 and 1525 BC, the port was destroyed by a volcanic tsunami from nearby Santorini, leveling the region and covering it with ash.


=== Antiquity ===

After the fall of the Minoans, Heraklion, as well as the rest of Crete in general, fared poorly, with very little development in the area. Only with the arrival of the Romans did some construction in the area begin, yet especially early into Byzantine times the area was abound with pirates and bandits.


=== Emirate of Crete ===
The present city of Heraklion was founded in 824 by the Arabs under Abu Hafs Umar who had been expelled from Al-Andalus by Emir Al-Hakam I and had taken over the island from the Eastern Roman Empire. They built a moat around the city for protection, and named the city rabḍ al-ḫandaq (ربض الخندق, "Castle of the Moat", hellenized as Χάνδαξ, Chandax). It became the capital of the Emirate of Crete (ca. 827–961). The Saracens allowed the port to be used as a safe haven for pirates who operated against Imperial (Byzantine) shipping and raided Imperial territory around the Aegean.


=== Byzantine era ===

In 960, Byzantine forces under the command of Nikephoros Phokas, later to become Emperor, landed in Crete and attacked the city. After a prolonged siege, the city fell in March 961. The Saracen inhabitants were slaughtered, the city looted and burned to the ground. Soon rebuilt, the town remained under Byzantine control for the next 243 years.


=== Venetian era ===
 
In 1204, the city was bought by the Republic of Venice as part of a complicated political deal which involved, among other things, the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade restoring the deposed Eastern Roman Emperor Isaac II Angelus to his throne. The Venetians improved on the ditch of the city by building enormous fortifications, most of which are still in place, including a giant wall, in places up to 40 m thick, with 7 bastions, and a fortress in the harbour. Chandax was renamed Candia and became the seat of the Duke of Candia, and the Venetian administrative district of Crete became known as "Regno di Candia" (Kingdom of Candia). The city retained the name of Candia for centuries and the same name was often used to refer to the whole island of Crete as well. To secure their rule, Venetians began in 1212 to settle families from Venice on Crete. The coexistence of two different cultures and the stimulus of Italian Renaissance led to a flourishing of letters and the arts in Candia and Crete in general, that is today known as the Cretan Renaissance.


=== Ottoman era ===

During the Cretan War (1645–1669), the Ottomans besieged the city for 21 years, from 1648 to 1669, perhaps the longest siege in history. In its final phase, which lasted for 22 months, 70,000 Turks, 38,000 Cretans and slaves and 29,088 of the city's Christian defenders perished. The Ottoman army under an Albanian grand vizier, Köprülü Fazıl Ahmed Pasha conquered the city in 1669. 
Under the Ottomans, Kandiye (Ottoman Turkish قنديه) was the capital of Crete (Girit Eyâleti) until 1849, when Chania (Hanya) became the capital, and Kandiye became a sancak. In Greek, it was commonly called Megalo Castro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο 'Big Castle').
During the Ottoman period, the harbour silted up, so most shipping shifted to Chania in the west of the island.


=== Modern era ===
In 1898, the autonomous Cretan State was created, under Ottoman suzerainty, with Prince George of Greece as its High Commissioner and under international supervision. During the period of direct occupation of the island by the Great Powers (1898–1908), Candia was part of the British zone. At this time, the city was renamed "Heraklion", after the Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles' city"), whose exact location is unknown.
In 1913, with the rest of Crete, Heraklion was incorporated into the Kingdom of Greece. Heraklion became again capital of Crete in 1971, replacing Chania.


== Architecture, urban sculpture and fortifications ==

Venetian constructions such as the Koules Fortress (Castello a Mare), the ramparts and the arsenal dominate the port area.
Several sculptures, statues and busts commemorating significant events and figures of the city's and island's history, like El Greco, Vitsentzos Kornaros, Nikos Kazantzakis and Eleftherios Venizelos can be found around the city.
Many fountains of the Venetian era are preserved, such as the Bembo fountain, the Priuli fountain, Palmeti fountain, Sagredo fountain and Morosini fountain (in Lions Square).
Around the historic city center of Heraklion there are also a series of defensive walls, bastions and other fortifications which were built earlier in the Middle Ages, but were completely rebuilt by the Republic of Venice. The fortifications managed to withstand the longest siege in history for 21 years, before the city fell to the Ottomans in 1669.


== Municipality ==

The municipality Heraklion was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 5 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Gorgolainis
Heraklion
Nea Alikarnassos
Paliani
TemenosThe municipality has an area of 244.613 km2, the municipal unit 109.026 km2.


== Neighborhoods ==


== Suburbs ==


== Transportation ==


=== Port ===
Heraklion is an important shipping port and ferry dock. Travellers can take ferries and boats from Heraklion to destinations including Santorini, Ios Island, Paros, Mykonos, and Rhodes. There are direct ferries to Naxos, Karpathos, Kasos, Sitia, Anafi, Chalki and Diafani. There are also several daily ferries to Piraeus, the port of Athens in mainland Greece. The port of Heraklion was built by Sir Robert McAlpine and completed in 1928.


=== Airport ===
Heraklion International Airport, or Nikos Kazantzakis Airport is located about 5 kilometres (3 miles) east of the city. The airport is named after Heraklion native Nikos Kazantzakis, a writer and a philosopher. It is the second busiest airport of Greece after Athens International Airport, first in charter flights and the 65th busiest in Europe, because of Crete being a major holiday destination with 7.974.887 travellers in 2018 (List of the busiest airports in Europe).
In April 2018, the inner space of the airport has been modernized and expanded by almost 3.000 s.m., with 11 new gates and new stores. The expansion was a donation by Hellenic Duty Free Shops.
The airfield is shared with the 126th Combat Group of the Hellenic Air Force.
A project for the new airport of Heraklion in Kasteli area is starting at the end of 2017.


=== Highway network ===
European route E75 runs through the city and connects Heraklion with the three other major cities of Crete: Agios Nikolaos, Chania, and Rethymno.


=== Public transit ===

Urban buses serving the city, with 39 different routes. Intercity buses connects Heraklion to many major destinations in Crete.


=== Railway ===
From 1922 to 1937, there was a working industrial railway, which connected the Koules in Heraklion to Xiropotamos for the construction of the harbor.
A study from the year 2000 investigated the feasibility of two tram lines in Heraklion. The first line would link the Stadium to the airport, and the second the center of Heraklion and Knossos.  No approval has yet been given for this proposal.
In the summer of 2007, at the Congress of Cretan emigrants, held in Heraklion, two qualified engineers, George Nathenas (from Gonies, Malevizi Province) and Vassilis Economopoulos, recommended the development of a railway line in Crete, linking Chania, Rethymno and Heraklion, with a total journey time of 50 minutes (30 minutes between Heraklion and Rethymno, 20 minutes from Chania to Rethymno) and with provision for extensions to Kissamos, Kastelli Pediados (for the planned new airport), and Agios Nikolaos. No plans exist for implementing this idea.


== Climate ==
Heraklion has a hot-summer-Mediterranean climate (Csa in the Köppen climate classification). Summers are warm to hot and dry with clear skies. Dry hot days are often relieved by seasonal breezes. Winters are very mild with moderate rain. Because Heraklion is further south than Athens, it has a warmer climate during winter but cooler during summer because of the Aegean sea. The maximum temperature during the summer period is usually not more than 28 - 30 °C (Athens normal maximum temperature is about 6 °C higher). The minimum temperature record is -0.2 °C
A new temperature record for February was set at 27.8 °C, reached on 15 February 2016.

=== Arts ===
The Cultural and Conference Center of Heraklion is a centre for the performing arts.


=== Sports ===
The city is home to several sports clubs. Most notably, Heraklion hosts OFI and Ergotelis, two football clubs with earlier presence in the Greek Superleague, the top tier of the Greek football league system. Furthermore, the city is the headquarters of the Heraklion Football Clubs Association, which administers football in the entire region. Other notable sport clubs include Iraklio B.C. (basketball), Atsalenios (football) and Irodotos (football) in the suburbs of Atsalenio and Nea Alikarnassos respectively.


=== Famous natives ===

Heraklion has been the home town of some of Greece's most significant people, including the novelist Nikos Kazantzakis (best known for Zorba the Greek), the poet and Nobel Prize winner Odysseas Elytis and the world-famous painter Domenicos Theotokopoulos (El Greco).
