text.wiki:
Heraklion or Iraklion ( hih-RAK-lee-ən; Greek: Ηράκλειο, Irákleio, pronounced [iˈraklio]) is the largest city and the administrative capital of the island of Crete and capital of Heraklion regional unit. It is the fourth largest city in Greece with a population of 211,370 (Urban Area) according to the 2011 census. The population of the municipality was 173,993.The Bronze Age palace of Knossos, also known as the Palace of Minos, is located nearby.
Heraklion was Europe's fastest growing tourism destination for 2017, according to Euromonitor, with an 11.2% growth in international arrivals. According to the ranking, Heraklion was ranked as the 20th most visited region in Europe, as the 66th area on the Planet and as the 2nd in Greece for the year 2017, with 3.2 million visitors and the 19th in Europe for 2018, with 3.4 million visitors.


== Names ==
The Arab traders from al-Andalus (Iberia) who founded the Emirate of Crete moved the island's capital from Gortyna to a new castle they called rabḍ al-ḫandaq (Arabic: ربض الخندق‎, "Castle of the Moat") in the 820s. This was hellenized as Χάνδαξ (Chándax) or Χάνδακας (Chándakas) and Latinized as Candia, which was taken into other European languages: in Italian and Latin as Candia, in French as Candie, in English as Candy, all of which could refer to the island of Crete as a whole as well as to the city alone; the Ottoman name was Kandiye.
After the Byzantine reconquest of Crete, the city was locally known as Megalo Kastro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο, 'Big Castle' in Greek) and its inhabitants were called Kastrinoi (Καστρινοί, "castle-dwellers").
The ancient name Ηράκλειον was revived in the 19th century and comes from the nearby Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles's city"), whose exact location is unknown. English usage formerly preferred the classicizing transliterations "Heraklion" or "Heraclion", but the form "Iraklion" is becoming more common.


== History ==


=== Minoan Era ===
Heraklion is close to the ruins of the palace of Knossos, which in Minoan times was the largest centre of population on Crete. Knossos had a port at the site of Heraklion (at Poros - Katsambas neighborhood) from the beginning of Early Minoan period (3500 to 2100 BC). Between 1600 and 1525 BC, the port was destroyed by a volcanic tsunami from nearby Santorini, leveling the region and covering it with ash.


=== Antiquity ===

After the fall of the Minoans, Heraklion, as well as the rest of Crete in general, fared poorly, with very little development in the area. Only with the arrival of the Romans did some construction in the area begin, yet especially early into Byzantine times the area was abound with pirates and bandits.


=== Emirate of Crete ===
The present city of Heraklion was founded in 824 by the Arabs under Abu Hafs Umar who had been expelled from Al-Andalus by Emir Al-Hakam I and had taken over the island from the Eastern Roman Empire. They built a moat around the city for protection, and named the city rabḍ al-ḫandaq (ربض الخندق, "Castle of the Moat", hellenized as Χάνδαξ, Chandax). It became the capital of the Emirate of Crete (ca. 827–961). The Saracens allowed the port to be used as a safe haven for pirates who operated against Imperial (Byzantine) shipping and raided Imperial territory around the Aegean.


=== Byzantine era ===

In 960, Byzantine forces under the command of Nikephoros Phokas, later to become Emperor, landed in Crete and attacked the city. After a prolonged siege, the city fell in March 961. The Saracen inhabitants were slaughtered, the city looted and burned to the ground. Soon rebuilt, the town remained under Byzantine control for the next 243 years.


=== Venetian era ===
 
In 1204, the city was bought by the Republic of Venice as part of a complicated political deal which involved, among other things, the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade restoring the deposed Eastern Roman Emperor Isaac II Angelus to his throne. The Venetians improved on the ditch of the city by building enormous fortifications, most of which are still in place, including a giant wall, in places up to 40 m thick, with 7 bastions, and a fortress in the harbour. Chandax was renamed Candia and became the seat of the Duke of Candia, and the Venetian administrative district of Crete became known as "Regno di Candia" (Kingdom of Candia). The city retained the name of Candia for centuries and the same name was often used to refer to the whole island of Crete as well. To secure their rule, Venetians began in 1212 to settle families from Venice on Crete. The coexistence of two different cultures and the stimulus of Italian Renaissance led to a flourishing of letters and the arts in Candia and Crete in general, that is today known as the Cretan Renaissance.


=== Ottoman era ===

During the Cretan War (1645–1669), the Ottomans besieged the city for 21 years, from 1648 to 1669, perhaps the longest siege in history. In its final phase, which lasted for 22 months, 70,000 Turks, 38,000 Cretans and slaves and 29,088 of the city's Christian defenders perished. The Ottoman army under an Albanian grand vizier, Köprülü Fazıl Ahmed Pasha conquered the city in 1669. 
Under the Ottomans, Kandiye (Ottoman Turkish قنديه) was the capital of Crete (Girit Eyâleti) until 1849, when Chania (Hanya) became the capital, and Kandiye became a sancak. In Greek, it was commonly called Megalo Castro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο 'Big Castle').
During the Ottoman period, the harbour silted up, so most shipping shifted to Chania in the west of the island.


=== Modern era ===
In 1898, the autonomous Cretan State was created, under Ottoman suzerainty, with Prince George of Greece as its High Commissioner and under international supervision. During the period of direct occupation of the island by the Great Powers (1898–1908), Candia was part of the British zone. At this time, the city was renamed "Heraklion", after the Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles' city"), whose exact location is unknown.
In 1913, with the rest of Crete, Heraklion was incorporated into the Kingdom of Greece. Heraklion became again capital of Crete in 1971, replacing Chania.


== Architecture, urban sculpture and fortifications ==

Venetian constructions such as the Koules Fortress (Castello a Mare), the ramparts and the arsenal dominate the port area.
Several sculptures, statues and busts commemorating significant events and figures of the city's and island's history, like El Greco, Vitsentzos Kornaros, Nikos Kazantzakis and Eleftherios Venizelos can be found around the city.
Many fountains of the Venetian era are preserved, such as the Bembo fountain, the Priuli fountain, Palmeti fountain, Sagredo fountain and Morosini fountain (in Lions Square).
Around the historic city center of Heraklion there are also a series of defensive walls, bastions and other fortifications which were built earlier in the Middle Ages, but were completely rebuilt by the Republic of Venice. The fortifications managed to withstand the longest siege in history for 21 years, before the city fell to the Ottomans in 1669.


== Municipality ==

The municipality Heraklion was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 5 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Gorgolainis
Heraklion
Nea Alikarnassos
Paliani
TemenosThe municipality has an area of 244.613 km2, the municipal unit 109.026 km2.


== Neighborhoods ==


== Suburbs ==


== Transportation ==


=== Port ===
Heraklion is an important shipping port and ferry dock. Travellers can take ferries and boats from Heraklion to destinations including Santorini, Ios Island, Paros, Mykonos, and Rhodes. There are direct ferries to Naxos, Karpathos, Kasos, Sitia, Anafi, Chalki and Diafani. There are also several daily ferries to Piraeus, the port of Athens in mainland Greece. The port of Heraklion was built by Sir Robert McAlpine and completed in 1928.


=== Airport ===
Heraklion International Airport, or Nikos Kazantzakis Airport is located about 5 kilometres (3 miles) east of the city. The airport is named after Heraklion native Nikos Kazantzakis, a writer and a philosopher. It is the second busiest airport of Greece after Athens International Airport, first in charter flights and the 65th busiest in Europe, because of Crete being a major holiday destination with 7.974.887 travellers in 2018 (List of the busiest airports in Europe).
In April 2018, the inner space of the airport has been modernized and expanded by almost 3.000 s.m., with 11 new gates and new stores. The expansion was a donation by Hellenic Duty Free Shops.
The airfield is shared with the 126th Combat Group of the Hellenic Air Force.
A project for the new airport of Heraklion in Kasteli area is starting at the end of 2017.


=== Highway network ===
European route E75 runs through the city and connects Heraklion with the three other major cities of Crete: Agios Nikolaos, Chania, and Rethymno.


=== Public transit ===

Urban buses serving the city, with 39 different routes. Intercity buses connects Heraklion to many major destinations in Crete.


=== Railway ===
From 1922 to 1937, there was a working industrial railway, which connected the Koules in Heraklion to Xiropotamos for the construction of the harbor.
A study from the year 2000 investigated the feasibility of two tram lines in Heraklion. The first line would link the Stadium to the airport, and the second the center of Heraklion and Knossos.  No approval has yet been given for this proposal.
In the summer of 2007, at the Congress of Cretan emigrants, held in Heraklion, two qualified engineers, George Nathenas (from Gonies, Malevizi Province) and Vassilis Economopoulos, recommended the development of a railway line in Crete, linking Chania, Rethymno and Heraklion, with a total journey time of 50 minutes (30 minutes between Heraklion and Rethymno, 20 minutes from Chania to Rethymno) and with provision for extensions to Kissamos, Kastelli Pediados (for the planned new airport), and Agios Nikolaos. No plans exist for implementing this idea.


== Climate ==
Heraklion has a hot-summer-Mediterranean climate (Csa in the Köppen climate classification). Summers are warm to hot and dry with clear skies. Dry hot days are often relieved by seasonal breezes. Winters are very mild with moderate rain. Because Heraklion is further south than Athens, it has a warmer climate during winter but cooler during summer because of the Aegean sea. The maximum temperature during the summer period is usually not more than 28 - 30 °C (Athens normal maximum temperature is about 6 °C higher). The minimum temperature record is -0.2 °C
A new temperature record for February was set at 27.8 °C, reached on 15 February 2016.


== Colleges, universities, libraries, and research centers ==
University of Crete
Hellenic Mediterranean University (HMU)  (Former TEI)
 MBS College
Foundation for Research & Technology - Hellas
Nicolas Kitsikis Library
Vikelaia Library https://web.archive.org/web/20140605051225/http://www.heraklion.gr/en/municipality/vikelaia


== Culture ==


=== Museums ===
Heraklion Archaeological Museum
Cretaquarium
Historical Museum of Crete
Natural History Museum
The Battle of Crete and National Resistance Museum
Nikos Kazantzakis Museum
Lychnostatis Open Air Museum
Collection of Agia Aikaterini of Sinai
Museum of Visual Arts


=== Arts ===
The Cultural and Conference Center of Heraklion is a centre for the performing arts.


=== Sports ===
The city is home to several sports clubs. Most notably, Heraklion hosts OFI and Ergotelis, two football clubs with earlier presence in the Greek Superleague, the top tier of the Greek football league system. Furthermore, the city is the headquarters of the Heraklion Football Clubs Association, which administers football in the entire region. Other notable sport clubs include Iraklio B.C. (basketball), Atsalenios (football) and Irodotos (football) in the suburbs of Atsalenio and Nea Alikarnassos respectively.


=== Famous natives ===

Heraklion has been the home town of some of Greece's most significant people, including the novelist Nikos Kazantzakis (best known for Zorba the Greek), the poet and Nobel Prize winner Odysseas Elytis and the world-famous painter Domenicos Theotokopoulos (El Greco).

text.quote: This neoclassic building features the art & history of Crete, plus a library & cafe with a terrace.
trip: Nice place if you want to indulge into Cretean history and past even while you are on holiday at a special place

Good overview of the history of Crete after the Romans, detailing the many occupations, as well as the 1923 Lausanne treaty forcing all Muslims to leave, as well as taking in many Armenian refugees. All periods are documented with well displayed objects, from the early

The first room contains an excellent summary of the major stages in Cretan and Heraklion history, while the other rooms contain exhibits from these different periods. A great way to contextualize the rest of the city and country during your stay.

This is a great museum and has a lot to show you about Crete. I have appreciated the history of the island a lot more and been able to piece it together since visiting. The displays are well laid out and vary from Byzantine times through to the Venetians and the Ottomans. There

The history of Crete is so varied and influenced by so many other cultures it is amazing they could display it so succinctly in one building. Well worth a morning (or afternoon) of your time - it takes at least 3 hours to do it justice

Many excellent items of historical interest, some of which must be almost priceless. Well laid out on 4 levels, each level presenting a period of Cretian history. There is a modern lift for those who cannot manage stairs. The museum is an easy 15 minute walk from the port
Great to see early El Greco paintings. Pity the rest of the displays aren't up to a high standard, But got us out of high winds for an hour.

This museum covers the history of Heraklion starting after the events covered in the Archeological Museum. There are several floors the oldest on the Ground floor and the WWII and pos WWII maths on the top floor. There is also a l cafe with a choice of seating area with a
It's a very great resume of the Cretan, especially Heraklion-Candia area history, beginning with the Byzantine period
There was a lot of information about modern Cretan history and the courtyard cafe was very pleasant.

Small museum packing a big punch. Short sharp exposure to Crete's varied history presented in a clear concise way. Very well curated and laid out. Perfect museum for when you are in holiday as it is not overwhelming as every room holds your interest. WWII exhibit really makes

The museum is in a neoclassical building and a dedicated stop on the hop on hop of train tour of Heraklion . 17 centuries of local history and culture and early Cretan life is wonderfully depicted.There is a very interesting depiction of world war and Crete ‘s bombardment and

The history of Heraklion is at your feet in the HMC... The museum documents and reveals the city's turbulent past from the first Byzantine period to World War II. Look out for: - 4x4m model of the city of Heraklion-Chandax in the mid 17th century. - El Greco's paintings. -

This lovely museum is well set out and easy to follow in half a day. It’s a real jewel showing all aspects of the island’s turbulent history and houses Crete’s only two El Greco paintings. And there’s a good cafe with a shady garden. If you visit before 1.3.2020 be sure to see
I loved this gem of a museum. It covers the history of Crete from the 4th century AD through World War II. Well worth the visit!
Extremely nterestng place to vet, well lad out & helpful / imformative staff. Cafe is also fantastic for lunch and a beer which we had in the tranquil garden.

This museum covers the historical period of Crete - where the archeological museum dealt with mostly the prehistoric period. Earlier that day, we had gone to the Venetian fortress. This musem explained how Crete was the crossroads of the world in early times and often a place

If you have a few hours to spare it is well worth a visit to the Historical museum. It is jam packed with amazing pieces of Crete’s history from ancient times to the modern. Tip, it is also close to the Mare Coffee Bar, an excellent place for a quick bite or full on feed.
This is one of the best curated collections of artefacts I have seen. From the amazing model of the town to the more recent history, every artefact was beautifully displayed and explained in detail.

Good to spend an hour or so waling around. Sets out the history if Crete, with a focus on the various wars of the century's. Section on world war two was very interesting. Reasonably priced at 5euro for adults and 3euro for students. Free bag lockers. There is a small cafe

Obviously the big drawing card in Heraclion is the Archeological Museum, which you should visit prior to Knossos. But don't ignore this museum, which illustrates the more recent history of Crete, from about the 4th century till WWII. It is a small museum, but well laid out and

The historical Museum Crete is very informative and a good choice. They have a small gift shop but there is a good selection of things to purchase.There are quite a few floors to see, I like the Byzantine pieces and the Ottoman Turks.
More of a recent-era focus gives this museum less urgency then the Archaeological one, but it does provide an interesting local perspective.

This is a small museum and very interesting to look around and to learn about the history and traditions of Crete. It wasn’t very busy when we were there so this enabled us to take our time and chat about the exhibits. The staff were excellent and all very helpful, they seemed

Local historical museums are usually a bit much - a few cases full of dusty rubbish, a stuffed animal or two and some donated household antiques. This place was thus a pleasant surprise. It’s very comprehensive and well laid out, the displays are excellent, the graphics and

When one is tired of looking at prehistoric pottery, take a break and see what’s been going on in Crete over the last 1000 years. Beautifully laid out, informative and visitor-friendly, with a nice little rooftop café when you need a break. Their icon collection is first-rate,

This is a small museum but delivers a world-class, very polished presentation of Crete's history from Roman times up to the modern day. The evolution of Heraklion and surrounding towns is well explained through artefacts, interactive displays, art and video and is in excellent

The small museum stands on the seafront and is over three floors Each room is well laid out and often in a unique manner to the other rooms The first room gives an overview of the 300 to 1690 with a fantastic interactive map of the old city and its important buildings The
To learn about the heart and soul of Heraklion, its rich history, and all the ups and downs that make it the most populous city on the island, this museum is a must.

I enjoyed this museum. It costs 5€ to visit. The staff was nice And willing to answer questions. There were a lot of children on tours with what I assume are their teachers which was nice to see. There are some old pieces that when combined with everything in the museum is meant

This is not a huge museum but it is a very good one, beginning with an extensive and intensive history of Crete (which is complicated and important to know the outlines of in order to understand the exhibits). Every room is carefully planned, and the variety of exhibits is

This museum chronicles Crete's more recent history, from the Roman period to the current time. Exhibits are arranged logically with good English text and it is easy to wind up through each floor to different periods and themes. There are various maps, models, artefacts, textiles

There are bigger and more famous attractions in Heraklion but if I doubt if there’s one that’s more welcoming. We were greeted at the door and received friendly and informative service throughout from collection attendants and cafe staff. The museum itself is well structured and
They have a great job in this museum. In the winter time, the first Sunday of every month is free. I can recommend the cafe inside as well, with a great brunch at the weekends.

Visited here as a group of 9 with friends and children. On entrance staff were rude and not very open to the childrens enthusiasm to learn and understand the cretan culture. Staff were abrupt and not open to questions, children were expected to walk around with their hands by

The museum is well presented, and covers a huge historical range, giving a good overview of Cretan history. We found that it probably tries to cover too much, and that parts, such as the Second World War section, left us wanting more.
You get a nicely arranged presentation of the history of Crete, which differs from the rest of Greece. All texts are also in English.

Fantastic museum. It preserves the artistic, historical and natural artifacts and exhibits them to the public. You can see from the demonstrations and exhibits the different historical phase of local history throughout the centuries. From the Venetian era to modern times and the

Worthwhile visiting this Museum its not as busy as the Archeogical museum of Crete but still has lots of really ancient artifacts. There is a very small coffee shoo on the upper tier but not a very good selection of snacks. 5 euro each and you can spend an hour or two learning
I enjoy going to the museum but this museum surprised me. They historical museum have also modern art exhibits that was amazing!

My teenage son and i spent about an hour in this museum-€5 admission for me and free for him. We were especially interested in the permanent exhibition exploring and effectively describing Crete’s role in WW2. The museum is very close to the Venetian fort and bus station down

One of the best museums I have ever visited. It may be small but what you see is amazing. Everything is well displayed with too many exhibits in cases that you can see all sides. It does worth the visit.
Historical museum of Crete is located near the city center, on a walking distance and it's hosted on an amazing building. Tons of items on display, lovely choice!

Interesting little museum located on the front of Heraklion. Cheap entrance fee and takes a good hour to look around everything. Really enjoyed it and doing it very interesting. Would highly recommend

We weren't sure whether to go to the Historical Museum after the excellent Archaeological Museum but were so glad we did. Everything is extremely well displayed with excellent information boards (in English as well as Greek) and the museum has clearly benefited hugely from its

We spent a couple of hours learning something of Crete’s history. The exhibits were well set out in modern surroundings within reasonable walking distance of the port. There is small entrance charge, but a visit is recommended.

This museum is excellent. The history of Crete is so well explained and interesting. The large models of the city are fascinating and the whole display and collection is so well put together. I have been several times to see it and brought others also. It is also near the nice

This museum shows you what the island of Crete has gone through in the past 600 years or so. Numerous countries have ruled over it and through those times blood has been shed. There are religious paintings, pottery ,coins, weapons and a section on the Crete way of life, all to

Worth the time. The museum takes you from BC right through to post WWII. Set out in chronological order so helps put all the ancient timelines into perspective. Very well set out and the very good interpretation signage.

The historical museum is easy to miss but inside there are some intetesting exhibits. The best is definitely the world war 2 exhibit. Very informative. Probably took an hour to see and there are quite a few steps. There was also a sculpture exhibit on when I visited which was
Don't try to rush your visit to this excellent museum. We started mid-morning, went out to lunch, and then returned to complete our visit.

An excellent introduction to the history of Crete from the end of the Romans to end of World War 2. Well labelled in Greek and English, spread over 4 floors. The section on World War 2 was particularly interesting, and there is a beautiful collection of Byzantine sculpture. The

Entry was 5 euros which was just right for the hour or so it took to walk around. The museum has lots of very interesting exhibits, our favourite was the exhibit on the second world war. We were quite suprised how much was squeezed into small space. I think this museum is well

We only had time for one museum and decided on this one rather than the archaeological museum as it covered more of the islands history. There is plenty to see and learn here, from ancient times to WWII and Crete's interesting political history. A bit dry so may not be ideal for

A €5 entry to this museum was just about right for just over an hour it took to walk around. I liked the way that it was laid out in chronological order and allowed you to appreciate how life and history has changed on Crete over the last 2000 years. For me the modern history

Again, a really interesting place to visit to learn more about Cretans and their way of life, from ancient times to the current day. There is also a fascinating section on how they coped during WWII and a good exhibition on Nikolas Kanzantzakis

The history of Crete spans the millennia starting from Minoan prehistoric times to which the Archaeological Museum is devoted. But what happened in Crete later? This museum offers a panorama of Cretan history from circa 330 (early Byzantium) to the WWII Battle of Crete. It

This was worth the 10min walk from the main bus station, along the sea front. 5 euro entrance fee, there are toilets near reception and free lockers to leave bags in. Staff were very friendly. Its well laid out over several floors with clean displays in both English & Greek.

A small but very well curated and interesting museum that takes you through the history of Crete from historical times up through the 20th century and WWII. There was just the right amount of information so you are never overwhelmed. A great little museum that everyone with any

I suspect most tourists think of this as 'the other' museum in Iraklion, but this little gem has beautiful icons, a fantastic exhibit on the city as Venetian Candia, as well as art and coats of arms and een a room dedicated to the island's role in the Greek War of Independence.

An extremely interesting mueum which manages to pack a lot into a small place and it's really worth visiting for an overview of Cretan history. Particularly poignant is the story of Cretan suffering under the constant invasions and its assimilation of these invaders although

The Museum presents a variety of historical topics: classical (of course), but also continues the timeline of Crete with displays about the Venetian Heraklion (great model), Byzantine influence and folk customs. Of particular interest was the exhibit on Crete during World War

We visited this Museum today and spent 2 hours going round. It contained everything including historical and cultural, from traditions to a thought provoking section on World War II. The staff were wonderful and helpful, access was good and toilet facilities spotless. Wheelchair

The World War 2 floor detailing the German invasion and occupation was particularly interesting. The museum is well laid out and arranged. The model of the ancient city on the ground floor is well done. Free for children 12 and under. It's good value.

This is worth to visit place, because you will get quite easily information about the history of Crete. The museum is planned well: in the first room are different eras of the history, later more detailed information. The challenge of the island has been to be situated between
It was very info , i would like to see again when i get the chance it is worth to visit all the historical sites it will open your mnt
Very good museum. Very beautiful Greek National costumes and historical items. Large Knossos model, interesting coins. Very enjoyable!

Quite a modern museum, compared to others in Crete. Tasteful presentation of objects. It's a large museum, but they don't go on and on with half a million different pot shards like some other museums we've visited. They show you their top pieces and move on to the next bit, so

Spent a very enjoyable morning in this very well laid out museum. I felt I learned a lot about the history of Crete, and found some of the exhibits very poignant. Also loved the El Grecos, which I was not expecting! Highly recommended.

Not a large Museum, so you can take your time. Good overview of the later periods of Crete, up to the Second World War. Some fine exhibits, and I particularly enjoyed the account of the kidnap of the German General by the British, with the help of the Cretan Resistance.

This museum gives a good overview of Cretan history, but has some flaws. The museum is modern, and many of the displays are quite interesting. Sometimes, however, events are poorly explained. For example, there are repeated references to a "holocaust" at the Arkadi monastery,
I was interested and impressed with the local Cretan displays, but particularly with the displays of the War of Independence and the Second World War.

This museum is all about Crete's often turbulent history from BC to post WW2. Laid out over 4 floors with unique e exhibitions. Really enjoyed the relu2gious icons set against low lighting and black back drops. 5€ to get in and well worth it. Cafe on 1st floor v nice esp

From the 4th century AD onward to World War II, this museum picks up where Heraklion's archaeological museum stops. It has a wealth of artifacts and exhibits, most with well-written information, also in English. I was especially impressed with the exhibits on the third floor,

The museum is worth visiting while the exhibitions vary from.time to time. Wonderfull balcony for coffees with a view. The best thing during summer " live music in the museum's garden" usually wonderful and the ticket includes the museum visit

A modern museum full of interesting artefacts and information about Crete. From early days through to the awful occupation during WWII and up to date. There is a wonderful collection of religious icons, worth a look if only for the artistry, along with a collection of modern art

We visited Heraklion for the day, my 11 year old daughter is mad for history. I was surprised when she asked to look around the museum, but I'm glad she did. Some of the artefacts that are on display from centuries ago is amazing. All the displays have explanations in Greek and

We took our 4 year old here and read out the information for her. She was so intrigued with everything. There was do much to see. We got there 40 minutes before closing so the lady at the desk allowed us to go in for only 3€ each. We managed to do all the floors in the time we

Along with the archeological museum, it beautifully unfolds the enormous history and culture of this small land. I found the WWII area particularly moving as it awakens memories of our very recent history.

The section on the island's history includes an interesting series of maps showing the various powers that controlled the island at various times.The section on Heraclio includes the development of the city's defensive walls, with a model of the city in the 17th C that allows
It was a fascinating experience. Really enjoyed our visit to the museum. Very informative, staff was helpful too.

The museum is located near Heraklion town center. It's kind of hidden. In fact, we almost walked past it. However, at 5 euros I have stepped into the past and learned everything about the history of Crete. Literally, I mean everything. From the history, to the island's culture,
After you visit here, then walk over to the castle. It relates closely to the maps and information you see at this museum. The museum also has temporary exhibits.
Not as elaborate as the Archaeological museum but still an enjoyable viisit. There are several floors and one holds the Battle of Crete collection from WW2

This museum is only a 5 minute walk from Heraklion's 'main drag' but I found it quite poorly sign-posted. Entry is €5pp and includes a guide leaflet in your own language. The museum is deceptively large and is light & airy. It takes you on a journey from Crete's early

If you're into educating yourself whilst on holiday, this is a great place to do so. Its give a great overview of the history of the island through various exhibits that take you through major time periods. Great way to spend a few hours and gain a greater understanding of the
If you're a history buff or into Greek history, this should be a place you visit. I studied Anthropology, my boyfriend studied history, so this was right up our allies.
We spent nearly 2 hours to see the museum. There are a lot of nice collection which help us understand more about history of this country 4000 year old of culture and life..

Of particular interest to me were the plans of Chania (now Iraklion) during the C17th siege by the Ottomans, which was one of the longest sieges in history. other than that there are several nice pieces including an inscription on Hebrew, a beautiful example of a wedding bread,

starting with an interactive room(hint: touch the button and look at the lighting behind you) that reviews a little history and how the town is laid out to the review of Greek culture and private donations, Why would a young woman wear a dagger in her belt? Visit to find the

Takes you through Crete's history from prehistoric times and the various occupations of Turkey and Venice.An excellent exhibition relating to the battle of Crete and the German occupation in World War II, with most boards in Greek and English and with some English recordings. 3

Very well organised ;get somebody to explain all these historical rooms from different centuries up and down instead of doing the round visit yourself ;or join an organised tour of the museum you will understand the greek /creatan history ;beautiful statues etc

My highlight was to see two paintings by El Greco, up close. The baptism on Jesus Christ was smaller than I had expected but beautiful. The rest of the museum was well laid out and had enough variety to hold my attention. The model of the city of Heraklion was particularly

This is a smaller museum which shows a few objects and painting from the more recent social and political history of Crete including World War two. It deploys different techniques including installations of offices donated to the museum and contains a painting by el Greco

Wow I really enjoyed visiting this museum...I am so glad I went here on my last day in Crete. This is must do if you are into history. The museum is laid out very well, with clear markings on how to move from one room to another so that you follow the timeline. Two hours flew

By the harbour with free street parking, this was excellent value, and a way of finding out what happened post-Minoan civilsation. There is a chronological account plus some interesting galleries on specific topics. Nice cafe, adequate loos.

The historical museum of Crete is located in downtown Heraklion in a 17th Century building just across the street from the ocean. It is walking distance from the Venetian Fort. It is small, but fabulous. It covers the Minoans, Ottomans, the Venetians, WWII, and there is a

The entry price was only €5 so I decided to give it a shot. It was like a standard European museum. If you want to learn more about the history of Crete it worth the visit, if you are not that bothered just go to the archaeological museum.
Worth going to more than once as it has an excellent display of objects from 1AD to the present day with particular emphasis on WWII, Nikos Katzanzakis, and a superb collection of icons.

My wife and I spent two hours at the Historical Museum of Crete getting a crash course in the complex cultural and political history of the island after roughly 1000 AD. The collection covers the successive foreign regimes that dominated the island until its unification with

The museum is compact but is a wonderful orientation to the history of Crete, including culture and archaeological finds. I find museums tiring after 45 minutes or so and this one has a great courtyard on the second floor where one can sit and recharge in fresh air (and a bottle
This museum is well worth a visit. The building itself is fascinating and the displays are amazing in their quantity and quality.
Very interesting history museum of Crete. From ancient times through to WW2. Good narrative on each display also audio can be purchased.Worth a visit

We visited here back in October 2016 and it was a cloudy day when we visited Heraklion. We intended to go for the Archaeological Museum; when it started raining and so we opted for the Historical Museum which was nearby. Being very fond of history I know a little about Crete in

This was a very well laid out museum covering the sweep of the history of this old town. All the mediums for explaining what happened and when were. Some of the religious items were gorgeous. The building was small but itbwas bursting with information. The staff were clearly

Small but informative museum on history of Crete. We didn't use the audio guide, but the panels on the wall are offer plenty of narrative. The interactive model of Heraklion in 1645 is enlightening and helpful for situating yourself - discovering the history in the

This has a well presented display of the history of Crete right through the ages from ancient through Byzantine, Venetian, Ottoman, modern Greek until the end of WW2. The only museum in town to treat the battle against Germany to 1945. A lot of thought and expense has gone into

A very interesting exposition with special artefacts. You can feel a history of Crete and see a lot of household items. It is reaaly important place to understant the Island and Greece as they are now.

A small museum on the seafront but with tons of information and exhibits. The occupation of Crete in WW2 was astonishing and a whole room is dedicated to telling personal stories! Over three thousand years of history tttofid out about!

After walking down the seafront I came across this museum. The €5 entrance fee was more than worth it. The museum tells the entire story of Crete, and what a story it is. I spent around an hour and a half wandering around this small but well stocked museum. If you have an hour

We loved this. The early Byzantine collection is excellent, and the ikons are superb. Don't miss the Second World War material, which is incredibly moving and well told in people's own voices. And the shop has some. Extraordinary memoirs in Greek and English. Definitely worth a
i recommend it!! you should try visiting it! If you love greek history there are plenty of things to see!

Cretan history from early Christian era onwards. Delightful engaging walk through history with displays, video, and wonderful collections of Byzantine artifacts, fragments of wall paintings, icons and relics. History on display and explained in English up to second World War. I

The Historic Museum of Crete is perhaps one of the most interesting sights of Heraklion. It is located near the Cathedral of Saint Peter and offers a beautiful view of the Cretan sea. In front of each visitor's eyes lie relics signifying the various periods of the Cretan
World class small museum with an engaging staff. Allocate more time than you originally planned because it gets better & better as you move through the exhibits.

This is a rather small museum, nevertheless it hosts some gems like the sacrifices by both Greek and Jewish population of the island during the 2WW Labels are in English too and there's appropriate music in each hall. Their cafe is small and friendly. There interesting items for

I was really impressed by this small in size museum. Located in an old mansion near the sea, the Historical Museum provides a good insight to Cretan culture and civilization after the Minoan era. Two early El Greco paintings are displayed there, the only ones in Crete. The WW2
We learnt a lot about Crete and we could have spent longer than the 2 hours. It has a nice cafe and you can sit outside.
Very interesting place where the visitor can travel in historical past in this place and feel the advancement of this local civilization

We were happy that we had enough time to see one more museum. Though this museum can not match the Archealogical Museum, it gives insight to the Creten Society evolution and its culture. It is really a shame that there were only a couple of paintings of the famous master El
This museum has well displayed exhibits from all periods of Creten life, up to the 2nd world war. Also a good exhibition of icons

Well worth a visit. A good display and information about what happened on this island during the 2nd World War. I particularly enjoyed the area which showed the layout of homes prior to 1960 with an explanation as to how they were built and how they have been expanded. A good

On the othrt side of town in front of hotel Xenia is this museum, there are byzantin conglomeration of Venetian and turkish periods, and christian periods; a reproduction of an cretian farmerhouse; also a room of the cretian author Nikos Kazantzakis.

From the moment we walked i we felt very welcome an unusual experience in a museum but that is the Cretan way. The receptionist explained where everything was how to use the av equipment-the displays were excellent especially the WW11 display showing the privations the Cretan
A bit out of the way!! When we located it was to late. We were told that it was worthwhile, so we will keep it for next trip.

This museum starts with a large, well-done wooden model of Heraklion which is an excellent orientation to the layout of the city and its landmarks from various eras. From there you can walk through the nicely-presented Cretan historical periods from the Byzantine to Venetian to
Well laid out and housed in a beautiful building, this museum has something of interest to all the family.
A lot of pots and urns. Interesting statues really good as divided into sections and era's . Good cafe friendly service and clean.
A very good museum for understanding the history of Crete from the earliest times through independence and WWII occupation. Nice little cafe with courtyard for a break.
So much to enjoy and learn about. Take time to go here. You can easily walk here and see all the fantastic history of the island.

Not extensive, but the story of the Nazi invasion during WWII, and the resistance is poignant and impressive. There is also a tribute, as well as a reproduction of the den of the well know writer, Nikos Katzinzakis.

This place fills in the blanks between the Minoan culture and today, focussing on the Cretan's free spirit and struggle for independent culture - and very well, although it's a pretty basic museum. I enjoyed this a lot more than all other historical sights or ruins in Crete, as

The price for visiting this museum is a mere 5euro and what you get for your money is amazing. The museum is beautifully laid out and impeccably clean! There are 4 floors of exhibits and plenty to see. Everything is in both English and Greek so luckily for us we were able to

I really enjoyed my visit but you need to pay attention to the handout given at the ticket desk. The room layout is not intuitive but there are some arrows on the walls to help a bit. Great collection and signs to explain everything.
Museums in Crete are far superior to other sites you might see. Make an effort to go to the museum and spend a couple hours reading everything. Truly spectacular!

At first we had trouble finding the museum and thought it was an old building/church so was disappointed when it looked like we couldn't gain access. The place really needs to be signposted better although this seemed to be a common theme throughout Herkalion. We spent a good
Housed in the mansion of an old Cretan family the museum is wonderful. Do not miss it. The exhibits are very interesting and are presented in a very appealing manner.

We spent a long time trying to get into this museum only to discover that we were at an old Catholic church that was not open to the public and was very close to the museum. A very interesting finding to us was the fact that the Jewish community was very highly thought of and
An excellent museum to get an appreciation of the history of Crete after the demise of the Minoans. We found the coverage of the second world war occupation particularly interesting.

This is a true treasure for people interested in history and civilization . Crete, an island full of memories and important contribution to history of resistance,science and courage. This museum does not only describes past but gives direction to future. A very important action

It is not expensive (5 Euros approx) and is well laid out and pleasant to wander around. As a UK visitor we found the WW2 floor with its detail of the very tough occupation and the grim battle very interesting. The museum gives a good overall picture of Cretan history from very

Easy to find museum near the harbour. This museum tells of the history of Crete and how the city of Herakleion has changed over the centuries! It isn't all old history though, the most interesting bit for me, the world war 2 history and the link to the UK through the Royal

The hardships over the ages that the Cretan people endured did not quell their fighting spirit and love of life and freedom. We visited just as a thing to do, but came out with enormous respect for the suffering and valor of the Cretan people, men and women alike.

We had an hour to spare before flight and were recommended to visit this. Wow Crete has had some history over the years and been occupied by so many differnent nations. From early settlers to World War 2 and present day. An awful lot of information packed into not a huge museum

I was not really impressed by the museum, although, it´s good compared to the rest of POI in Iraklion. It is quite small museum, unless you are really into history, it will take you a most 1 hour to see it all. They got 2 painting of El Greco there, the only 2 in Crete. Very
At €5 is not expensive and having never been to Crete before it was worth a visit. The bit about the second world war and the Ottoman occupation was interesting.
A really interesting museum which is very well laid out and whose staff are very helpful. Well wirth a visit
A must see if you have any interest in the history of Crete from Roman times forward! Way better than I imagined. Very modern and all exhibits in both Greek and English. What a gem!

I spent quite some time there as I wanted to understand the various Cretan historical periods, not just the Minoan period. You learn everything about the invasions by the Venetians, the Turks, the Italians and Germans in WWII, the "Cretan Question" and you find yourself admiring
A variety of exhibits on different floors made this a journey through time including recent history..A lot to see.I saw the el Greco paintings there two(2).Very fascinating.
My wife and I will be visiting the historical museum of Crete for the second time. To check all the details and read all descriptions take more than 2 hours. And it's worth it.

This picks up from where the archaeological museum finishes (so you won't get to see really old stuff) and I genuinely thought it was fascinating. The recent history of Crete explains the people- years of suppression at the hand of the Venetians but mostly the Turks and the
A nice informative, modern museum which shows the more recent history of Crete. I enjoyed the WW2 section the most. Entry cost €5.
I would definitely recommend this one, there is a great selection of cretan history there. The room full of coins was the highlight for me. It also has some original El Greco paintings

Lovely aircontioned museum giving a real insight into the history of Crete. Set over 5 floor there are both lifts and stairs. There is also a small coffee bar, storage for your bags and a small entrance fee. Each room depicts a different period and it flows from ancient
My father features in the Cretan resistance section. It was so good to see. It was easy to find. The curator was delighted to meet my brother and me.

My girlfriend and I visited this along with the archeology museum in the same day. The historical museum focuses on Crete and Heraklion. Took us about an hour to walk through it and we were taking our time. 5e in and an audio tour is available which I recommend. They also give
We so enjoyed our visit and all for €5! It is a cliche but there really is something for everyone here.
Great museum well played out fascinating artifacts. Very helpful and courteous staff. Small cafe serving snacks not too expensive.

After going through the first two rooms, I half expected my visit to be somewhat of a fiasco. The first room includes a number of interesting, but not very well-commented pieces, mainly with reference to Heraklion (the miniature model of old Heraklion is nice to follow against a
Demonstrates visually the various stages of Cretes development into a part of Greece. A lift is available as it is spread over 3 floors. Of particular interest to WW2.

Smaller museum but good continuance from Archeological Museum. Great display on development of Heraklion with Roman, Venetian, Arab, Greek and Ottoman control and conflicts and the key characters involved. Could have spent a couple of hours but didn't realised it closed at 5pm.
Really enjoyed learning about the history of Crete in this well thought out museum, so well worth a wonder down the sea front if in Heraklion for the day.

This is a delightful museum full of interesting facts and images and items which help you understand the history and the people of Crete. It is well laid out, easy to read in Greek and English, and it has a delightful café for that mid-visit coffee and snack - or some home made

This museum is a nice little treat.. . ..for 5 euros you get a quick overview of the history of this amazing island. It has been the site of an advanced early civilization and many conquerors. We enjoyed it and used the audio guide (3 euros). We would recommend so you can get
Varied collection of interesting things, not too big. Has a lift and small coffee shop, Enjoyed visit.

We went there with my girlfriend and we are not really that kind of people who are interested in museums and so on just we wanted to know more about the Crete and actually i really enjoyed time there, everything is so modern and interesting. Ticket is just 5€ per person so have

This museum tells the history of Crete, from ancient times through World War II. Fortunately, since the other sites in town cover the ancient history well (Palace of Knossos and Heraklion Archaeological Museum), the focus here is more on the A.D. period: Roman, Arab, Byzantine,

A quick look was all we had time - and legs - for so I won't say much, except that I'll come back and do it justice next time. There's more than one floor and it's stuffed with interesting info and exhbits, particularly about more recent history. Can you do it in a day along

It is my second time in the museum. Very good and rich expositions. Liked a lot the Venetian era expositions. The WW2 exposition is very interesting and exciting. The folklore exposition is lovely and inspiring. Recommended.
As a museum professional, I can really recommend this museum to all visitors, it is really interestingly laid out, good labelling and wonderful artefacts.
Very interesting museum.You can see how the town of Heraklion was during the previous centuries.You see things about the battle of Crete and Nikos Kazantzakis.

It is one of those visits that make you feel like traveling is indeed worth it. The Historical Museum of Crete is a fine building that houses Cretan history since the Byzantine times. The setting of its collections is what is special about it, constrasting history and tradition

Mixed quality of description notes, generally well set out artefacts. Audio guides of poor quality generally, with less information than the written descriptions, Very good exhibition on Crete and World War II and very good folklore exhibits. The Portolakis exhibition of icons

This is a very interesting museum that covers the history of Crete all the way up to WW2. What is different about this museum is that many artefacts are not kept inside glass cabinets but out so you can literally touch some of them, many of the artefacts that are not kept behind
This deals mainly with history rather than Archaeology and goes tight up to 2nd World War. Ran out of time as we had to catch our flight!
Was very interesting and educational to see and hear all about Creete history. Learned a lot about the previous eras.

This place mainly tells the political story of the last 500 years or so of Crete. Most people probably wouldn't be that terribly interested. It does cover the German invasion and the founding of Greece and describes the Turkish involvement. Very good for what it is.

Somewhat tardis like mush bigger on the inside, I expected archaeological focus but it is very varied. Met a guide who explained to my son how to use the traditional knives of Crete, my son (a black belt) enjoyed the demonstration. Would recommend

This privately endowed Museum in Herakleon is a housed in a former private residence with a later modern extension. It follows the history of Crete from prehistoric times through the Venetian occupation and latterly the traumatic second World War. At the time of my visit

This museum features Byzantine art, information on the many rebellions in Crete, the history of Crete itself and Its prized paintings by El Greco. It took me just under 2 hours to go through and it is well laid out and easy to follow Crete through the ages.

a great museum for the history of Heraklion and Crete. It is impressive to see the plenthy of civilizations that passed from Crete. Maybe not the most impressive miseum but realy great if you spent the nesesary time and take the audio guided tour.

I particularly wanted to look at the El Greco painting of St Catherine's monastery and the WW2 display. These thoroughly lived up to my expectations and the rest of the museum was excellent definitely worth a visit.

The museum is housed in a lovely old building along the renovated waterfront and can easily be combined with a walk along the port, which is a must do. I found the exhibits of the various occupations interesting, as well as the replica of Nikos Kazantzakis' study and collection

Very interesting information on the many occupations of Crete. Only thing we struggled with was the English translated information was in a dark gold/brown on a black background, so difficult to read. The Greek was white on black, would be better if both could be the same.

The original goal of those founding the Historical Museum of Crete or Historical Museum in Heraklion was to collect and preserve valuable archaeological, ethnographic and historical material deriving from the medieval and modern periods in Cretan history. The same approach also
We spent a lovely morning at this museum. Check out the upper floor to see a reproduction of a home, as well as cooking items and clothing. The WWII exhibit was also fascinating.
different sort of exhibits than the archeology museum but also well worth a visit and a wander through to see more of the actual life of the ages gone by.

Interesting display on the history of Crete through the ages. Lots of information and well displayed. 2 small paintings by El Greco on display. Lots of icons, Byzantine art, local folk costumes. Easy to spend nearly 2 hours there.

Some museums really can, to many people, be dry and hard going - that is never the situation at Heraklion. The exhibits are well presented, the explanations are well written and your interest will be held from start to the finish of your visit

You find this along the seafront not far from the Natural History museum. It deals with the city history and not the Minoan/Roman past at the archeological museum. Has regular special exhibitions. Small but good shop

This interactive museum is a must visit. I usually got bored with museums after 60 minutes or so but here we spent over two hours getting an education about Cretan history. The compact building set over four floors and was interesting on every level. A visit not to be missed.

This museum was tacked on to the end of our tour of the palace at Knossos. We were happy with the experience at the Knossos site, but this museum, freshly renovated now, really allowed the palace, the history and culture of Crete to all come alive and remain in our memories

A very modern museum in an old building on the waterfront of Heraklion. Small fee to enter. Very interesting exhibits, many interactive. Gives good chronological history of the people of Crete from ancient times to the turmoil of World War II.

It was in our plan visiting this museum during the hot hours of the day. Completing our morning schedule, we went to the Historical Museum of Crete. It is hundred meters from Heraklion Fortress.In front of the Museum you can enjoy a see view were you can have a nice time after
Took about an hour and a half in the museum. Good overview of the history of Crete, especially the world war 2 part. Only 5 euro to enter.

I didn't expect much from this museum. However, this is an excellent museum encompassing Crete's history from early times through World War II. The displays are excellent, many of them using small video presentations. We spent well over an hour there. Well worth your time, for a

I am not really a museum person but we really enjoyed this one. Allow yourself an hour and a half to enjoy this... the people that work here are really knowledgable and happy to answer all your questions.

I loved this museum! it is one of the best museums i have ever seen! The museum has a lot of rooms, each room containing a different collection. At the entrance you get a map which guides you to visit every room so you can learn Cretes history in a logival order. There are a
We enjoyed this museum very much, as it did a great of explaining the history of Crete (and in English!). Some of the murals and artifacts are really beautiful.

The collection is in each room different, and therefore constantly interesting. The restaurant had possibilities for sitting inside or outside. To sit in the sun or in the shadow. I had a marvelous view on the sea, Heraklion Port. The food was excellent!
So well laid out, it is like walking through a time portal. Incredible amount of artifacts to see and learn about. We "popped in" for a look and spent a couple of hours here.
It was the best of all the museums we visited. The self-guided tour was very explanatory. Only point i would like to add is that sometimes we need to look to find the numbers to put on the device.

I went both to the archaeological and the historical museum and I must say this one was more fun. While not as impressive, it hosted a more diverse collection and we managed to get a better story through the audio guides (which the archaeological museum lacked). Crete's history
Nice museum about Crete history in some floors. Crete history insight from Minoan times from World war 2. No dislikes.

A wonderfull place to see exhibits for cretan and ancient greek history, interesting artifacts from minoan period. A look to civilization and culture of cretans and greek. If you visit this museum during the summer you should check the amazing night events on the back yard of

Nice little museum, and relatively accessible for the disabled (elevator to second floor level 2A, but there are still a few stairs to climb to level 2B). Great ground floor display, however, although in Greek and English the English is faint and rather hard for my older eyes to
I like wrap up, the summary of the history of this incredible island. That complete well the visit of the archeological museum.

I believe the original History Museum was located opposite this but is currently under renovation - (There are ruins that have bridges over them). The museum itself doesn't look like one, so you may miss it and there's some sections which are still under renovation. Adults are
Stunning exhibits well presented definitely somewhere to spend a couple of hours to get a break from the heat. Helpful staff, nice cafe and shop.

Really interesting, well assembled and displayed collection. An absolute must if you are in Crete, everything you would expect to see is here and some unusual surprises. Everything is labelled in English and an English audio guide is available.

Impressive time about the history and the past times. Gave me a good feeling what has happened during the last several thousands of years. Descriptions in Greek and English . Even when there were hundreds of visitors I never felt stressed or disturbed by any noise . Good times

We visited the museum after visiting Knossos. The museum is very well laid out with excellent exhibitions and is well worth a visit. There are also information about each of the cabinets etc in English as well and our guide from Knossos accompanied us and explained displays in

Another great museum in Heraklion just a short walk from the natural history museum. This was little more adult than the natural history museum but just enough to keep the kids interested. A very interesting history of the island from early times through to the occupation and

Can miss this museum if you don't have the time. Rather visit the Heraklion Archaeological museum and spend more time there. The El Greco paintings were nothing great. Other than that nothing of significance.

I have to admit I was expecting dusty displays .... I was very surprised by the interactive exhibition introducing history of Crete. Pity there was not more detailed intro of the history after ww2. I recommend to borrow the audio guide which has more details and the period music
a lovely place.Friendly staff.Very clean and tidy place.Very interesting for people who read History.

Very close to the center small museum showing history of the area, what I found unexpectedly a good collection of hand guns, some of them made in USA which I’ve never seen before in any museum I’ve visited

A lovely well laid out museum filled with a variety on interesting items. The staff are very helpful. This is a museum where you are allowed to photograph the exhibits. Not to be missed when visiting Heraklion, just a short walk along the coast road from the bus station and port.
Surprisingly good collection of stuff on several floors. very reasonable at five euros and easy to find.

Very educational place. When i readed reviews, i noticed that lot of ratings and feedback wasn't actually from this museum. Suomeksi vielä Ihmiset kun ei näköjään erota arvosteluissaan argeologista ja historiallista museota toisistaan... Historiallisessa museossa on pääasissa

I figured that if I was in the island of Crete, I could probably benefit from learning something about it. I had low expectations of a small museum with a bunch of pots, or old trinkets in glass cases. Boy, did this museum exceed my expectations! Perhaps because we also rented

We spent a couple of hours in the museum which covered the history of Crete and its various conquerors through to the second world war. Walking round also gave us a couple hours respite from the sun and we finished our visit with a coffee served under the trees in the garden
Excellent small museum in an attractive building with friendly staff. Easy to get around, displays well presented .
Good exhibits. Lovely and cool inside. And there is a wooden model of Knossos which helps make some sense of its form. Easy to get to from bus station 1.

Goodness. Where to begin. This place is such a veritable feast that it requires more than one visit, From the plethora of sculptures to the quaint exhibits from Cretan villages, the museum delights the eyes. My absolute favourites were the pieces of Byzantine art, some of which
Liked the El Grecos, the exhibition about Kazanztakis (author of Zorba the Greek), and the stories fromn WW2. Not a single mention of the Greek Colonels and their reign of terror though.

The antedote to all the Cretan 'tourist' history that concentrates on Minoan Crete to the exclusion of all the rest. Gives a great insight into the complex history of Crete, one not to be missed. Well worth the entrance fee.

It is an excellent idea to have a detailed museum of non-minoan history of Crete, and this museum has great collection of artifacts, however it fails to present them properly. The main problem is that the audioguide is extremely basic, and is very close to just reading the label
From the knossos palace to the museum passing by all the sight seeing hot spots you will have a nice time and do not forget to taste the most famous local sweet the (boughatza) you will like it...

This lovely, little museum offers 2 El Grecos (native Cretan), history of Crete, library and films of author, Nikos Kazantzakis (Zorba the Greek, Last Tempation of Christ, among many others), art of Crete and a very interesting history of Crete in each of the World Wars--the

We love history museums and had high hopes for this one, which is a private collection. Some of the displays were interesting (e.g. WWI period) but the museum was scattered over several different floors and rooms and we believe the price was high for the content displayed. We

This museum has history going back a 1,000 years. Laid out over 4 floors, it starts with the first recorded history of the Island and continues up until World War 2. It was well laid out with all of the information in English. This museum does not appear to have a large number
This museum is operated by a private foundation and is better managed than state funded institutions. Well presented and informative displays and a couple of early El Grecos.

This Museum covers a long history dating back to the Byzantine, Medieval, going through the Ottoman, 19th Century and WWII Eras. Touring the Museum makes you feel as living in each of these Eras through Pottery and Miniature Sculptures, Photos, Paintings and Icons, Books and
Very interesting history of Crete with various artefacts. To be visited. Unfortunatley, the two El Greco's paintings weren't visible due to work in progress.

This is a much smaller museum compared to the Archaeological Museum of Crete. It had some interesting artifacts, but not as exciting as the stuff in the Archaeological museum. If I could only go to one museum on Crete, it would be the Archaeological Museum.
Great museum - very well curated with beautiful displays and ample information in English. A must-see when you visit Crete!

after 10 days in Greece/Crete, it's nice to get the basics about history of Crete. This museum does it nicely, clearly presented and quite complete. It does not take long to visit though, don't expect too much (yet you can find the 2 remaining El Greco painting)
Great experience. Especially suitable for those interested in Greek history up to Second World War. But not really a place were children would be interested.

For only 5 Euro, this museum is good value. There is a fair bit to see covering both ancient and modern history and there was enough English descriptions to understand the displays. The service was great. The gentleman at the entrance counter was very helpful and spent some
Crete has been invaded so many times! The museum covers in great detail the struggle of this island for its independence and the sacrifices of it people.

The museum is full of Greece history, lots of information from the past. We went with our two daughters which cost only 10€. It wasn't really much for the youngest however still a must see if you love Crete.

This is an interesting museum, that highlights the history of Crete in the C.E.(common era or the antiquated term A.D.). The WW II was an eye-opener for me, as I did not know the history of that time for Crete. It is well worth a visit to learn about Crete.

This beautiful small museum on four levels is well worth the visit: you will follow the history of Crete from ancient to modern times, realising that due to its locations, various "invaders" consequently added a unique richness to this island. A couple of paintings by El Greco &

I did know what to expect, especially because Imthought all museums were "historical", but I enjoyed my visit very much. I think the diversity of exhibits and the tremendous span of time covered from ancient history to modern times made this museum special and quite

This small, private museum has two early works of "El Greco", who grew up in Heraklion. Their exhibit on World War II is particularly interesting. They tell their story quite differently than British accounts.
if you want to know what else has been happening in Crete after the Minoan civilization, than this is the museum for you. it is near the Venetian city wall, so it is easy to find.

The exhibits of this museum date back to the Byzantine and medieval periods. On display there are also relics from the Cretan revolutions and a collection of Cretan folklore items. I found it interesting enough and worth visiting if you want to go deeper in the Cretan culture.
The best stuff in this museum is futhest upstairs. Worth seeing the folk costumes and the stuff about WW2. Ground floor a bit dull.

Today i had chance to visit there. At the beggining there is a huge 3-d map of Heraklion, which i find very good.than the things come chronilogicly you can easily understand the simple history of Crete if you spend 45 minutes in there. At the end i reccomend you to drink coffee

I like to go to museums about local history. This museum is about AD forward. While it does provide a view of history from a cretan point of view it is not as good as other local history museums I have seen.

I liked best the information about Crete during the occupation during the 2nd World War and the part played by the British especially Patrick Leigh Fermoy. The historical exhibits are interesting but not as good as the Archeological Museum. There are two small El Grecos on
It is interesting museum.Presenting history of Crete.The frescos on the second floor are disapointing.On the upper floor are folklor dresses.

The museum has a good collection of exhibits illustrating the history of the island. Photography is allowed.

This museum has many interesting displays and art works from the Byzantine time to the 20th century. The latter is a display about World War II. Unfortunately more attention is given to graves of Nazi soldiers than the Jews that they deported to their deaths. In the earlier

I find that it is sometimes difficult, as a foreigner, to get a grasp on the post-classical history of Greece, because so many of the museums and featured sites are ancient. The Historical Museum of Crete is a good way to acquaint yourself with some of the history that you don't
Was a great idea to visit the historical museum. Was a great experience. I really like to go again. Was amazing. We went there with my friends and we make many photos. Was great time.

Spent an afternoon their and learned so much about Cretan history, its links to Venetian history and historical ownership are fascinating, it was 10 euros to get in and over 4 floors, if you have any interest in Cretan history, you’ll love this place.

In a building that used to be the house of Kalokerinos, a great benefactor of Heraklion the modern building attached to the classic building shows the effort to meet our history through our modern eyes. Visitors can have a look at our history and, i believe is a "must to visit"

The museum itself is not big, but very very informative. It covers the whole history of the island and we learned a lot from the trip. Great way to learn more about this beautiful place. Very helpful staff!
I had a very interesting visit in this Museum. If you have 2 hours free go there! It gives you all the history of Crete. Hope you will enjoy it as i did.

We spent some 3 hours in here, absorbing so much about ancient Crete - most of which I did not know. The displays are wonderful, the explanations so good; however, someone ought to change some of the print in English - beige text on a black background with low lighting, so bad

Clean, tidy and well laid out. Covers Cretan history comprehensively - ancient but also through to Byzantine era, Venetian, Turkish; War of Independence; and through to WW2. Also houses the Nikos Kazantzakis collection.

Enjoyed to see the place. Everything was very well organized and easy to find, not too much. The historic rewiew of El Greco was interesting and made me want to know more about this person. And the outside garden wit a cup of coffee to relax was also good. Here you can sit down
Would recommend to anybody who is in heraklion to pop in. Great collection of artifacts ! They have minoan, classic greecian and some roman pieces.
Despite the Folk Art on the second floor which was charming, this is a dull museum. It has a pleasant cafe' looking out to sea, where you can rest your legs!!

This is really small museum, situated on the sea side just next to st.Peters church. It has hot 4 floors full of historical artifacts. On the the best piece of history - a collection of ancient statues and tops of columns. At the top floor are two small rooms with 20th century
If you have interest for Crete´s history: Go to the historical museum in Heraklion. It's a little museum, but you get a good experience of Crete's history
A very nice and well-organised museum for the rich history of Crete after the ancient period, covering byzantine period, middle ages to WWII. For the ancient period see the archaeological museum.

I am not a museum bug cause the museums usually doesn't follow the demands, slow and missing concepts. However this one is really interesting, we have visited this one with my wife after the archeological museum and I can tell we didn't feel tired at all, only at the end when we
They close at 17:00 we came there at 16:30 and they asked us to . leave we examined as much as we could but it wasn't enough
Beautifully set out. Easy to follow the lay out unlike some museums where you go round in circles. Unfortunately it shut at 5pm and we had not quite seen it all.
A lot to see, from pre historic to modern day. Three floors with a nice cafe for a mid way break. Audio guides are adequate but not super informative. Good signage in English.
From ancient to modern Crete. There were exhibits on El Greco and Nikos Kazantzakis. The audio tour is a bit enjoying as you have to enter the number every time.

This was my second visit and I will definitely go again. After spending more than 3 hours it was impossible to take in more but there are still things I need to spend longer studying. The special exhibition of El Greco was very tastefully done and a friend who has been to a top
Very much focused on telling the story of Crete, right up until modern times. It seemed relatively impartial and didn't seem to have any political agenda.

Great museum , that must be visited to understand the history and the culture of Crete which is a mixture of several influences from the Minoan civilisation to the Ottomans do not miss the last floor if you are interested in getting acquainted to the traditional life in Crete

Always, when my foreign friends are visiting, I'm providing a tour toward the museums. Worthy to visit. Something different, and in a very nice plaza to spend later on your time for a coffee or a snack or lunch.
As a numismatist, I particularly liked the impressive display of Cretan coinage through the ages. I also enjoyed looking at the furniture and equipment to be found in old Cretan houses.
You will see many interesting topics and all will excite you! You must visit this Museum! You will know a lot more about Crete!

This is El-Greco Year so the museum staged an exhibition around two original paintings by Dominikos Theotokopoulos, a.k.a. El Greco recently acquired by the Municipality of Heraclion. The show focuses on the Venetian and Roman magnates who supported Theotokopoulos in his early
Full of history without being cluttered or overwhelming. A tad crowded with tour groups but able to move through without feeling pressured.

This museum is not as spectacular as the archeological museum, but still very much worth the visit, if you have some time to spare. Museum is very well laid out, has a nice atmosphere and includes archeological remains and history of Crete from the 4th century AD up to and

I suggest to visit the museum with a guide , the museum is nice but if nobody explain you something you just walk around and loo at the things,The museum has a cafeteria too we eat there the food was ok.
Well laid out and labelled items, well lit. air conditioned building. museum staff very well informed and helpful.
Not as spectacular as the archeological museum, but does tell the rest of the story of The varied history of Crete. Very interesting.
Staying on a beautiful island like Crete, one should make an effort to learn about the local history and culture. The historical museum gives this, and more. Recommended.

I wish we had a guide to explain everything. It gets very tiresome to read a lot of little plaques. Although, I did learn a great deal! The museum has a great atmosphere and connects the past and present very well.

During our travel to Heraklion two weeks ago, we visited several museums. One of them is the Historical Museum of Crete. The museum presents a collection of valuable archaeological, ethnographic and historical materials depicting the history of Crete from early Christian period
It covers quiet several periods of Cretan life and you leave with the sense that you learnt few things for the locals in the present and the past.
Modern Crete (post-renaissance) with an emphasis on El Greco and Kazantzakis. A very well presented collection with section on folk traditions and WW2.

I went here with a tour group after visiting Knossos. It was great to see the artifacts found there and learning more about Minoans. I really enjoyed the frescos, jewelry, and tombs. I am told the museum is recently renovated and it is really beautiful. It is also very English
