Just full of interesting objects and works of ancient art and history. A must see. We were fortunate to visit on National Environment day and thus the usual 6 Euros entrance fee was waived. It puts into perspective what wonderful art there was at Knossos and elsewhere on the

We had travelled through Turkey and Greece, looking at all sorts of ruins and museums, but this museum was probably the best of them all! If you have the time (maybe 2 hours?), then absolutely go and visit.

The museum is a quick and thorough introduction with photos, icons, jewelry, weavings, models and videos of the history of this much fought over island. For new visitors to Iraklio there is a large table top model of how the city looked a hundred years or so ago that is perfect

Medium-sized museum over 3 floors, but packed with information, so that I ended up spending 3 hours here. There are ancient artifacts, mosaics, clothing, jewellary, paintings, coins... Well labelled in English. Don't miss the section on WW2, but don't watch the videos if you are

If you want to find out the unique historical and cultural richness of the island, this is the perfect place to start and travel from the most ancient times to modern history. The artifacts are very well preserved, some of them also being a real joy for the eyes, such as the

Wow, that´s all. There is just so much to see on original exhibits. Idealy a guide would make this a real experiance as there are many storeys behind each item and some very important exhibits could be missed.
A museum that hosts a variety of items and themes from 400 till the liberation of Crete. very interesting and well curated in a perfect spot in Heraklion just by the waterfront
This is a very well done museum that spans the fascinating history of Crete, from ancient times to the present. Well presented, with good interpretation of exhibits.

Intelligently laid out. In many ways better than the touted but hollow archaeological museum. Don't miss Kazantzakis's study or the lovely and short essay on time in the folk exhibit on the top floor.
I really enjoyed this museum, it was so relaxing and full with interesting things to see, I definitely recommend it.
This museum is rich in history and has several objects in display. It is located near all attractions. Definitely recommend it.
We spent about 2 hours at this wonderful museum and found it highly educational about the city's and Crete's history. It was nice to have explanations in English.If you like history,don't miss it!

This museum is very well equipped if you wanna learn more about Cretan history since the middle age, it doesn't offer enough information about ancient history (and neither does Archeological Museum, by the way). Anyway, overall is an excellent place to get to know more about

This museum is very well equipped and it shows a lot of history of the Crete. Few years ago it was free entrance,now it is 5 euros. And everyone who loves history and want to learn something new must visit this museum.

text.wiki:
Heraklion or Iraklion ( hih-RAK-lee-ən; Greek: Ηράκλειο, Irákleio, pronounced [iˈraklio]) is the largest city and the administrative capital of the island of Crete and capital of Heraklion regional unit. It is the fourth largest city in Greece with a population of 211,370 (Urban Area) according to the 2011 census. The population of the municipality was 173,993.The Bronze Age palace of Knossos, also known as the Palace of Minos, is located nearby.
Heraklion was Europe's fastest growing tourism destination for 2017, according to Euromonitor, with an 11.2% growth in international arrivals. According to the ranking, Heraklion was ranked as the 20th most visited region in Europe, as the 66th area on the Planet and as the 2nd in Greece for the year 2017, with 3.2 million visitors and the 19th in Europe for 2018, with 3.4 million visitors.


== Names ==
The Arab traders from al-Andalus (Iberia) who founded the Emirate of Crete moved the island's capital from Gortyna to a new castle they called rabḍ al-ḫandaq (Arabic: ربض الخندق‎, "Castle of the Moat") in the 820s. This was hellenized as Χάνδαξ (Chándax) or Χάνδακας (Chándakas) and Latinized as Candia, which was taken into other European languages: in Italian and Latin as Candia, in French as Candie, in English as Candy, all of which could refer to the island of Crete as a whole as well as to the city alone; the Ottoman name was Kandiye.
After the Byzantine reconquest of Crete, the city was locally known as Megalo Kastro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο, 'Big Castle' in Greek) and its inhabitants were called Kastrinoi (Καστρινοί, "castle-dwellers").
The ancient name Ηράκλειον was revived in the 19th century and comes from the nearby Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles's city"), whose exact location is unknown. English usage formerly preferred the classicizing transliterations "Heraklion" or "Heraclion", but the form "Iraklion" is becoming more common.


== History ==


=== Minoan Era ===
Heraklion is close to the ruins of the palace of Knossos, which in Minoan times was the largest centre of population on Crete. Knossos had a port at the site of Heraklion (at Poros - Katsambas neighborhood) from the beginning of Early Minoan period (3500 to 2100 BC). Between 1600 and 1525 BC, the port was destroyed by a volcanic tsunami from nearby Santorini, leveling the region and covering it with ash.


=== Antiquity ===

After the fall of the Minoans, Heraklion, as well as the rest of Crete in general, fared poorly, with very little development in the area. Only with the arrival of the Romans did some construction in the area begin, yet especially early into Byzantine times the area was abound with pirates and bandits.


=== Emirate of Crete ===
The present city of Heraklion was founded in 824 by the Arabs under Abu Hafs Umar who had been expelled from Al-Andalus by Emir Al-Hakam I and had taken over the island from the Eastern Roman Empire. They built a moat around the city for protection, and named the city rabḍ al-ḫandaq (ربض الخندق, "Castle of the Moat", hellenized as Χάνδαξ, Chandax). It became the capital of the Emirate of Crete (ca. 827–961). The Saracens allowed the port to be used as a safe haven for pirates who operated against Imperial (Byzantine) shipping and raided Imperial territory around the Aegean.


=== Byzantine era ===

In 960, Byzantine forces under the command of Nikephoros Phokas, later to become Emperor, landed in Crete and attacked the city. After a prolonged siege, the city fell in March 961. The Saracen inhabitants were slaughtered, the city looted and burned to the ground. Soon rebuilt, the town remained under Byzantine control for the next 243 years.


=== Venetian era ===
 
In 1204, the city was bought by the Republic of Venice as part of a complicated political deal which involved, among other things, the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade restoring the deposed Eastern Roman Emperor Isaac II Angelus to his throne. The Venetians improved on the ditch of the city by building enormous fortifications, most of which are still in place, including a giant wall, in places up to 40 m thick, with 7 bastions, and a fortress in the harbour. Chandax was renamed Candia and became the seat of the Duke of Candia, and the Venetian administrative district of Crete became known as "Regno di Candia" (Kingdom of Candia). The city retained the name of Candia for centuries and the same name was often used to refer to the whole island of Crete as well. To secure their rule, Venetians began in 1212 to settle families from Venice on Crete. The coexistence of two different cultures and the stimulus of Italian Renaissance led to a flourishing of letters and the arts in Candia and Crete in general, that is today known as the Cretan Renaissance.


=== Ottoman era ===

During the Cretan War (1645–1669), the Ottomans besieged the city for 21 years, from 1648 to 1669, perhaps the longest siege in history. In its final phase, which lasted for 22 months, 70,000 Turks, 38,000 Cretans and slaves and 29,088 of the city's Christian defenders perished. The Ottoman army under an Albanian grand vizier, Köprülü Fazıl Ahmed Pasha conquered the city in 1669. 
Under the Ottomans, Kandiye (Ottoman Turkish قنديه) was the capital of Crete (Girit Eyâleti) until 1849, when Chania (Hanya) became the capital, and Kandiye became a sancak. In Greek, it was commonly called Megalo Castro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο 'Big Castle').
During the Ottoman period, the harbour silted up, so most shipping shifted to Chania in the west of the island.


=== Modern era ===
In 1898, the autonomous Cretan State was created, under Ottoman suzerainty, with Prince George of Greece as its High Commissioner and under international supervision. During the period of direct occupation of the island by the Great Powers (1898–1908), Candia was part of the British zone. At this time, the city was renamed "Heraklion", after the Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles' city"), whose exact location is unknown.
In 1913, with the rest of Crete, Heraklion was incorporated into the Kingdom of Greece. Heraklion became again capital of Crete in 1971, replacing Chania.


== Architecture, urban sculpture and fortifications ==

Venetian constructions such as the Koules Fortress (Castello a Mare), the ramparts and the arsenal dominate the port area.
Several sculptures, statues and busts commemorating significant events and figures of the city's and island's history, like El Greco, Vitsentzos Kornaros, Nikos Kazantzakis and Eleftherios Venizelos can be found around the city.
Many fountains of the Venetian era are preserved, such as the Bembo fountain, the Priuli fountain, Palmeti fountain, Sagredo fountain and Morosini fountain (in Lions Square).
Around the historic city center of Heraklion there are also a series of defensive walls, bastions and other fortifications which were built earlier in the Middle Ages, but were completely rebuilt by the Republic of Venice. The fortifications managed to withstand the longest siege in history for 21 years, before the city fell to the Ottomans in 1669.


== Municipality ==

The municipality Heraklion was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 5 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Gorgolainis
Heraklion
Nea Alikarnassos
Paliani
TemenosThe municipality has an area of 244.613 km2, the municipal unit 109.026 km2.


== Neighborhoods ==


== Suburbs ==


== Transportation ==


=== Port ===
Heraklion is an important shipping port and ferry dock. Travellers can take ferries and boats from Heraklion to destinations including Santorini, Ios Island, Paros, Mykonos, and Rhodes. There are direct ferries to Naxos, Karpathos, Kasos, Sitia, Anafi, Chalki and Diafani. There are also several daily ferries to Piraeus, the port of Athens in mainland Greece. The port of Heraklion was built by Sir Robert McAlpine and completed in 1928.


=== Airport ===
Heraklion International Airport, or Nikos Kazantzakis Airport is located about 5 kilometres (3 miles) east of the city. The airport is named after Heraklion native Nikos Kazantzakis, a writer and a philosopher. It is the second busiest airport of Greece after Athens International Airport, first in charter flights and the 65th busiest in Europe, because of Crete being a major holiday destination with 7.974.887 travellers in 2018 (List of the busiest airports in Europe).
In April 2018, the inner space of the airport has been modernized and expanded by almost 3.000 s.m., with 11 new gates and new stores. The expansion was a donation by Hellenic Duty Free Shops.
The airfield is shared with the 126th Combat Group of the Hellenic Air Force.
A project for the new airport of Heraklion in Kasteli area is starting at the end of 2017.


=== Highway network ===
European route E75 runs through the city and connects Heraklion with the three other major cities of Crete: Agios Nikolaos, Chania, and Rethymno.


=== Public transit ===

Urban buses serving the city, with 39 different routes. Intercity buses connects Heraklion to many major destinations in Crete.


=== Railway ===
From 1922 to 1937, there was a working industrial railway, which connected the Koules in Heraklion to Xiropotamos for the construction of the harbor.
A study from the year 2000 investigated the feasibility of two tram lines in Heraklion. The first line would link the Stadium to the airport, and the second the center of Heraklion and Knossos.  No approval has yet been given for this proposal.
In the summer of 2007, at the Congress of Cretan emigrants, held in Heraklion, two qualified engineers, George Nathenas (from Gonies, Malevizi Province) and Vassilis Economopoulos, recommended the development of a railway line in Crete, linking Chania, Rethymno and Heraklion, with a total journey time of 50 minutes (30 minutes between Heraklion and Rethymno, 20 minutes from Chania to Rethymno) and with provision for extensions to Kissamos, Kastelli Pediados (for the planned new airport), and Agios Nikolaos. No plans exist for implementing this idea.


== Climate ==
Heraklion has a hot-summer-Mediterranean climate (Csa in the Köppen climate classification). Summers are warm to hot and dry with clear skies. Dry hot days are often relieved by seasonal breezes. Winters are very mild with moderate rain. Because Heraklion is further south than Athens, it has a warmer climate during winter but cooler during summer because of the Aegean sea. The maximum temperature during the summer period is usually not more than 28 - 30 °C (Athens normal maximum temperature is about 6 °C higher). The minimum temperature record is -0.2 °C
A new temperature record for February was set at 27.8 °C, reached on 15 February 2016.


== Colleges, universities, libraries, and research centers ==
University of Crete
Hellenic Mediterranean University (HMU)  (Former TEI)
 MBS College
Foundation for Research & Technology - Hellas
Nicolas Kitsikis Library
Vikelaia Library https://web.archive.org/web/20140605051225/http://www.heraklion.gr/en/municipality/vikelaia


== Culture ==


=== Museums ===
Heraklion Archaeological Museum
Cretaquarium
Historical Museum of Crete
Natural History Museum
The Battle of Crete and National Resistance Museum
Nikos Kazantzakis Museum
Lychnostatis Open Air Museum
Collection of Agia Aikaterini of Sinai
Museum of Visual Arts


=== Arts ===
The Cultural and Conference Center of Heraklion is a centre for the performing arts.


=== Sports ===
The city is home to several sports clubs. Most notably, Heraklion hosts OFI and Ergotelis, two football clubs with earlier presence in the Greek Superleague, the top tier of the Greek football league system. Furthermore, the city is the headquarters of the Heraklion Football Clubs Association, which administers football in the entire region. Other notable sport clubs include Iraklio B.C. (basketball), Atsalenios (football) and Irodotos (football) in the suburbs of Atsalenio and Nea Alikarnassos respectively.


=== Famous natives ===

Heraklion has been the home town of some of Greece's most significant people, including the novelist Nikos Kazantzakis (best known for Zorba the Greek), the poet and Nobel Prize winner Odysseas Elytis and the world-famous painter Domenicos Theotokopoulos (El Greco).


==== Literature ====
Elli Alexiou (1894–1988) author
Minás Dimákis (1913–1980) poet
Odysseas Elytis (1911–1996) Nobel awarded poet
Tess Fragoulis, Greek-Canadian author
Rea Galanaki (1947–present) author
Giritli Ali Aziz Efendi (1749–1798), author and diplomat
Nikos Kazantzakis (1883–1957) author
Pedro de Candia, (1485–1542) author and travel writer, recorded the Spanish Conquest of the Americas
Stephanos Sahlikis (1330-after 1391) poet
Lili Zografou (1922–1998) author


==== Scientists and scholars ====
Nicholas Kalliakis (1645–1707) Greek Cretan scholar and philosopher
Niccolò Comneno Papadopoli (1655–1740) lawyer, historian and librarian
Andreas Musalus (ca. 1665–1721) Greek Cretan professor of mathematics, philosopher and architectural theorist

text.quote: Former 19th-century mosque, now a Greek Orthodox church dedicated to St. Titus.
trip: Whilst walking around the old town of Heraklion, we discovered this beautiful church by "mistake", and I am really glad for that "mistake" :-). I am not at all an expert on greek orthodox churches, but I really enjoyed this church - it felt really right, on all terms. The

A nice litte church, not very impressive or architecturally special, but with a nice interior, some nice paintings and a couple of surprising views. If you are there anyway just make the short detour and visit.

It was only a quick visit to the city so we didn’t have time to explore much. This wonderful church though dominated the square where we had dinner and made for a lovely backdrop. It is right by the very popular Lion Square and the structure is beautiful. The history of this

An orthodox church in the tourist area, with a great facade. One can enter, and it has some interesting modern stained glass windows, as well as the typical iconostases. It also has a narthex where candles are burning and one can buy trinkets as well as candles.

Friday 28th August and we visited this Church situated in Agiou Titou Square, off 25 is Avgoustou, in the centre of Heraklion . A former 19th century Mosque, which explained why it did not look like a traditional Greek Church. It has a number of arched windows and entrance

This wonderful church is close to the Morosini Fountain (lion fountain). Worth a visit, especially for history buffs. Titus, also known as Titus the Apostle, lived in the first century and was a Cretan of noble birth. He was given his title probably because he was an associate

This is a building that has gone and seen through the history of the island, going through different phases of being converted from different religion and being destroyed by earthquakes. In the current state, the interior of this building is very different than it's exterior.

We visited her with friends whilst touring the area. It is a very lovely church. Very spacious inside with beautiful carvings. There was a wedding about to take place but the 'officials' still allowed us a quick visit inside. Outside they were gently trying to move on some

After Koules Fortress, we went to a pedestrian street to continue to exploring this area. There is a square on the right side facing the harbour. It is where Agios Tito's Church is located. The Church is not big nor fancy, but it has a significant historical value in this church

A very beautiful church in the center of the old town of Heraklion. Situated in a pedestraian street just next to Loggia (The Town Hall). It has a different shape (square) than the other churches, and it is really beautiful both from outside and inside.

This Church has lovely windows and very interesting internal wooden carvings. We obtained a very informative leaflet inside the Church, outlining the history of Titus, the Apostle and the history of this Church. There was a nominal fee for the leaflet, but we cannot recall the

Beautiful windows and amazing detail in the wooden carvings inside. However beware of the rude staff, we got made to leave for our dress but the sign only states to be dressed decently which we were expect he said we must cover shoulders and knees, well if you want that to

Visited the Church of St Titus, partially rebuilt ,an orthodox Greek church on the famous 25 th of August street . The skull of St Titus is kept in a silver reliquary in the church on the left once you enter . The church is in the St Titus square near shops and cafes . It’s an
When walking up or down 25 Augustou Street, Look out for Agious Titos Byzantine Church. There are two large palm trees either side of entrance. Worth viewing.
Since you are already walking through the 25th August, you have to make a stop and enter Agios Titos.
This is the nicest church in Heraklion, on my opinion. It is often crowded or with weddings. Worth a visit.
Located off Heraklion busiest pedestrian shopping area this church became a mosque then a church again depending on who ruled Crete. Its spacious provides some welcome peace.
I encourage you to read the Apostle Paul's letter to Titus. This cathedral has a portion of Titus' remains. And its a beautiful cathedral. Must see in Heraklion..on the entire island of Crete.
We stayed near the Agios Titos Church, during daytime the dome is white and nighttime is blue which is beautiful. The area is peaceful and safe.
The iconography in this Church is beautiful. Definitely worth a visit. If you can find a guide, it is worth it to know what you are looking at and the significance of the icons and relics.
Greek church with nothing special, in my opinion. The entrance is free so it's a good stop to relax for a while during a hot day.

Went here looking for the cathedral and soon realised it was St. Titos church, but we were not disappointed, beautifully decorated and we were made to feel welcome, don't miss the skull of St. Titos in the chapel to the left as you enter, priceless relic!

If you are in Heraklion, have a look at Aguilar Titos. It’s a church of the Eastern Orthodoxy, but it’s unusual exterior suggests it may have been modified as it has none of the usual elements associated with such an church. More of a mosque feel than a Christian church. Turns
A beautiful church, we attended the Greek Easter weekend services. Located in the heart of the old town with a beautiful courtyard
Very beautiful interior in Byzantine style, worth to go in and visit, it's also a beautiful view at night when the cupola has a blue light.

I happened to visit in a Sunday when the square in front of the church and the church itself were filled with delightful happy children ... It’s beautiful inside, quite calming, very humbling and moving! I lit a candle for my late daughter and thought that if there were a God,

Agios Minas Cathedral is a Greek Orthodox Cathedral in the city of Heraklion. Ιt is dedicated to Saint Menas the martyr (285-309 A.D.), who was the patron saint of Heraklion. The church is of the cruciform type with a dome based on a high spandrel. Internally there are elements
Very beautiful church next to the shopping centre. Deserves a short visit. Sometimes gypsy, not Greek beggars are outside asking for money. I ignore them.
Τhe most beautiful historical church in the city that explains who built it when it was built with amazing view and cafeterias across the street

We didn’t get to enter but we took a few pictures from the outside and read a bit of its background from the signage. It looks quite majestic. And from the side there is a small garden, that would be a nice picture spot too with the church in the background. If you’re on the
This Church is full of history and the main Church in Heraklion. It is well cared for, quiet,and a place fro meditation. It is easy to find and well worth a visit.

Very pretty Greek orthodox church, right in the center streets of Heraklion, Crete. It is a great place to visit, and spend a few moments admiring its wonderful paintings in silence. The Church is used for masses, so visits have to be very respectful and non-disturbing. If you
Every church has its own voice and so does this one so it always good to go and rest awhile and contemplate. Thankyou.

My wife and I were here on a Globus tour, though this was part of cruise ship tour itself. We were on our own in Knossos, wandering thru the town, seeing the 'downtown' and Morosini Fountain, City Hall, Basilica of St. Mark ... The Church itself was small, but beautiful

If you are walking from the waterfront, this church is located on the left hand side of 25 Augustou Street, as you head toward the Loggia and the Lions Fountain. If it is open, take a step inside and look around.

St Titus church is next door to the Loggia and only a few yards from the Lion fountain. It is well worth a visit to see the stained glass which casts a warm glow. Many of the interior walls are white, which makes the interior very bright, unlike many other Greek Orthodox

This church has the relics of Titus, companion of St. Paul, and first bishop of Crete. The church is in typical Byzantine style. The service was beautiful and the clergy was very welcoming. Upon entering the church, do not miss the side chapel on the left, which houses the
We found it by chance as we were wandering around.... really beautiful inside and there is a small chapel with the skull of St Titos..... There is a sign on the door saying ‘no shorts’.

This church has a long history and was a bit of a surprise find while visiting Heraklion. Since the original church was remodelled by muslims the church displays some features usually found in mosques, which make it very interesting. The icons and the wood carvings are truly
Well worth it is it when you’re in Heraklion . Centrally located and always open until 9 PM. Gorgeous stained glass and iconography.

A lovely peaceful building when we visited in the evening. A final resting place for the skull of St Titus, repatriated from Venice in 1966. The church spent a few centuries as a mosque during the ottoman occupation.

Agios Titos Church is a Greek Orthodox church just a few blocks up the road from the harbor. A bustling market area with shoppes, restaurants, cafes and bars have grown up around this small, working church. For its size, it is elaborate and ornate inside, with pictures of saints

This church is in the centre of the old town and stands in a pleasant square. The interior is ornate and worth seeing, please note modest dress is expected and people wearing shorts are not allowed entry.

Saint Titus was the first Bishop of Crete and a follower of the Apostle Paul. The church is set in it’s own square with a few cafés / bars around the edge. It’s a working church as well as a focal point for us tourists. It’s opposite Lion Square.

This is an attractive building on 25th August Street in excellent condition. There is a good square to the front. This is an Orthodox church with the pictures of saints everywhere. In the small chapel on the left is what is purported to be Titus's skull inside a gold ornate
This is a great Orthodox church to visit if you have not alreay seen many. It does not take very long to visit, so enjoy.

This is an attractive old church on a small square on 25th August Street. Inside is typically ornate. One extra thing of interest - as you enter, to the left there's the small chapel dedicated to St Titus. In this chapel you will see his crown: Look carefully through the hole in
This was a nice church and a peaceful break from the busy streets outside. Free to enter, no shorts and conservative dress preferred.
The most beautiful church of Heraklion Special building, yard and several cafes for entertaining around the church, with space for the children to play. lovely
Lovely church worth a for a short visit if you are near by. Beautiful pictures inside the building that had a great old history.
Big church that provides food and clothes to poor and refugees at the mornings. It's on Heraklion Square.
Great church in the city centre. A nice square is just in front. Don't take a look only from the outside but take your time also for a proper visit of the inside.
Here to pray on the Tito Head relics...the addressee of Paul letters...place to be see if you arein Heraclion
This is a place of worship close to the liontarakia (Morosini's fountaun) meeting point. Nice outside, nice inside, beautifully lit outside at night.

Passed by the church while wandering treu the city. Took a picture for remembrance. Not that special, but one of the told highlights of the city. It was closed at the time so could not see the inside.

This unique orthogonal church (at least judged by Byzantine standards) is softened by the sway of palm trees planted around it. It dominates the square where is it located on August 25th pedestrian Street. Agios Titos is said to have served different roles during Crete's long
Can't say to much about this church as without sounding disrespectful they are very much all alike. Great artwork, lovely architecture, and amazing stained glass windows
The woodwork throughout the church is exceptional, and the rest of it is definitely worth stopping by.

The Agios Titos Church is a wonderful 19th century building located in a cobblestone square, right next to a paved road that leads to the Heraklion harbor. Great place to seat, relax and soak up some sun. Do not miss.

Located in the August 25th street. The church was dedicated to Agios Titos, disciple of Apostle Paul and first Bishop of Crete. During Turkisch occupation the church was turned into a Mosque. After the earthquake of 1856 it was completely destroyed and rebuilt as an Ottoman
This church sets off the architecture of the city. Beautiful and slightly set back from the path edge but easily seen. Lovely example of an old church.

This Church is really historic and has a lovely square around it to sit or have a coffee. I like to visit it often with family. It is very peaceful and a good place to get away from the madness and shops and just sit in peace.

Agios Titos is a magnificent Byzantine-era church, among the most important monuments in all Crete. The basis for this importance is the fact it was built by Emperor Nicephorus Phokas, who liberated Crete from the Arabs and made it again part of the Byzantine Empire. Returning

The unusual shape and lay-out of St Titus church results from it being converted in the early 20th c. from a mosque. It reminds us that parts of what is now Greece were not liberated from the Ottoman Empire until the late 19th c. and early 20th c. Although simple and plain by
This was my favorite renaissance building in Heraklion, great architecture and a lovely square surrounding it, with a little fountain on the side. Don't miss it.

This is an Orthodox church in a former 19th-century mosque - hence its exotic exterior appearance. It is dedicated to Saint Titus, a disciple of Apostle Paul. Titus was also the first Bishop of Crete. It is one of the most important monuments in the center of the town.
A beautiful restored church that welcomes all. Set in the heart of Heraklion it’s an escape from the bustle of the city. You may even wish to light a candle in memory of a loved one.
Pleasant church located on a small square along 25th August Street in the old town. The interior is quite plain
One of the best churches ive been in my life, religion is very important for greeks and I really respect that.

The temple of Agios Titos is an Orthodox church in Heraklion, Crete, dedicated to Saint Titus. Today's temple was built in 1869 as Yeni Mosque and in 1925 it was attributed to Christian worship. It deserves a visit to this church-monument and is located in the heart of the city.
A small church which is very nice inside. On the main tourist street. It provides a lovely break for those walking up and down.

This is noteworthy by its connection to the New Testament times via history. The church itself is not old but a remnant of the Turkish occupation. But it is of interest. It is not a classically Greek Orthodox church but has unique interest because of its more recent history.

A completely rebuilt church after the Ottoman mosque now being used as an Orthodox church but completely unorthodox from an arquitectural point of view due to this special history. The church is nice but the surroundings are nicer (a square and places to relax)

This charming church is slightly set back from 25 Augoustou Street and can't be missed as you walk about the central city. It is dedicated to Crete's first bishop, the 10th century St. Titus. The original church was destroyed in the 1856 earthquake and then built in its current

Sadly nowadays like elsewhere, a lot of these beautiful churches have to be closed unless a service is taking place. Fortunately this was open on my first visit to Heraklion. I was able to take a few moments to take in the surroundings and spent some thought in reverance.
A very interested sightseeing. A historical monument in the centre of Heraklion with a lot of touristic shops and cafes around.

A mosque converted into an Orthodox church. Nice, but nothing. A nice cube in the center of Heraklion. The most interesting thing is the iconostats: imposing. For the rest it is very modern in furnishings and decorations.
Skull of St Titus, disciple of Apostle Paul and 1st bishop of Crete, is kept in a silver reliquary. Quite moving witnessing elder Greeks' devotion. Extraordinary wood carvings to decor.

Attractive on the outside this church isn't that old now (although it has a very rich history since it was originally thought to have been built around 960AD). However, it was destroyed completely by an earthquake in 1856 and then re-built. It is in a nice part of the town near
Ah I just love old churches like that. The weather was awful but I couldn't stop looking at it, I think rain made it look even better.
We found this church quite interesting. The relics of Saint Titus were moved to Venice when the city fall to the Turks and recently the skull of the Saint has been returned here.

We came across this lovely church by chance, situated off the main street in a quiet square. As we approached I thought it was a mosque. It had indeed been one during the Turkish occupation , but is now dedicated to St Titus. Fabulously adorned with beautiful icons, richly

This church is a stop on the pedestrian walkway. It was a nice spot to take a quiet moment and reflect. Stainglass windows were beautiful. There was no fee charged although Donations were much appreciated. Hung in the middle of the sanctuary is an intricately carved wood
Situated in a nice square this little church is rather nice inside and well worth a look. It has a nice ceiling and is usually quiet.

We stumbled upon this church on our way back to our hotel and it was like an oasis. Absolutely beautifully adorned, as all Greek churches are, but with a sense of peace and tranquility. I lit a candle and felt very grateful to be there.
A pretty church, particularly at night You would need to be respectfully dressed (no shorts) before entering.
We've seen the church only from outside as it was a busy day and had a ceremony inside, but it looks beautiful.

Part of a day trip and worth a visit if you are a Christian. Very tranquil place. Nuns very welcoming giving orange juice and sweet cake . The history fantastic and I really enjoyed looking at and praying to the picture of out lady of perpetual succour. Dress modestly for visit

This is a must for all those who are religious Christians and wish to visit holy places of great saints, like St Titos, the companion of the Apostle, St Paul. Even if you are not religious, this is a beautiful church to behold. Magnificent windows - the colours are spectacular!
Worth visiting this church is so beautiful it's worth to visit it the priests are very loveable and very helpful
In a lovely square away from the crowds it has an interesting history and benches to rest on and take in the peacefulness.

If you're a catholic then this must be an incredible experience. It's a beautiful church with a private area to view the Titus relic. Even for someone who wasn't Catholic or even religious, to be so close to a relic so closely related to bible scripture and see the effect on
A beautifull church in the center of the city. You can't miss it if you go for a walk. The building is very nicely preserved.

I wouldn't call myself religious, but when I saw this church I was amazed. The architecture and location is fantastic. You have to be dressed respectfully when entering. The church is, apparently, the only Catholic Church on the island (so a local told me). Inside was quite

Was taken here as part of a free walking tour while in Heraklion. Having a passionate tour guide who knew the history of the church in its various incarnations over the centuries really helped me to appreciate the place which is a beautifully quiet place just metres away from

Russian lady adviced me to see church and holy relics, scull of st.Titos,nice soul refreshment,, church sells nice icons and suvenirs, all near shoping street .first bishop of Crete and Poul most trusted companion from gospels.
Really beautiful church ⛪ very large scale, clean square outside worth a visit for sure, and of course take picture outside
Amazing venecian architecture of five separate churches in one. Unique atmosphere for praying and meditation.
Stumbled onto this church. reminded me very much of the Venetian churches, beautiful wall art. drop in and light a candle.
Famous for St. Titus' skull being buried in the church. There are also some frescoes. It is still very much in use today.
Beautiful Old Large Icons, very Large Chandeliers. It is interesting to see the architecture of the church. Easy to find when walking the touristic road of the 25th of August Street.

very beautiful inside and out! take note though you won't be spending much time there, its one of those "let me take the quick photo and i'll be on my way" not a lot to learn or take in other than the beautiful architecture!
Simple church not old while you are there you can go for free you ll feel the peace go set and have some relax as we did .

The cathedral is an Orthodox church, after its renovation in 1925 but it has a long history.It is found on August 25th street, one of the busiest streets of the town.Around the temple there are all sorts of shops,tavernas,gast foods and coffee shops.The original church of Agios
It's hard to understand why certain places like this, located in cities with temperatures above 30ºC, insist to deny the access to people in shorts...
Very calming in the midst of a chaotic city. The interior is a wonder, gold, stained glass windows beautiful. Free admission, with a peaceful little resting place to the rear.
Agios Titos- church of Saint Titus. Place in the city. It is easy to find it. Remember is church- wear suitable clothes there (arms and knees covered).
Stop and see. This is an absolutely beautiful Orthodox Greek Church. Frescos galore! As someone not religious, I could really appreciate this church.

The Church of St Titus is unusual, yet beautiful and reminds me very much of a mosque. I didn't go inside but imagine it is as lovely inside as other Greek Orthodox Churches I had the pleasure of visiting whilst in Crete.

This church is relatively new and renovated. The inside, although the paintings look like they are from a distant art period, they were painted only 150 years ago. The church is in beautiful condition. The best part was when a little old lady helped our little daughter light a

To be able to pray before the skull of St Titus was quite something. The church was well kept, centrally located and mantained a prayerful atmosphere. Would definitely visit again if I ever returned to Heraklion.
Beautiful church in the centre of Heraklion. Lovely courtyard at the side gave a cool and restful place to sit.
The church is a nice, quiet, cool reprieve from the busy street you need to walk up to see it. There are impressive icons and the architectural details are quite interesting.
We visited the church recently whilst having a look round Heraklion very beautiful building with a lot of fine detail and craftsmanship inside.
Stunning building. You are asked to dress appropriately before entering. Just off of one of the Main Streets of the city.
It's very sparse inside and to be fair I preferred the little Catholic Church in the back street but this is a beautiful building and worth going to.The icons are exquisite.
Just a few steps away from the tourist trap is this beautiful church where it was relaxing and enjoyable just to sit and contemplate. Everything was beautifully maintained.

The Titos Church is located in the heart of Heraklion center near the famous shopping street. The building looks very nice and has a dominant place on the beautifull plakas of downtown. In this area you find very good restaurants too.
On 25 August Street-formerly used as Byzantine church,then a Turkish mosque, and finally restored in 1925 as Greek Orthodox Church. The interior is lovely!

Nice church both inside and out. I had a tour guide so it was interesting to hear about the paintings/history of religion too. Really lovely building too. Benches outside to sit and relax, and lots of cafes/restaurants/shops around.
A real landmark, and a place to visit especially if you like history , religion and culture !! Agios Titos is the patron saint of the city of Heraklion.

This church has quite a history, having been a Byzantine temple, a Catholic Church and a mosque in its previous life. The exterior is fairly plain and boxy but has a kind of elegance and balance. The interior is just lovely, small but colorful. The stained glass is not elaborate
We visited Agios Titos church last August. It is a majestic church. It is situated very close to the city center of Heraklion a hundred meters away from Lion;s square

If you are on a cruise ship and decide to stroll around the city, maybe do a little shopping, then you will probably happen along to see St. Titus Church in the busy shopping area. From the outside, it does not appear to be an over abundantly fancy structure. Do go inside and

St. Titus was the founder of Christanity in largely Orthodox Greece. Indiscreet, but pretty place of worship in the center of Hrraklion is worth a short visit while you're touring the city...many tavernas nearby to enjoy a snack or coffee.

Saint Titos is a church located in the center of Heraklion city and is devoted to the Apostle Saint Titus, a student of Saint Paul and the founder of the Christian Church of Crete. It is a wonderful architectural monument, as it possesses elements of Venetian influence along

the most beautifull church of Heraklion, possible of Crete, totally different of the Greek Ortodox churches! in the centre of the town anyone can vist it! rebuilted and renovated many times since 961 when the first church of saint Titus was established!
During Christmas holidays of 2016, the Church of Agios Titos in Heraklion was honored to be the host of the presents by the 3 Wise Men to Jesus Christ !
Very beautiful church in the centre of Heraclio. In the night is much better as the coloured windows is wonderful.
The Agios Titos Church is definitely the jewel of Iraklio. As it is placed at the center of the city, it is a place you cannot really miss.

The lovely square in front of the church is pedestrian, and many children enjoy playing there. I only saw the church from outside, but my little boy attended the service in the evening and he was very moved. I will definitely join him next time we visit Heraklion.
Beautiful, glowing at night. And a real live skull inside! Can't ask for more, in the middle of town and free.
Walk in this beautiful church,light a candle and say a little prayer.It is a cathedral after all! A survivor never the less
This is not a very old church as previous churches on the site have been destroyed by earthquakes. Pleasant enough for 10 minutes.

We were walking in the area & came across this church which I had previously heard about. We went inside mostly because we had heard that the skull of Titus (New Testament) is supposed to be there. It is a nice looking church but not as elaborate as many others in Europe.
This was well-worth seeing while in Heraklion. There was no staff so the "no shorts" policy was not really enforced. It was less decorated than the Greek Orthodox churches we saw around.

In the city center next to the Loggia (Heraklion's city hall) there is the most beatiful church of the city. An iconic area with an atmospheric square full of cafes and popular shops. Visiting during the afternoons of Friday and weekends you may be lucky and see a greek wedding
A worthwhile trip to Agios . The road in very good conditions. The scenery very nice.. A lot of history at the site.

First things first, in that church you can find the most important relic on Crete, I guess, i.e. the skull of st. Titus. The skull is kept in a golden chalice, in a special place. In other words, it shouldn't be possible for you not to find it. Also, the interior design of that
The church is very beautiful inside and was part of our tour from the cruise ship. We paid 85 Euros for 3 and a half hours tour 4 people.
The Agios Titos Church or St Agios Titos Church is in the centre of Heraklion and has much history.We found the church to be beautiful!
This church on one of the main squares is frequently open for a quick visit. Interesting stained glass windows and iconostasis. Free, or put a small donation in the box.
This is a lovely church to visit - in the alcove to the left of the front entrance is a silver reliquary containing the skull of St Titus who wrote one of the letters in the New Testament.

Agios Nikolaos to Heraklion by bus Because Crete is such a large island (640 miles of coastline) organised excursions or boat trips can be prohibitively expensive, exclude admission prices and often adhere to similar, strict timetables. So, when you visit the sites, they are
Fantastic church inside and out. Worth the visit if only to get through the main door. The interior is unbelievable too.
We found the church to be beautiful. Lots of gold leaf in the paintings but not too over-awing. Well worth seeing, even if not religious - we felt quite comfortable there.

The Agios Titos Church or St Agios Titos Church is in the centre of Heraklion and has much history. There is an ancient relic there. When you enter the church, turn left into the separate room. In front of you on the right is the relic of the skull of St Titos. In 961,

We visited Heraklion on 25 August and as we passed there was a band playing outside the church for a ceremony, which attracted our attention. When we returned later, we went inside the church. The signs indicated that the skull of St Titus, a Cretan and one of the first non-Jews

Well worth a visit to see the stunning interior of this church. Beautiful wall and ceiling painting.

This was a surprise. The Church is over 1000 years old but it has a very updated and well organized self guided tour. Old Churches tend to run together when traveling extensively in Europe but this one stands out.

Half-way up August 25th Street is the Agios Titos Church. It was built in 961 AD by Emperor Nicephorus Phoas, who liberated Crete from the Arabs. The church was built by the Byzantines and later remodeled as a Catholic church by the Venetians. When the Turks took over it

when we visited the church was open , my mum is greek orthodox so we went in and paid our respects to all the saints, and we saw the beautifull interior of this lovely church , we also paid a donation and lit a candle for loved ones past , and we had a peice of holy bread, it
A lovely church on route to the port - we didn't go in but that was because we were on a guided tour to the town and port
the Church is in the center of Heraklion and near the harbour it is beautiful and near the church there are many restaurants and shops for tourists
Heraklion is not the attractive part of the crete.. This church is one of the few to see. Very well preserved and clean.
Beautiful interior, everything wooden, with lots of paintings and icons. An astonishing chandelier and a nice place to rest from the sun and meditate or pray

The church was mostly dark and we could not see the stained glass windows and lots of other stuff. That was quite disappointing because there is also a skull of "Saint Titus" sitting on a desk and special other church features.
No entrance fee but a small church ; in the centre of Heraklion with interesting icons ;well looked after;

Unassuming from the exterior, Agios Titos is quite a beautiful church. There are icons everywhere, some of them portraying some unique Cretan events and saints. We were lucky enough to visit on the feastday of St. Titus, so the reliquary had been moved out into the middle of the
Very intersting building to visit whilst you are taking in the rest of the capital. easy to find. walk round all the in a I is easy t miss some of the art.

A truly beautiful building in an eclectic style echoing the byzantine, venetian and ottoman past of Heraklion. Situated in an attractive square it offers aesthetic pleasure and an escape from the busy city centre.

We stumbled upon this in old town Heraklion and were struck by the architecture, which is unusual for Greek Orthodox churches. Inside is a treasure trove of icons and other religious relics from many different centuries. It is a gorgeous church and a very active one with
Part of history, one of the nice parts. The city cites many historical buildings. The church also has a very nice interior decoration.

Had a quick visit to the church and was glad I did, it is beautiful! It was intriguing to observe Greek Orthodox visitors and the way in which they interact with the religious artifacts. Please remember to dress appropriately, my wife always carries a shawl to cover her

A beautiful church inside and out. Wish we had more time to explore it. I was not dressed appropriately so we were only able to pop our heads in (as a woman, if you like to visit churches its a good idea to have a shawl a scarf to cover yourself - the greek orthodox church is
If you visit Heraklio without visiting Agios Titos church, it will be like haven't been visiting this city. Spend some time sitting in silence, into the main building. Make a gift to yourself.

On arriving by local bus at Heraklion bus terminus my wife and I thought that it was a fairly quiet area until we found the hidden town centre , bustling with shops eateries architecture in abundance including this stunning building which has been cleaned and renovated it forms

It was definitely not as decorated as the Cathedral. If you are into churches or of that religion, probably of more interest. You could easily pass on it though. Although again, everything here is in the downtown are so takes 2 min. to stop in and see it.
The Church of Agios Titos (Saint Titus) is well worth the visit. There is magnificent carved wood, many beautiful icons, splendid brass chandeliers.
attractive Greek Orthodox church-has the skull of Titus on display in a side room. Great woodwork and detail in the building. Nice historic stop.
Walking around the city of Iraklion I saw this church.Very beautiful from outside and inside...I liked it.
It is a beautiful Greek Orthodox church. We visited it during our walking tour of the city. Nice painting and the overall design of the church from inside. Really liked it!

Strolling around the shops and bars we stumbled across the beautiful Church. Not really dressed correctly we sheepishly popped our heads in. The sound of prayers being sung greeted us... It was captivating. You must look inside here and catch a few minutes of peace and

It is a beautiful Great Greek Orthodox church. We visited it during our walking tour of the city. Nice icons, painting and the overall design of the church from inside. Don't need to spend long time there!
Definitely a Greek Orthodox church- the artwork and paintings are all on the slightly violent side. Beautiful- although you don't need more than about 15 minutes.
Church with the skull of the apostel Titus. If the door is open, just walk in and see and walk out... Not a musthave on your bucketlist ;)

Great Greek Orthodox church. Dedicated to St Titus apostle. We loved the woodwork inside as well as the overall design and layout. We visited it during our self guided walking tour of the city. Don't miss it!

We were recommended to see this church but it was locked up so could only view from outside. Not very impressive.
In the middle of Heraklion, you can find the Agio Titos Church, beautiful Byzantine designs, peaceful place for pray, amazing architecture.... i loved it very much.
This church, located in the center of Heraklion, shows typical characteristics of Greek church. Look at stained glass, holy pictures, candles, and altar carefully !

For those searching to find a sacred and peaceful pause in their travels, a brief (or not so brief) visit to this church is definitely an option. With its religious ambiance and its housing of relics, it's a nice place to visit.
Surrounded by unique cafes this church is easy to find. Much to observe once you are inside. Look up as well as outside and around. A very inviting church where serenity will be found.

The big feature of this church is the head (respectfully encased in gold) of St Titus. A very nice interior and quite simple in comparison to the Cathedral nearby. Calm and quiet.

Once you got to the center of Crete, you will find this nice Church on a small plaza, by the time we pas they were having mass, so we can only see it from the entrance. very nice church, worth the visit.

Orthodox Beauty indeed in the middle of Heraklion as you walk to the main streets and boulevards. Once you enter you will be touch by its spirituality and beauty. A place worth visiting, taking some pictures and showing respect in absolute silence.
I'm not actually into churches but this is a beautiful building I just watched it from the outside but i'm sure you can go inside and even attend a service.

Visited Agios Titos on a day of walking around the city. The church itself is a great monument located in the center of Heraklion. The wall painting of Saints represent religious stories. It is probably the oldest church in Heraklion since the 10th centure. 100% worth visiting.

Right in the center of the city, only a short walk away from the Lions Fountain square and the preserved Lotzia (now municipality of Heraclion) is this old very well preserved church with a great history & a nice architecture both outside & inside.
We came across it by accident and went inside. It has a lovely altar and front of the church with carvings and plenty of stained glass and some lovely paintings. it is a very lovely church

Took a trip down the Heraklion when staying in Agia Pelagia on holiday. The church is in a nice square in the town centre just before you reach the market. It has some lovely pictures and stain glass windows. Nice place to visit..

Very close to the center of the city of Heraklion, this church is one of the best known monuments in the area. A big square in front of it, where you can take a break eating if drinking something. The inside is very beautiful. In the night time it is litten upon with some light
Close to lion square and has a great square area in front of the church. Quite beautiful inside. Looks even more mystical at night.
Worth visiting this Church right in the centre of the hustle and bustle of the city.The patron saint of Heraklion.

Very impressive greek orthodox church with many valuable byzantine icons inside. Marble floor and beautiful vitraux. Outside is one of the most beautiful squares in Heraklion center. This is a must visit place in the city.
Nice Greek Church in the square located amongst shops restaurants and café. Well worth a visit beware of the Albanian children playing the accordian and begging for money.

Near to the city center, this church is really worth to visit. Nice architecture from outside and inside.
Very nice church with lots of icons as must of the Orthodox churchs. It's very easy to visit it in very few minutes.
Interesting architecture bothoutside and inside. Close to the city center, it is worthy to pay a visit while walking around.

Agios Titus Church is steeped in history. Although a bit drab from the outside, it is stunningly beautiful within although having Titus scull encased in gold is maybe a macabre. Well worth a visit if you are in the area.
You will find a nice and peaceful atmosphere when you leave the busy street outside and go into this traditional greek church.
It is very easy to locate as it is just on the side from the main shopping street. There are cafes outside so you can sip on a cup of coffee in a shade while admiring the beautiful architecture.
If you can, visit this also at night, when it's illuminated, and the cupola is blue. Amazong athmosphere.
It is a nice place to go to have a rest form the busy shopping street close to this church. Also interesting to see from inside.
So beautiful! Spectacular at night - looks like it was taken from a ferry tale. Both the outside and the inside make an impression.
Easy to find on the main street. Interestingly the church was converted from a mosque in 1923. Attractive interior.
We viewed this at night, beautifully lit up, quite a contrast to the busy and lively mall it is situated in.

This is certainly worth a visit if only to see the effect of light through the stained glass windows and admire the carved wooden screen and chandelier. Also it is worth taking a closer look at the icons - all of which are very interesting.
A small and cozy church... a 5 minute walk from the port. Worth a stop by when strolling down the main street (opposing the port).

Interesting church right in the centre of Heraklion. Many other churches in town including Catholic churches.

Just north of Koules fort. The church of The patron saint of Crete, the church contains his skull in a gold case. It was not returned until 1966 having been taken (along with the rest of his body) by the Venetians when the Ottomans invaded. The church is beautiful, but a little
This is a historic church that was once a Catholic Church when the Italians rules. It is close to the centre of town and is a must see when in Hiraklion
Masterpiece of architecture in heart of old city make big impress in your heart. Very nice interior with lot of iconics and inside you feel all that spiritual energy through your body.
its a pretty little church in the town centre of heraklio. one would come across it while walking around. but its not a place worth making a special trip to
Nice, a bit small church in the center of Heraklion. Definitely worth entering. There are cafes in the nearby square.

This quaint little church in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Heraklion is certainly worth the time to stop and have a look. It has beautiful stained glass windows and paintings and quite different from other churches.Dont miss seeing it.
Good collection, we did this to get out of the heat for a while and were not disappointed. Staff were very helpful.
Nice living church with no graffitti in great shape with religoius art. Worth a look on the way to the Venetian port.

They have the actual skull of St. Titus in the church in a gold case. Beautiful Orthodox church and definitely worth a stop. If you are walking from the town square to the port where the fort is located the church will be along the way.

You will come across this church walking through the hustle and bustle of Heraklion, This old Church allows for a stop to enjoy the peace, history, spiritualness and quiet. Beautiful icons and architecture. . I also recommend a stop at one of the sidewalk cafes...by the trees,

Beautiful church, resplendent with gold. Peaceful, serene building with thankfuly no cameras allowed!.wonderful place to visit.
You can get "churched" out so it takes something spectacular to get my attention; this wasn't it. I thought it was more amusing to watch a local woman eating her lunch in the pew across from me.

one of the oldest churches in Heraklion. you can see the interior of the church. you can see the remaints of the St. Titos' body, inside the church. for people from Heraklion, is one of the most important places to go and visit
Pretty church to pop your head in and see the beautiful insides. Won't take you more than a few minutes.
In Heraklion near the market. Beautiful inside with stained glass windows and detailed wood carving and murals.
The church is located in the commertial area. It is an imposing structure with interesting inside and a long history of various conqueros.

very quiet even in August and if you are lucky you get a taste of local religious celebration. beautiful cool interior you escape from the heat and just relax there

Believer or not, it's worthy to visit this old church. The square is amazing the architecture a well. You can spend your time around the plaza for a coffee or a quick snack. In case you want to do that try Pagopoieion restaurant / cafe ....
Lovely church with some great wood carvings on the iconostasis. The most interesting part is the side room wherer St. Titus' skull is housed in jewelled gold. Definitely worth a look in.
That's where othoman and byzantine religious art lives in a perfect combination. Absolutely worth visiting!
Peculiar in architecture 9once a mosque), very impressive the church of the first bishop in Crete and a disciple of saint Paul that hosts its relics. Beautiful with beautiful imagery and ambience
It's a lovely building, though the tie-rods in the arches are just a little alarming. Paintings everywhere--icons, historical scenes, decorative stenciling. The dome is quite impressive.

I just loved everything about it - the courtyard where the church is nestled amongst palms, the interior with the lovely wooden face surrounded the altar, the Byzantine art. It makes a gorgeous picture, and it's so tranquil, which contrasts with the chaotic nature of Heraklion.

Peaceful escape from the crowds - beautiful church - even witnessed a wedding at 8 pm on a Saturday evening - a lovely experience. The square outside has benches and there is a little fountain and a taverna tucked away round the side.
The fronting plaza is its most attractive feature. Pamphlets inside explain the history, including reference to the relics of St. Titus that are housed in a small chapel within the church.

Agios Titos Church is absolutely beautiful and it's a great place to visit at Heraklion. At night I usually found live Greek music being played outside of it and it was just beautiful. It's a great way to spend a part of your evening - just enjoying the amazing view and the

Whenever we visit Iraklion, we always enter the centre of the town with a stroll up the pedestrianised 25 Augoustou Street where there are several notable attractions, none more notable than the splendid Agios Titos church. It's on the left hand side as you walk up the street
google: Nice church for a short visit. There is a cosy yard behind it.
This church was amazing and beautiful! We got to experience a baptism and learned a lot about the history. We truly recommend visiting this place!
Beautiful church and larger than many. Saint Titus was a disciple of Saint Paul and the 1st church was built here ~961 CE. During Turkish rule it was a mosque called Vezir Mosque. Worth a visit.

text.wiki:
Gouves (Greek: Γούβες) is a village and former municipality in the Heraklion regional unit, Crete, Greece. Since the 2011, local government reform it is part of the municipality Hersonissos, of which it is a municipal unit. The municipal unit has an area of 94.963 km2 (36.665 sq mi). It lies around 20 km (12 mi) east of Heraklion.
Goúves is often confused with its busy summer resort, Káto Goúves. Besides this well developed tourist resort with long sandy beaches, the area has some traditional villages and archaeological sites and Eileithyia caves. West of Goúves are the tourist resorts of Kokkíni Háni (also spelled Háni Kokkíni) and Amnísos, both with similar attractions, and, to the east, Crete's largest resort, Hersonisos.
Káto Goúves, just a couple km north of the village, and is a summer resort.  There is a variety of accommodation, from large hotels to boarding houses and self-catering apartments, and there are many restaurants, bars, nightclubs, and shops.


== Villages in the Municipal Unit of Gouves ==
Villages in the area include:

Anopoli - several some minutes from Kokkini Xani village, and 5 km south in the mountains at an altitude of 205 m.
Elia Village - located 12 km southeast of Heraklion city, in the inland of Hersonissos Municipality, and just 4.5 km from Kokkini Chani village by the sea. The village is on a small hill, at an altitude of 230 m
Epano Gouves - located on the south side of Gouves village by the north side of Ederi Mountain, just 18 km east of Heraklion city and just 3 km from Gournes village.
Epano Vatheia - is located in the valley of Vatheianos Kampos, at an altitude of 260 m in the inland of Hersonissos Municipality, just 15 km southeast of Heraklion city.
Gournes - a village by the sea and located just 15 km east of Heraklion city in the Municipality of Hersonissos.
Gouves village - also known as Kato Gouves, this is a village by the sea
Haraso village - located southeast of Heraklion city just 27 km from the airport and at an altitude of 388 m, in the inland of Hersonissos Municipality just 10 km south of Gouves village.
Kalo Chorio - located just 7 km south of Gouves village and 25 km southeast of Heraklion city
Karteros Village - located by the sea just 8 km from Heraklion city and is the natural limit of Hersonissos Municipality
Kato Vatheia village - located between Vatheianos Kampos and Epano Vatheia
Kokkini Chani - a village by the sea and located just 12 km from Heraklion city.
Koksari village - located 23 km southeast of Heraklion city and just 5 km from Gouves village
Skoteino - located south of Gouves village
Vatheianos Kampos - located 13 km east of Heraklion city and borders Kokkini Chani village.


== Points of interest in Municipal Unit of Gouves ==


=== Amnisos ===
Amnísos and its long sandy beach lies about 7 km East of Heraklion city, just beside the airport and in front of the islet of Dia. There is another Minoan villa in the area dating from 1600 B.C., where some frescoes that are now in Heraklion Archaeological Museum were found.


=== CretAquarium ===
One of the largest and most modern aquariums in Europe, CretAquarium was founded and operates as part of the HCMR. It is geographically located on the north-western part of the former American Base of Gournes, where together with the premises of the research institutions of HCMR forms THALASSOKOSMOS - the largest centre for marine science and promotion of the Mediterranean sea world.


=== Dia island ===
Dia island is located 6 miles northeast of Heraklion city. it is uninhabited and the home of seabirds and species associated with coastal cliffs. It is one of the NATURA protected areas, due to its status as biotope for endemic plants. Legend has it that Dia island used to be a colossal sea creature that came close to Crete and then Zeus turned it into stone with a powerful thunderbolt, thus creating the island.


=== Eileithyia Cave ===
This cave lies 1 km inland from Amnísos. It was an important sanctuary since Neolithic times. It was dedicated to Eileithyia, a Greek goddess of fertility and childbirth of Cretan origin. The cave is rectangular, 64m long and 9-12m wide. After the entrance there is an antechamber, which leads to a rectangular room surrounded by cylindrical stalagmites which were probably worshipped by the pilgrims. At the cave's mouth there is a square, known as "The Square of Altars". This courtyard may have been used in ceremonies. The cave remained in use until late Roman times.


=== Gorge of Karteros ===
Gorge of Karteros also known as Astrakiano Faragi is located in the Municipal Unit of Gouves and can be entered by Karteros village on the southeast side. It is a hiking trail with ponds and small waterfalls.


=== Kera Eleousa Monastery ===
One of the most important monasteries in the Municipal Unit of Gouves, located near Voritsi village just some minutes away from Gouves village. A fortress type monastery with significant archaeological ruins. Visitors can see the church, the monks' cells and the yard of the monastery.


=== Minoan villa of Kokkíni Háni ===
The summer resort of Kokkíni Háni lies in Vathiano Kambo, about 13 km East of Heraklion and Northwest of Goúves. At the spot known as Nirou Háni, archaeologists found a well preserved Minoan villa dating from the New Palace period. The villa had two storeys, was about 1000 sq. meters large and had all the typical features of the Minoan architecture: two paved courts, connecting corridors, storage rooms, light wells, shrines, etc. About 40 tripods and huge double axes were found in some rooms, suggesting that the owner of the villa might have been a high priest. Like most of the Minoan buildings, the villa was destroyed by a big fire. The finds from the excavations are now displayed in the Heraklion Archaeological Museum.


=== Monastery of Saint John Theologos ===
This monastery (Agios Ioannis Theologos in Greek) lies in a verdant setting southeast of the village of Anópoli. It used to be part of the Saint George (Agios Giorgios) monastery, which is located to the North, which was abandoned following the frequent pirate raids  in the 15th and 16th centuries and all the monks moved to the monastery of Saint John. During the Ottoman occupation of Crete, the monastery hosted Cretan revolutionaries and  a secret school, something that lead the Ottomans to destroy it and kill the monks and the people of Anópoli in July 1896. The monastery was founded again some years later.


=== Skotino Cave ===

This cave, one of the largest of the hundred caves in Crete, is located high on a hill northwest of the village of Skotinó, a few kilometers inland south of Goúves. It is also known as Ayía Paraskevi cave, this name coming from the church built on top of it. The cave is 160m deep and 36m wide. The first archaeological researches on the site were done by Arthur Evans, the well-known British archaeologist who unearthed and partially restored Knossos in the early 20th century. A more comprehensive exploration was done by French and Greek archaeologists in the 1960s. They found a number of bronze and ceramic votive offerings, the oldest of them dating from the earliest Minoan periods, suggesting the cave was an important sacred shrine dedicated to a female fertility deity, possibly Britomartis. The cave was still used in Classical Greek and Roman eras, when the fertility goddess Artemis or her Roman equivalent Diana replaced the Minoan deity.

== References ==


== Bibliography ==

trip: You don't need to buy a ticket in advance, you can just come to the aquarium and buy a ticket there. It is a small aquarium so don't expect to spend hours inside. the exhibits were nice and clean. You have to wear a face mask during your visit. and sometimes it feels impossible

Their exhibits are extremely well-maintained and cleaned, and they have done a brilliant job creating a relaxing atmosphere for their visitors. The background music was calming and soothing. This is a much nicer experience compared to my recent experience with Sealife
A nice aquarium with a great variety of sea life specimens. Children will enjoy the tour, especially the big tank with the sarks. Worth every minute you spend there.

Considering how far we had to travel from Heraklion center to get to the aquarium, we were quite disappointed in the experience. The staff were very friendly and helpful, which was great. We first did the virtual reality experience, which was definitely the highlight of the
able to see vast variety of sea life. very interactive for the kids with a onsite gift shop and cafe.

We took a taxi out to see the Aquarium which is East of town. It is not large but is well laid out and interesting. It exhibits Marin slide of the Mediterranean. They also have a cafe which looked nice even though we did not eat there. It’s worth a trip.
