(Translated by Google) Awesome place :)) very informatively told about dinosaurs. There is an application on the Market that tells everything about them. Price 10 € adult, 8 € child

(Original)
Потрясающие место:)) очень познавательно …

text.wiki:
Watercity is an aquatic park in the area of Anopolis, between Hersonissos and Heraklion on Crete, Greece. It has 36 water games in 80,000 square meters.

It is a member of the World Waterpark Association (WWA).
text.quote: Standard water park with slides, a wave pool, 2 children's pools, a jacuzzi & eateries.
trip: A great experience, lots of fun; very quiet due to covid-19 so no queues for the slides. The staff were helpful, it was really clean and the rides were fun - especially the ones you go on together!
Booked in for 2 tickets to watercity and spent €60 in a taxi to get there and the place be closed ? Says on the website open , it let me book in for that day absolutely ridiculous

I've really enjoied this little parc. I think it was a good idea to get there and have some fun.. It changes from beaches and Tavernas. This time (September), there were no much people and we could do the slides looot of times! The snack choices are also good enough. Nice time

We visited here in August 2020 and we're really impressed with the park. It was really clean with lots of lifeguards looking out for your safety. Some of the food and drink is a bit pricey but that is too be expected in a place like this. It was really fun but tiring! If you

Very fair price from an exciting waterpark with a good selection of rides. No que for the rides when I went so three hours was perfect as we did all rides multiple times and chilled in the lazy river.

This water Park has some decent slides but i was expecting it to be bigger. It was 2 hours away from chania but with the amazing weather in greece we will manage to have a good time. I would say this place is nice but personally wouldn't drive that far again

We all had a brilliant time. It's the first time our son has been old enough to go on all the attractions in a park without supervision so he had an absolute blast! While we were able to relax in the sun without having to chase him around all day. The staff were all super

We were here for a day in August 2020. It was lovely as the weather was hot (obviously!) and there were hardly any queues on the rides (the pandemic kept people away). The staff were excellent and they made sure everyone sanitised their hands before getting on each ride. There
Epic rides with lots of fun for the whole family. Well kept clean with sanitising at each ride and social distancing. Overall an amazing day out and a definite recommendation.
It was great fun I can really recommend I have kids 8&9 they loved it. I found the concrete and brick floors got a bit too hot to walk on but hey ho !

What a great find this place is. Yes, we've visited during the pandamic so footfall is lower. This has meant we have pretty walked straight onto every ride without queueing. That aside, the park is spotless and very well kept. The rides are varied for all age groups. We visited

Great fun, all seemed very safe, despite Corona. Fewer people meant very little waiting time, or none at all, for the rides. No problems in upgrading (free of charge) my 7-year old to be allowed on the Level 3 (most thrilling) rides. Areas with sun beds a bit ageing, but OK.

After 5-6 hours we had enough, which is great for a couple of adults ;) Lots of variety including artificial wave and "tarzan" to the pool. We didn't try the food, quite expensive - I recommend taking your own. The price does not include the rental of a locker (4 euro + 2
Great place lots of fun for everyone. Very attractive site and good food. My teenage boys loved it I enjoyed relaxing on a sun bed and trying some of the more sedate rides.

Very different experience due to covid (no queues in August and using hand gel before every slide!) but really great fun! There are loads of slides and some of them are crazy fast! We ate there too and prices were reasonable. Would go again!

We’re a family of four, two girls age 11 and 13. Plenty of decent slides to keep both our more adventurous and less so children happy all day (we stayed all day 10:30 to 5:30). We barely queued all day for any slides, the most we did queued was less than 10 mins. Could be due to

Good quality slides that are suitable for all ages. There were not many queues for the slides even though the park was fairly busy which is good. The food is quite highly priced but this was expected. One thing that we didn’t know before arriving here was that you have to pay €4

Nothing bad to say about this waterpark! Good system to pay everything after your day (scanning-bracelet), friendly staff, waterslides very very nice, prices of food are not much and everything superclean!👌
The waterpark shows sign of age. Needs maintenance. Dirty water with paint residues in the babypool. The price level is quite high for Crete standard.
We liked very much. My son was delighted with slides. Lots of slides together. The best waterpark in Crete.

we had a wonderful day! it's a must in Crete for the families. when you are tired to visit ruins, gorges, towns, it's a great break for kids and teens, and parents really enjoy it too lol it was very fun! And it was in July 2020, so not a lot of people, and a beutiful weather.
a lot of water slides for everyone. but there are many people in the summer that makes it a bit annoying.
My family really enjoyed the day there. The weather was good for October and the place wasn't very busy which was nice.

The teenagers had lots of attractions there and had fun all day. Food was ok in the cafe. The water in the wave pool was a little cold, but we were at the end of the season and that is understandable. There were enough loungers and we enjoyed the day.

The Watercity waterpark is very nice place to spend day with kinds. Lot of attractions, nice pools and various places to take sunbath. Visited few days before closeing of the park, but all attrackions were in use. Not too much people and short lines. Very friendly staff.
Nice escape, but could be better! I think this place needs some more good rides and an extension to be in Europe's top

The waterpark is well run and clean, even on the penultimate day of the season although some staff seemed to be running two rides at once which led to a bit of confusion. A number of the rides and the wave pool and jacuzzi pool weren't working which was a little disappointing

It was a nice day for all of our family. Not many people because of end of the season and it made it even more relaxable. Me and my son visited all of attractions and he even take grandma to some of these.
After people left (who came with buses) it became a lot less crowded. The last part of the day was the best for us, because we didn't have to stay in line anymore.

There was around 10 Slides open,the 2 most "extreme" were shut all day. The potential for injury is there if you don't follow the instructions for the "games" .the food was ok but expensive ,the drinks doubly so. The slides were much the same regardless of the colour rating but

Were here in the beginning of October. There were practically no people and queues on the slopes. Due to strong wind there was no energy in the water park and thus there was no water for about an hour. Then everything started to work. Pluses: not so crowded, enough sun beds, no
Absolutely splashing experience. A bit far from hotels area but you should visit this park for having a nice day there alone or with friends

I've been to all the waterparks in Orlando and judge all others by them as the standard is high. The water is cool and not overly cold but in avg weather being 26 it's nice . As for the slides the doughnut rides are varied and offer something different for all levels of

Overall experience was good, but as an adult I would have expected more adrenaline possibilities and different slides (even tho there were many). We had a organized group visit there, which was 6 hours, we wanted to leave after 3 hours, because we had done everything 3 times

We came at around 10AM and left in the afternoon. the kids loved it, I would have loved if the little one (5Y) had more slides, there is only two small ones for him, but other then that it was really good.

There are a lot of rides for a fun day out. I would advise children over 10+ as a lot of the rides are for big kids. This was a great laugh loved the bigger rides including the red ride and yellow tube race ride. The food was average I loved the Pasta but my boyfriends burger

We booked our tickets before travelling and got a 15% discount. A taxi return from Gouves is €40. We arrived for opening at ten. Grabbed sunloungers(loads free all day)near the wave pool and purchased a locker nearby (€4). There is no cash taken in the park, you each get a wrist

Good size...not too big..easily do-able in a day....nice n clean, entrance fee a bit mean as a 1.40 meters child priced as adult...much much quieter in last two weeks of UK summer holidays as is extremely busy in June and July...online discounts..

We visited the park at the end of August with two kids age 10 and 6. We arrived late around 1.30-2pm as we took other activities first. I was hoping for some discount for half day only as somebody mentioned before late admission but unfortunately we paid full €91 plus later the

Water park has great slides and is a must do! You scan everything on your wristband (food, giftshop, drinks etc) and pay the total when you leave. Lockers are a reasonable price and the park is well kept. From Stalis it's about 40 minutes. Thought the transfer cost was

We visited here as a family of 4, booked online to take advantage of 15% off. Hotel arranged a cab for us to get there. Kids enjoyed it, yes its a bit dated but there is something for all ages, lots of sunbeds and shade. Food basic so if you don't have massive expectations you
We enjoyed it very much, it was thrilling and fun. Also we would like to give a shoutout to the beautiful lifesaver on kamikazi and the competetition slide.

Excellent day out! Rides fun, clean and kept us busy all day! Lots of sunbeds and didn't have to queue for more than 10 mins. Worth every penny! Took own lunch but had drinks there. Didn't go on any extreme level 3 slides as others fast enough for us all!

We went to the park on 21 Aug with family of 3 (2 Adults + 5 years kid. ) , we arrived around 1 pm and we only paid 40 Euro in total ( i am not sure if it is late admission discount:) ) my kid had so much fun, there are two children pool with slides and she went to 4 bigger

Myself & my husband took our 10 year old grandson on holiday to Crete, as he is a lover of water parks we didn't hesitate in taking him to water city, however, it is a large park but the rides are very far apart so we had to keep moving sun loungers, also. it was really dirty on

Great day out for the teenagers and adults alike. Clean, well run and the lines go down quick. Took a pack up as thinking the food would be expensive or limited availability. But prices where fair. Hotdogs and sandwiches were 3 -4 euros. Well worth the day out. Time flew by.

We parked our teen kids to WaterCity for a day...slapped then with money and sunscreen. On the ads, we were quite fearful of the types of slides (being as hellicopter parents)... but we relented and let them go. Thankfully the slides are engineered to slow down the rider

I've been to Watercity in July and I think It has been the best waterpark I've seen. It's very big with a huge amount of attractions which are simply amazing and extreme ! All the staff is very friendly and always ready to assist you. What I really liked is that the waiting time
water part is always a fun, but we all (adults, kids, and teenagers) had much more fun in the Aqua water park.

I wasn't there but my husband went with my family , including my teenage niece , they had a fantastic time . They did the craziest of rides and had no complaints at all. Staff were great and kept everyone safe. One slight moan was the queue for the greek food (gyros pitta etc)

We went to watercity as s family with three teenagers and found it had everything. It had a really good cashless system so everything goes in your locker at the beginning and you pay at the end. This meant our teenagers could grab a hotdog or drink when they needed and could

Watercity is a big, varied water park to the south east of Heraklion in the hills. Most, but not all, activities; slides, pools, etc. are top notch and well maintained. It doesn't come cheap however. A modest visit of 2 adults and 2 pre-teens cost us about €150. So 4 stars for

Really well organised, wide variety of rides and a spectacular view over Heraklion. Good system of paying via your wrist band so no need to carry money. Food and drink reasonably priced for this type of location. We loved it!

We got the excursion ticket from watercity website, picked up from our hotel at 9.50am and taken back at 5pm. Perfect amount of time, we went on a Thursday and it was pretty quiet, minimal queues and plenty of time to do all the slides more than once. Just to note that the

Excellent time at Water city, well worth a visit. Went with a 17, 13 and 6 year old and 2 adults. 6 year old could go on most things but obviously not the really big water shoots. Cashless system in the park makes it easy to purchase food and drink and you just pay at the end.

We were a big group, aged 8 to 78, and everyone had fun. We bought the tickets online, and really appreciated the informative email with travel instructions. A bit on the expensive side, even with a discount. A lot of great rides, and staff took the safety measures very

Visited this waterpark whilst on holiday in Crete. We booked via our accommodation and got return transport included in the price. Waterpark is on a large are, and there were plenty of sunbeds. Average rides, can not really compare o somewhere like Sian Park in Tenerife, but

Ageing park with some decent rides. Friendly staff but overpriced. Kids can ride grade 2 and 3 rides but,if they want to ride grade 1, you will have to pay an extra €8.50 taking the cost of a child’s ticket up to that of an adult. At no stage we’re we made aware of this until

Hi, After a doubt between Water City and Aqua Plus for my family with 3 children (12, 8, 2), i decided to go on Water city. Generally I think it was a right decision, however some issues i want you to consider. Pros: 1. Huge park (city....), which acc. many feedbacks is bigger

Attended the park with kids aged 10 and 6. Rides rated at levels 1, 2 and 3. 10 yr old was able to do all rides as he was taller than the 140cm required, and 6 year old levels 1 and 2. Had so much fun. Cashless system really good. Signs say the lockers are free, however they are
Great day out, good value for money, staff friendly, clean environment. Wrist band payment excellent. A safe day if you follow instructions!

We had fun here, spend approximately four hours. Not all slides fits 10 years old children. So from 10 slides that they have we could do only 7. The staff is nice. Not sure that the experience was worth the price that we payed.

We had great fun - lots of good slides and very friendly staff. My only criticism is that the slides with no inflatable rings were quite rough in places, so lots of people had sore backs. A t shirt helps. There were lots of sun loungers available and lots of shade. Queues were

Fantastic As said great organisation Get wrist band from shop for locker Just bring credit card and pay for food etc at end of stay. Kids and grandma even loved the rides! Kids got henna tattoos, reasonably priced Loved every minute!

A fantastic day out! Lots to do, very well organised, clean and relatively short queues. We booked online and got a taxi which worked well. We have a 13 yr old and 10 yr old; both had a ball, as did we. Would recommend it to all!
We had a great day at the parc, many fun attractions, although the wild river was kind of a problem (not enough water). Food is ok for a day stay..

We visited Water City on 25th July 2019. We all had a fabulous day. We have been to water parks elsewhere where we have paid significantly more money and queued an awful lot longer. We booked online with a 15% discount, kids were full price as >1.4m which meant they could go on

Nice location, beautiful views. Very crowdy, probably, because of the high season. Could be cleaner. Very long waiting time at food kiosks. Slides are cool. Together with tickets it coated 120 euro for 3 of us

We had a great day at water city. With younger kids my main concern on water slides is always safety. The lifeguards at water city are extremely safety conscious and made sure that there was only ever one person on the slides at any time. Yes,it is expensive, but you can

A big lie ! This is the truth ! The publicity is overrated and exagerated ! I have been to some waterparks in my life but this is the worst ! The prices are huge for everiyhing ! We had a horrible hot dog and the service was ...i dont know there are not rnough wotds in the

We went for a day out as a family of 5. 2 x 13 year olds are charged as adults. Cost of visit was over 100 euros to get in. So, I suppose we expect that. However, its the extra charge of 4 euros to use a locker that makes me mad. Surely, at over 100 euros to get in you should

Watercity was fantastic. Lots of slides, queues were well organised and moved quickly. There were plenty of free (unlike Majorca) rings for half the slides, free sunbeds, and reasonably priced food (€23 for 3 of us at lunch incl a beer). All in all a great day and would highly

This park is a perfect place to spend your day in family. The ticket is a little bit expensive but the prices of the food and drinks are reasonable. The toboggans are great and the atmosphere good. Really good staff.

I visited with my husband and late-teens children. Everyone enjoyed the day, seemed very quiet and no queuing for slides. I managed to get a 15% discount on admission by pre-booking tickets on their website. You get a wristband on arrival with a bar-code on it, so can use
Brilliant day out. Rides were excellent. Arrive at 10:00 as it doesn't get busy till after 12:00. Some of the staff are a touch miserable.
A great day out but it is worth arriving early and ensuring you utilize all the rides to benefit from the facilities. Very clean and not overly busy so it was even more enjoyable.
Plenty of slides, good day, but food expensive and not much to choose if you don’t like chips or burgers. Kids had a great time on all the different slides.

Went here this year for the second time, came last year too. We went slightly off peak (early July this year, early September last year) and for us the queues were small or non-existent, so lots of sliding gets done! Many sunbed areas. Me & The Boy enjoyed sliding a lot, you

We had a lovely visit to water city (once we’d found it - not easy to get to from the new road heading west towards Heraklion - use sat nav). The staff were friendly and printed our tickets bought online. We enjoyed all the slides (favourite was the Minotaur). The wave pool

slides were amazing me and my dad had a lot of fun. Only the staff at the fastfood bar where you can get burgers and fries were so unfriendly. the girl at the cashier gave me such a nasty look plus the system is so slow. Please management give you're staff there a hospitality

Nice waterpark with lots of slides for all ages. With wristband can buy from shop and snackbars (credit 100€) I would recommend to inform visitors about time. Because a lot of people come with travel agency and should exit until ex: 16:00.

Pretty good time we spent at watercity, but water is not so clean i expected for 27€ entry. Lot of rides, everyone can choose your own, no queues all day long, i was surprised. I have been there with 2,5 years old baby and no problem.
bitoutinthe sticks but a good park with enoughrides to keep most kids happy.Lockers for valuables and plenty ofsunbathe space -clean and goos food

Good waterpark with lots of fun. Kids liked it a lot, the activities are good, large number of slides, staff is friendly and has an high focus on safety. The wristband is also used to log purhases from shops and several snackbars. The payment is done when leaving - smart feature!

Second time we did this waterpark , it didn't change much and that was a good thing. We enjoyed it a lot, the layout is really well done. Grab a donut and go down the slide, simple as that. No fastpass or anything, everybody equal customer. Bought pictures here again as well.

It a hard find destination not well signed on the way but if you use navigation it drive there. You have some fine rides there it could be crowded in high season. It was also today but you havent wait more than 4 minutes for a ride. Parking is for free. We have some problems

Our 2nd visit there. A lot of fun for kids. Clean and safe. By car or transfer: it depends on. If to speak about money only then for 1-3 persons worth to order tickets+transfers from your hotel; for more people just make calculations /my calculations show that if you get a car

We we’re very disappointed. We payed 91 for 2 adults and kids of 3 and 7 years. Everything in the park is old. Everything needs renovation. Too much money for three toboggans for kids under 140 cm. Not worth of that money. Definitely never come back. Very disappointed.
Very interesting insight into traditional and current life in rural Crete with many superb exhibits, easy to find in Piskopiano and surrounded by many great shops and restaurants.

Really nice waterpark with friendly customer service and lifeguards. Bought the tickets online as there was a discount available and then called the watercity number to reserve the bus transfer seats. Just be aware that the bus transfers are 8 Euros on top of the water park

We were friends at 20s that visited the park and we did order shuttle service to the park and it was 45 minutes late to pick us up. It was also 30 min late to shuttle us back. The waterslides were poor, maybe one waterslide was good. But they did have amazing wavepool

Excellent park for our family visit. We were a mixed age group of 11 ranging from 8 to mid 40's. The rides were great, something for everyone, and we didn't have to queue long for any of them. There are some steep hills to climb to get to the top of a lot of the rides so expect

I’m not a massive lover of water parks but I have to say I had a fantastic day here. We booked our tickets online the day before to take advantage of the discount. If you purchase a child ticket (our son is 11) it means they can only go on the rides numbered 1 and 2 but you can

We are a couple in our mid-twenties and had a great time at Water City. We visited on a Monday in May and the park was fairly quiet, we didn’t have to wait long (if at all) for the slides. There’s a great selection suitable for all ages. As some of the other reviews mention

The park is nice. Well maintained. However the water could be a lot cleaner. We visited on a windy day (it's very cold on a windy day) and the water was full of bugs and leaves. The slides are nice, but not spectaculair. Because of the off season we did not have to wait any

Had a really good day here , would definately return.. lots of slides/ activitys .. cashless system is also very good as you can pay for things using your wrist band and then pay at the end.. my only criticism is that you have to keep running up the hills back to the top of the

we visited in late May and it was almost empty, never had to queue and got on every ride many times. food was disappointing, although served quickly. we did the organised tour which dropped us off at 10.30am and didn’t collect us till 4.30pm. we found this too long a day for

My partner and I visited Water City today through our Hotel and paid €40 each for transfer and entrance. After seeing the leaflets and website claiming it was ‘the biggest waterpark in Crete’, had over 30 ‘games’ and had the biggest waves, we were very excited to spend our day

We visited Watercity last May whilst on holiday and we were extremely lucky because there was only a few people in the park as it had just opened recently after undergoing refurbishments. There is a good choice of slides and tube rides where you sit in rubber rings/donuts. As

We booked this via our hotel for simplicity and felt it was still a decent deal with coach transfer. We set up on the 'island' in the middle of the lazy river as the wasn't too crowded and looked like it would offer a good bit of shade during the day. The entrance and lockers

Me and my partner visited this water park in early October, the weather was warm but still windy in shade, there were no queues at all which was great, we managed to complete most of the slides, then decided to stick to using slides that only had rings, because some of the

My new husband and I visited on our honeymoon, the rides and whole waterpark were very clean. All the staff were friendly, views were incredible and most importantly we had lots of fun on the slides. Would reccommend to anybody, definitely our preferred waterpark as we visited

Visited water city with the wife (pregnant) and children (12,9,7). After visiting water parks on every holiday we've been on this would rank as the worst. We had to pay full price for the wife even though she was pregnant and couldn't go on any of the slides, surely a spectator

This place was so much fun. Lot of slides to choose from, well organized. Easy to buy drinks and food because you didn't have to carry money with you. Pay when you live. Crazy slides to us adults and smaller slides for children. Area was very clean. We had so much fun. And

The place is very well situated, far away from the center in a quiet area. It is easy to drive there, but don’t forget it is easy for Crete. Two of the slides were closed so we didn’t tried all of them, which makes me think that you pay the full price and you don’t use
Visited with family and two yoiung children. Great facilities for all ages. Good selection of refreshments and snacks. Very Clean.

we were a family of 16 8 adults and 8 grandchildren of varying ages. From the time we arrived until we finally left fun was had by all.Some of the younger children were disappointed that they weren't allowed on the some of the bigger slides. The Jacuzzi was very disappointing

There was a large group of us that attended and it was great that nobody felt left out. The staff are helpful and friendly, food and drink is really tasty and good value also using a barcode system so you do not need cash everywhere you just pay when you leave. Everytime we
Did this a package with transport there & back from Malia. Great day fun slides, went home exhausted after a fun packed day

As it is out of season there was literally not many people there at all. We didn’t have to wait in a que for any of the slides therefore we had been on them all in less than an hour. 2 of the slides were closed all day and we have no idea why as the water was even running down

I had high hopes for this water park, however they were soon dashed. Half of the rides were not open, and even the wave pool was not on, so there wasn’t much to do apart from go on the same 3-4 rides that were available. Warning: be careful of rides without a ring because you
Out of season so not a queue in sight. Able to go on all of the rides as much as we wanted with no wait. All the rides were good but not the best water park I have been to.

Visited whilst on holiday with grown up children and grandchild staff all very helpful and happy to help park itself was. Very clean and plenty of lifeguards slides and rides had no queues and no waiting although I imagine this would change in high season Food and drink is

Really amazing park for all ages.You can have a full day of games and you will not regret it. Food was not so good but the last thing you would do with all these slides is to eat. Even if you are afraid of hights you can try the lazy river or the pool of waves. Just great!!!

First time at the watercity waterpark and it was a really great experience! I love the thing that it’s huge and you can do so different things and have fun. It’s really clean. Most of the stuff is friendly and happy especially the lifeguards. But I think they can lower the price
A group of 9 of us booked from a wee shop for $30 and that included a bus there and back. Definitely would recommend to anyone, and would return if i was ever back in Malia.
We came here for the day while on our family holiday. This was a great day! Exceptionally clean, slides are fantastic, lots for all of us to do. Will definitely return next time we ho to Crete.

Went here this month it was recommended to us by the locals. I’ve been to water parks in America so them compared to this one didn’t really compare. But it was still a nice day out. Younger kids would probably have a better day out. If you pre-book your tickets you get a cheaper

We went here during September and there were hardly any queues (if any) all day. The park is situated about 10 mins drive from Heraklion Airport up a hill. They have an intuitive cashless barcode payment system. Don’t be fooled though as there are very few prices advertised and
Great Waterpark, we were advised to go early afternoon as buses leave at 4pm so less busy. Glad we did, plenty rides all had fun

Recently visited. Had a lovely relaxing day. Took our 10 year old who to be honest did not want to go on all the fast / bigger rides so we spent most of our time on the smaller slides, lazy river, and the 2 large pools with slides and waves. The larger slides looked fantastic

Overall the park is a great day out.. loads of great rides.. The only issue I had with it was bought tickets on line to get the discount.. children are classed as under 140 cm.. both mine are under 140cm so I bought 2 adult and 2 child tickets. The first slide we queued for we
We loved it, our son is 4 years old and there was plenty of slides for him. We spend there the hole day.

We had such a good time on our visit to the Water Park! The drive up to the park is stunning with awesome views of the island! They have a great system of payment, where you scan whatever you buy to a wrist band! They do offer lockers for your gear.... but it’s not really

This place was great, queues not too long. Slides were different levels of difficulty. Plenty of places to eat and relax. Please note all food and drink purchased is done on bar code so no money is in the park BUT if you don’t keep a check on the kids you could end up with a

A last minute decision based on the weather (rainy and wind West of Heraklion where we are staying), we (family of 4, with two boys of 7 and 9) made the pilgrimage to Salt Water City Park; the first water park we have ever been to that uses salt water. It made no difference to

Went in August. After speaking to tour operators we hired a car as the water park was about 75km from our hotel and we were informed that the water park is built several hundred metres (high) up a mountain Road with no bus service and very high taxi costs. We checked on line and

Great day out, spent all day there, we had a 20 mth year old baby, a 6 year old and a 13 year old, they all enjoyed the day. Some of the staff could do with learning some customer service but that can be overlooked. Money is not used in the park, they scan your wrist band when

This was an amazing day out. The temp on the day was about 33 degrees. The water was refreshing and plenty of shade to be had. There is a lot of seating areas and sun beds. The way you pay is good, you will be given a wrist band to wear while your in the water park and this is

Who would have thought a silly old pensioner would like this sort of place. Loads of things to do, all wet! Death ride, I'm still here! Nice food and drinks. Toilets clean even tough busy. Shaded places if you cant take part. Great time for the family group
Lots of different slides to try for all ages. Queues not too bad, max waiting time of about 10 mins. Clean and plenty of shady spots. Signage from main road could have been better.

Went with the Children and Grandchildren (22). The slides are awesome and the water lovely and warm. Difficult to find but well worth the effort as everyone had a fantastic time. Not expensive and the way that the manage payments in the park is something many other attractions
The kids never get bored! So many rides, queues were never massive. Clean, safe, loads of sun beds. Food is ok but drinks are expensive. Highly recommended visiting here.

We were there on a friday. There was many people at the park, and a lot of waiting time on the popular rides. I love the no cash system where you pat with your wristband. A lot of differnt kind of rides from all to the little kids to the adults. I would like to visit again so
Last minute decision - great day out. Lockers keep your belongings safe and dry and wrist bands mean you dont have to carry cash or valuables.

Family of 4 with 2 teenage boys. We liked this water park. As with most places where you haven't been before it takes a little while to work out what to do/where to go. First thing after entering you might want to go down to the shop below the entrance where you can get a

Watercity is not a cheap day out but it is certainly fun! The four of us took a tour bus from our hotel. I wasn’t looking forward to it as I’m not a huge fan of rides and that combined with cold water (no heated pools) doesn’t give me pleasure. However I still enjoyed the day! I

If you really love a water park full of slides this place will be fun for you, but expect to wait 10-20 min before your turn. There are Two slides where you have to take a douple swimring and have to slide as pairs which is nice but one is scary if you have a fear of heights. If

We visited the water-city in the summer its too good to be there the service is very good the slides are fun but . Lines not short but also not so long, food are not the best. (Fast food). Absolutely this attraction must see for who visit crete.

Nice waterpark. The day we went the queues were not long. Definitely recommended for an afternoon. Drove there ourselves and found it easily using Google Maps.

We've been to many waterparks over the years and this one is just fantastic. It's clean, the lifeguards are diligent and good with the kids. There's a huge selection of rides. Food and drink is very reasonably priced. It felt safe. Great location at the top of a hill with

Fabulous Waterpark, fun, brilliant rides, lots to do. Had a lovely time. Can’t praise the staff enough! Can be a bit pricey, for food, drinks etc..but suppose that’s what you pay in Waterparks now days.
Great fun day. Not have to queue very long at any ride. Only complaint, the floor can be very hot to walk on bare feet.

Really enjoyed our trip. Would definitely recommend. Staff were friendly, the place looks clean and the slides were great.

Not recommend to go after September. Because water is really, I MEAN REALLY cold. At least you could offer lower prices as it’s not the season. This reason, ruined our day at water park. Everything else is pretty awesome.

Had a great day here lots to do, very clean, liked having the wristband and paying at the end of the day saved worrying about leaving valuables about. It's not to expensive for food either which is good as there were 8 of us. Would definitely recommend visiting here.

Best water park we have visited ! Lots of fun for all ages, and for us a family of grown up children, lots of adrenaline rides to keep every happy !!! Super space to sunbathe and swim too, and life guards very "on the ball" and always watching. safe, family fun !

Good value for money and a great day out for the family. Suggest you get there between 10 and 11 to get sun beds. Very relaxed atmosphere and lots to do for all ages. Foods ok and they work on a cashless system so you pay at the end of the day. Overall we had a fantastic time!

Great day out , but please take your own food , 4x burger chips 8x soft drinks €55 rip off. Low quality

Enjoyed a fantastic day out as we are all early 20's we thought it would be too young for us but was perfect for us. Rides were excellent and blew us away! Good idea for wristbands and charging food and drink on them. Park was really well laid out but the tarmac was really hot

If there are no queues, you can go on every ride twice in just over an hour. How people can stay here all day is beyond me! This is genuinely the worse water park i have ever been to. Dead bugs in the water when you come out! Absolutely vile

We booked through our Hotel and arrived at the Watercity Waterpark at around 11.00 on a very warm day.... The process of using the bands to record payments of food, drinks and gifts was good and we progressed to a sheltered spot where 11 of us across 4 generations set up camp.

Had a brilliant time at water city. There were a variety of water rides, a lazy river and pools. The slides were great fun, with a lot of variety. When we went the queues were short, which was a plus for us. Would recommend coming here if you're staying nearby.

Went there with my girlfriend. The entrance fee is really high. As a local i don't suggest this water park. There are better things to do in Heraklion city. Except the entrance fee you have to calculate also: Money for locking rent, Money for eating sth, Money for photos etc...

While in Crete we went to both Acqua Plus and Water City. They both have pros and cons for example at Acqua park the staff were a more friendly and personable, the park is laid out well so it's easy to get round and it was completely dead when we went so the queuing time was

It's not all it's cracked up to be in pictures, the park is actually very small and after about 30 minutes there isn't much to do. A great day for children but a rather boring one for adults. The food is also very average.

When we visited water city it was an overcast day but still warm and it worked in our favour as we didn't have to wait for any of the slides! There were no queues which meant we went on every slide several times! Very enjoyable day and well worth a visit!

We really enjoyed a day out to watercity as you go in you get a wristband and anything you purchase in the park u pay on the wristband and u get a receipt with how much ur balance is. The only thing we did pay was the €2 deposit at the shop for the pad lock that you get back the

After we had been on each slide once, the combination of a lack of people in the park and steep uphill barefoot climbs on sharp paving tiles left us wanting to head back. Although I enjoyed it, is is more for the water park enthusiast.

Visited with my boyfriend in September for my 21st birthday. The park isn't very big but there are plenty of slides to enjoy. I really enjoyed the day, got to the park for 10 and got on most of the slides within an hour and a half as it wasn't very busy. There is something for

Visited this water park in October 16. We managed to get a 10% voucher which we found on its web site so maybe check prior to going. You can download onto your phone and show it at the pay point no need to print off. We didnt go on an excursion it cost 15 euro by taxi each way

Went here twice , in October, end of season, with my 4year old and had lots of fun!!!There were enough pools and slides my daughter could do for the visit to be worth while. There were not so many visitors - which I prefer... no cues... enough space in the pools... The staff was

Great day out. We visited in mid october and was still lovely and warm. All the rides were open. Booked the tickets and bus via our rep. In our group there were 5 adults 2 teenagers 4 kids and 2 toddlers. There was something for everyone. Only critisim was that the floors are

We had such a great day, brilliant slides and the kids loved it! Lifeguards really friendly too! Our boys are 8 and 5 and there was plenty of slides for them to go on! Only downside was the waves in the wave pool only came on once and we missed it!
An excellent family outing that we all enjoyed. Very few queues and great rides for all ages. Good value for money. Would highly recommend it.
Everything you need is inside. Food and drink prices are not big. Many different tubes, not large queues. Safe and nice place.

Visited all slides and liked it. My older son was very happy with the visit. Some of the slides was not so good, especially those where you have to slide without a tire. But anyway we liked it very much!

Didn't look great on arrival but actually was great fun. Money on wrist bands was good but be careful as you don't know what you are spending ! Food was pretty awful !

Great place for all kids and adults, many water slides for all ages. Best recommend to come here at the morning when it's open and leave at noon

This water park is such a good one. There is all types of water slides for everyone and every level of thrill you are wanting to seek! I would highly recommend you visit this water park. However please note to get to the top of each slide there is a VERY steep hill every time

We spent one day in the park and it was the best/most fun day in Crete. At the end of the day we ware tired and smiling, what more could you ask for. Lots of slides, but the food was not that good. You need minimum 6 hours!

15 euros the adults and 10 per kid so it is a bit expensive for a family plus what you are going to spend inside in snacks etc. They only have two toilets so it was a bit tiring having to cross the whole park to go to toilet and they dont have toilets for children.

text.wiki:
Phaistos (Greek: Φαιστός, pronounced [feˈstos]; Ancient Greek: Φαιστός, pronounced [pʰai̯stós], Minoan: PA-I-TO?), also transliterated as Phaestos, Festos and Latin Phaestus, is a Bronze Age archaeological site at modern Faistos, a municipality in south central Crete. Ancient Phaistos was located about 5.6 km (3.5 mi) east of the Mediterranean Sea and 62 km (39 mi) south of Heraklio, the second largest city of Minoan Crete. The name Phaistos survives from ancient Greek references to a city in Crete of that name at or near the current ruins.
The name is substantiated by the coins of the classical city. They display motifs such as Europa sitting on a bull, Talos with wings, Heracles without beard and being crowned, and Zeus in the form of a naked youth sitting on a tree. On either the obverse or the reverse the name of the city, or its abbreviation, is inscribed, such as ΦΑΙΣ or ΦΑΙΣΤΙ, for Phaistos or Phaistios ("Phaistian" adjective) written either right-to-left or left-to-right. These few dozen coins were acquired by collectors from uncontrolled contexts. They give no information on the location of Phaistos.


== Archaeology ==
Phaistos was located by Thomas Abel Brimage Spratt, commander of the Spitfire, a paddle steamer, in the Mediterranean Survey of 1853, which described the topography, settlements and monuments of Crete. Spratt followed the directions of Strabo, who said:Of the three cities that were united under one metropolis by Minos, the third, which was Phaestus, was razed to the ground by the Gortynians; it is sixty stadia distant from Gortyn, twenty from the sea, and forty from the seaport Matalum; and the country is held by those who razed it.
The simple geometric problem posed by these distances from known points was solved with no difficulty by the survey. The location pinpointed was the eastern end of a hill, or ridge, rising from the middle of the Geropotamos river valley extending from the sea to the Messara Plain in an east–west direction. The hill was called Kastri ("fort", "small castle"). A military man, Spratt understood the significance of the location immediately:I thus found that Phaestus had occupied the extremity of a ridge that divides the maritime plain of Debaki from the plain of the Messara, so as to command the narrow valley of communication.
A village of 16 houses remained on the ridge, but the vestiges of fortification walls indicated a city had once existed there. A half-century later, after removing the houses, Federico Halbherr and his crew began to discover the remains of an extensive palace complex. As he had begun excavation before Arthur Evans at Knossos in 1900, he did not have the advantage of Evans' concepts of Minoan civilization nor the knowledge acquired after the decipherment of the Linear B syllabary by Michael Ventris. Excavation ended in 1904, to begin again after another half-century, in 1950. By this time it was understood that the palace had been constructed at the beginning of the Proto-Palace Period. After 1955 the place name, 𐀞𐀂𐀵, pa-i-to, interpreted as Phaistos (written in Mycenaean Greek), began to turn up in the Linear B tablets at Knossos, then under the Mycenaean Greeks. There was every reason to think that pa-i-to was located at Kastri.
No Linear B has been found at Phaistos, but tradition and the Knossos tablets suggest that Phaistos was a dependency of Knossos. Moreover, only a few pieces of Linear A have been found. As Phaistos appears to have been an administrative center, the lack of records is surprising.
In 1908, Pernier found the Phaistos Disc in the basements of the northern group of the palace. This artifact is a clay disk, dated to between 1950 BC and 1400 BC and impressed with a unique, sophisticated hieroglyphic script.
The tombs of the rulers of Phaistos were found in a cemetery 20 minutes away from the palace remains.


== Bronze Age ==
Phaistos was inhabited from about 4000 BC. A palace, dating from the Middle Bronze Age, was destroyed by an earthquake during the Late Bronze Age. Knossos along with other Minoan sites was destroyed at that time. The palace was rebuilt toward the end of the Late Bronze Age.
The first palace was built about 2000 BC. This section is on a lower level than the west courtyard and has a nice facade with a plastic outer shape, a cobbled courtyard, and a tower ledge with a ramp, which leads up to a higher level. The old palace was destroyed three times in period of about three centuries. After the first and second disaster, reconstruction and repairs were made, so there are distinguished three construction phases.
The Old Palace was built in the Protopalatial Period, then rebuilt twice due to extensive earthquake damage. When the palace was destroyed by earthquakes, the re-builders constructed a New Palace atop the old.
Several artifacts with Linear A inscriptions were excavated at this site. The name of the site also appears in partially deciphered Linear A texts, and is probably similar to Mycenaean 'PA-I-TO' as written in Linear B. Several kouloura structures (subsurface pits) have been found at Phaistos. Pottery has been recovered at Phaistos from in the Middle and Late Minoan periods, including polychrome items and embossing in imitation of metal work. Bronze Age works from Phaistos include bridge spouted bowls, eggshell cups, tall jars and large pithoi.In one of the three hills of the area, remains of the middle neolithic age have been found, and a part of the palace was built during the Early Minoan period. Another two palaces seems to have been built at the Middle and Late Minoan Age. The older looks like the Minoan palace of Knossos, although this is smaller. An earthquake c. 18th century BC destroyed the palace but a larger palace of the later Minoan period was built on the ruins around 1700 BC, consisting of several rooms separated by columns.
The levels of the theater area, in conjunction with two splendid staircases, gave a grand access to the main hall of the propylaea through high doors. A twin gate led directly to the central courtyard through a wide street. The floors and walls of the interior rooms were decorated with plates of sand and white gypsum stone. Upper floors of the west sector had spacious ceremonial rooms, although their exact restoration was not possible.
A brilliant entrance from the central courtyard led to the royal apartments in the north part of the palace, with a view of the tops of Psiloritis. The rooms were constructed from alabaster and other materials. The rooms for princes were smaller and less luxurious than the rooms of the royal departments.
Around 1400 BC, the invading Achaeans destroyed Phaistos, as well as Knossos. The palace appears to have been unused thereafter, as evidence of the Mycenaean era have not been found.


== Iron Age ==
References to Phaistos in ancient Greek literature are quite frequent. Phaistos is first referenced by Homer as "well populated", and the Homeric epics indicate its participation in the Trojan War. The historian Diodorus Siculus indicates that Phaistos, together with Knossos and Kydonia, are the three towns that were founded by King Minos on Crete. Instead, Pausanias and Stephanus of Byzantium supported in their texts that the founder of the city was Phaestos, son of Hercules or Ropalus. The city of Phaistos is associated with the mythical king of Crete Rhadamanthys.
The site was reinhabited during the Geometric Age (8th century BC). Phaistos had its own currency and had created an alliance with other autonomous Cretan cities, and with the king of Pergamon Eumenes II. Around the end of the 3rd century BC, Phaestos was destroyed by the Gortynians and since then ceased to exist in the history of Crete. Scotia Aphrodite and goddess Leto, who was also called Phytia, were worshiped there. The people of Phaistos were distinguished for their funny adages. Epimenides, the wise man invited by the Athenians to clean the city after the Cylonian affair (Cyloneio agos) in the 6th century BC, was of Phaistian descent.

Borgna, Elisabetta. (2004). "Social Meanings of Food and Drink Consumption at LM III Phaistos." In Food, Cuisine and Society in Prehistoric Greece. Edited by Paul Halstead and John C. Barrett. Oxford: Oxbow Books, 174–195.

text.wiki:
Nikos Kazantzakis (Greek: Νίκος Καζαντζάκης [ˈnikos kazanˈd͡zacis]; 18 February 1883 – 26 October 1957) was a Greek writer. Widely considered a giant of modern Greek literature, he was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature in nine different years.Kazantzakis' novels included Zorba the Greek (published 1946 as Life and Times of Alexis Zorbas), Christ Recrucified (1948), Captain Michalis (1950, translated Freedom or Death), and The Last Temptation of Christ (1955).  He also wrote plays, travel books, memoirs and philosophical essays such as The Saviors of God: Spiritual Exercises. His fame spread in the English-speaking world due to cinematic adaptations of Zorba the Greek (1964) and The Last Temptation of Christ (1988).
He translated also a number of notable works into Modern Greek, such as the Divine Comedy, Thus Spoke Zarathustra and the Iliad.


== Biography ==

When Kazantzakis was born in 1883 in Kandiye, now Heraklion, Crete had not yet joined the modern Greek state (which had been established in 1832), and was still under the rule of the Ottoman Empire. From 1902 to 1906 Kazantzakis studied law at the University of Athens: his 1906 Juris Doctor thesis title was Ο Φρειδερίκος Νίτσε εν τη φιλοσοφία του δικαίου και της πολιτείας ("Friedrich Nietzsche on the Philosophy of Law and the State"). Then he went to the Sorbonne in 1907 to study philosophy. There he fell under the influence of Henri Bergson. His 1909 doctoral dissertation at the Sorbonne was a reworked version of his 1906 dissertation under the title Friedrich Nietzsche dans la philosophie du droit et de la cité ("Friedrich Nietzsche on the Philosophy of Right and the State").  Upon his return to Greece, he began translating works of philosophy. In 1914 he met Angelos Sikelianos. Together they travelled for two years in places where Greek Orthodox Christian culture flourished, largely influenced by the enthusiastic nationalism of Sikelianos.
Kazantzakis married Galatea Alexiou in 1911; they divorced in 1926. He married Eleni Samiou in 1945. Between 1922 and his death in 1957, he sojourned in Paris and Berlin (from 1922 to 1924), Italy, Russia (in 1925), Spain (in 1932), and then later in Cyprus, Aegina, Egypt, Mount Sinai, Czechoslovakia, Nice (he later bought a villa in nearby Antibes, in the Old Town section near the famed seawall), China, and Japan.
While in Berlin, where the political situation was explosive, Kazantzakis discovered communism and became an admirer of Vladimir Lenin. He never became a committed communist, but visited the Soviet Union and stayed with the Left Opposition politician and writer Victor Serge. He witnessed the rise of Joseph Stalin, and became disillusioned with Soviet-style communism. Around this time, his earlier nationalist beliefs were gradually replaced by a more universalist ideology.
As a journalist in 1926 he got interviews from Miguel Primo de Rivera and the Italian dictator Benito Mussolini.
The 50th anniversary of the death of Nikos Kazantzakis was selected as main motif for a high-value euro collectors' coin; the €10 Greek Nikos Kazantzakis commemorative coin, minted in 2007. His image is on the obverse of the coin, while the reverse carries the National Emblem of Greece with his signature.


== Death ==

During WWII he was in Athens and translated the Iliad, together with the philologist Ioannis Kakridis. In 1945, he became the leader of a small party on the non-communist left, and entered the Greek government as Minister without Portfolio. He resigned this post the following year. In 1946, The Society of Greek Writers recommended that Kazantzakis and Angelos Sikelianos be awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. In 1957, he lost the Prize to Albert Camus by one vote. Camus later said that Kazantzakis deserved the honour "a hundred times more" than himself. In total Kazantzakis was nominated in nine different years. Late in 1957, even though suffering from leukemia, he set out on one last trip to China and Japan. Falling ill on his return flight, he was transferred to Freiburg, Germany, where he died. He is buried on the wall surrounding the city of Heraklion near the Chania Gate, looking out over the mountains and sea of Crete. His epitaph reads "I hope for nothing. I fear nothing. I am free." (Δεν ελπίζω τίποτα. Δε φοβούμαι τίποτα. Είμαι λέφτερος.)


== Literary work ==
Kazantzakis' first published work was the 1906 narrative, Serpent and Lily (Όφις και Κρίνο), which he signed with the pen name Karma Nirvami. In 1907 Kazantzakis went to Paris for his graduate studies and was deeply influenced by the philosophy of Henry Bergson, primarily the idea that a true understanding of the world comes from the combination of intuition, personal experience, and rational thought. The theme of rationalism mixed with irrationality later became central to many of Kazantzakis' later stories, characters, and personal philosophies. Later, in 1909, he wrote a one-act play titled Comedy, which was filled with existential themes, predating the post-World War II existentialist movement in Europe spearheaded by writers like Jean-Paul Sartre and Camus. After completing his studies in Paris, he wrote the tragedy, "The Master Builder" (Ο Πρωτομάστορας), based on a popular Greek folkloric myth.

Through the next several decades, from the 1910s through the 1930s, Kazantzakis traveled around Greece, much of Europe, northern Africa, and to several countries in Asia. Countries he visited include: Germany, Italy, France, The Netherlands, Romania, Egypt, Russia, Japan, and China, among others. These journeys put Kazantzakis in contact with different philosophies, ideologies, lifestyles, and people, all of which influenced him and his writings. Kazantzakis would often write about his influences in letters to friends, citing Sigmund Freud, the philosophy of Nietzsche, Buddhist theology, and communist ideology and major influences. While he continued to travel later in life, the bulk of his travel writing came from this time period.
Kazantzakis began writing The Odyssey: A Modern Sequel in 1924, and completed it in 1938 after fourteen years of writing and revision. The poem follows the hero of Homer's Odyssey, Odysseus, as he undertakes a final journey after the end of the original poem. Following the structure of Homer's Odyssey, it is divided into 24 rhapsodies and consists of 33,333 lines. While Kazantzakis felt this poem held his cumulative wisdom and experience, and that it was his greatest literary experience, critics were split, "some praised it as an unprecedented epic, [while] many simply viewed it as a hybristic act," with many scholars still being split to this day. A common criticism of The Odyssey: A Modern Sequel was aimed at Kazantzakis' over-reliance on flowery and metaphorical verse, a criticism that is also aimed at his works of fiction.Many of Kazantzakis' most famous novels were published between 1940 and 1961, including Zorba the Greek (1946), Christ Recrucified (1948), Captain Michalis (1953), The Last Temptation of Christ (1955), and Report to Greco (1961).
Scholar Peter Bein argues that each story explores different aspects of post-World War II Greek culture such as religion, nationalism, political beliefs, the Greek Civil War, gender roles, immigration, and general cultural practices and beliefs. These works also explore what Kazantzakis believed to be the unique physical and spiritual location of Greece, a nation that belongs to neither the East nor the West, an idea he put forth in many of his letters to friends. As the scholar Peter Bein argued, "Kazantzakis viewed Greece's special mission as the reconciliation of Eastern instinct with Western reason," echoing the Bergsonian themes that balance logic against emotion found in many of Kazantzakis' novels.
Two of these works of fiction, Zorba the Greek and The Last Temptation of Christ had major motion picture adaptations in 1964 and 1988 respectively.


== Language and use of Demotic Greek ==
During the time when Kazantzakis was writing his novels, poems, and plays, the majority of "serious" Greek artistic work was written in Katharevousa, a "pure" form of the Greek language that was created to bridge Ancient Greek with Modern, Demotic Greek, and to "purify" Demotic Greek. The use of Demotic, among writers, gradually started to gain the upper hand only in the turn of the 20th century, under the influence of the New Athenian School (or Palamian).
In his letters to friends and correspondents, Kazantzakis wrote that he chose to write in Demotic Greek to capture the spirit of the people, and to make his writing resonate with the common Greek citizen. Moreover, he wanted to prove that the common spoken language of Greek was able to produce artistic, literary works. Or, in his own words, "Why not show off all the possibilities of demotic Greek?" Furthermore, Kazantzakis felt that it was important to record the vernacular of the everyday person, including Greek peasants, and often tried to include expressions, metaphors, and idioms he would hear while traveling throughout Greece, and incorporate them into his writing for posterity. At the time of writing, some scholars and critics panned his work because it was not written in Katharevousa, while others praised it precisely because it was written in Demotic Greek.
Several critics have argued that Kazantzakis' writing was too flowery, filled with obscure metaphors, and difficult to read, despite the fact that his works were written in Demotic Greek. Kazantzakis scholar Peter Bein argues that the metaphors and language Kazantzakis used were taken directly from the peasants he encountered when traveling Greece. Bein asserts that, since Kazantzakis was trying to preserve the language of the people, he used their local metaphors and phrases to give his narrative an air of authenticity and preserve these phrases so that they were not lost.


== Socialism ==
Throughout his life, Kazantzakis reiterated his belief that "only socialism as the goal and democracy as the means" could provide an equitable solution to the "frightfully urgent problems of the age in which we are living." He saw the need for socialist parties throughout the world to put aside their bickering and unite so that the program of "socialist democracy" could prevail not just in Greece, but throughout the civilized world. He described socialism as a social system which "does not permit the exploitation of one person by another" and that "must guarantee every freedom."Kazantzakis was anathema to the right-wing in Greece both before and after World War II. The right waged war against his books and called him "immoral" and a "Bolshevik troublemaker" and accused him of being a "Russian agent". He was also distrusted by the Greek and Russian Communist parties as a "bourgeois" thinker. However, upon his death in 1957, he was honored by the Chinese Communist party as a "great writer" and "devotee of peace." Following the war, he was temporarily leader of a minor Greek leftist party, while in 1945 he was, among others, a founding member of the Greek-Soviet friendship union.


== Religious beliefs and relationship with the Greek Orthodox Church ==
While Kazantzakis was deeply spiritual, he often discussed his struggle with religious faith, specifically his Greek Orthodoxy. Baptized Greek Orthodox as a child, he was fascinated by the lives of saints from a young age. As a young man he took a month long trip to Mount Athos, a major spiritual center for Greek Orthodoxy. Most critics and scholars of Kazantzakis agree that the struggle to find truth in religion and spirituality was central to a great deal of his works, and that some novels, like The Last Temptation of Christ and Christ Recrucified focus completely on questioning Christian morals and values. As he traveled Europe, he was influenced by various philosophers, cultures, and religions, like Buddhism, causing him to question his Christian beliefs. While never claiming to be an atheist, his public questioning and critique of the most fundamental Christian values put him at odds with some in the Greek Orthodox church, and many of his critics. Scholars theorize that Kazantzakis' difficult relationship with many members of the clergy, and the more religiously conservative literary critics, came from his questioning. In his book, Broken Hallelujah: Nikos Kazantzakis and Christian Theology, author Darren Middleton theorizes that, "Where the majority of Christian writers focus on God's immutability, Jesus' deity, and our salvation through God's grace, Kazantzakis emphasized divine mutability, Jesus' humanity, and God's own redemption through our effort," highlighting Kazantzakis' uncommon interpretation of traditional Orthodox Christian beliefs. Many Orthodox Church clergy condemned Kazantzakis' work and a campaign was started to excommunicate him. His reply was: "You gave me a curse, Holy fathers, I give you a blessing: may your conscience be as clear as mine and may you be as moral and religious as I" (Greek: "Μου δώσατε μια κατάρα, Άγιοι πατέρες, σας δίνω κι εγώ μια ευχή: Σας εύχομαι να ‘ναι η συνείδηση σας τόσο καθαρή, όσο είναι η δική μου και να ‘στε τόσο ηθικοί και θρήσκοι όσο είμαι εγώ"). While the excommunication was rejected by the top leadership of the Orthodox Church, it became emblematic of the persistent disapprobation from many Christian authorities for his political and religious views.
Modern scholarship tends to dismiss the idea that Kazantzakis was being sacrilegious or blasphemous with the content of his novels and beliefs. These scholars argue that, if anything, Kazantzakis was acting in accordance to a long tradition of Christians who publicly struggled with their faith, and grew a stronger and more personal connection to God through their doubt. Moreover, scholars like Darren J. N. Middleton argue that Kazantzakis' interpretation of the Christian faith predated the more modern, personalized interpretation of Christianity that has become popular in the years after Kazantzakis' death.The Ecumenical Patriarch Athenagoras, the leader of the Orthodox Church, declared in 1961 in Heraklion: “Kazantzakis is a great man and his works grace the Patriarchal library.”
