I believe the museum had just completed a multi year renovation and it is beautiful. You can spend as much or as little time as you would like here depending on how you pace yourself. The collection is vast and beautiful.
Amazing way to complete ones visit of Knossos. Visit in that order. Only negative is the pushy tour groups
Great collection of ancient artefacts. I really liked the amphoras with the animals painted on them! Excellent!

This place is a treasure trove of Ancient Greek artefacts and is a great thing to do after visiting Knosos All the artefacts are displayed in different rooms with signs explaining their importance If you like the ancient world go here!

I absolutely loved this visit; definitely worth a go. Immerse yourself in the local history and culture. Very inspirational early art and crafts on display. A strong sense of centuries of life gone by and local specificity.

We enjoyed very much the marvellous artifacts. Exhibitions are pretty well organized. It would have been an interesting visit, if there hadn't been so many noisy groups, all led by screaming guides. What a pity for such an important museum.

This is a very interesting museum with a lot to see and read about. If you are visiting Knossos or going this is the place to see all the artifacts from there.
We only managed the ground floor as time was limited. Interesting museum with lots of Minoan artefacts on display.

A lot you can see and learn about ancient history of the Crete. Only thing that was missing is , you can't buy book or a catalog about the current or the past exhibitions.
One of the greatest museums in Greece with a huge collection of Minoan Art. Went here on a guided tour after a Knossos visit.
The museum included so many artefacts from Minoan times. It was quite busy while we were there but this did not pose a problem. Toilets could have been cleaner.
So important and so beutiful museum exhibits, everyone must visit this Museum! Infact, you can spend there all the day!

Great displays , well thought out and presented . A must for anybody who appreciates history and the achievements of the Minoan civilisation . You could easily spend a couple of hours in the museum . The museum is Airconditioned and well lit .

The place to visit. Great archaeological museum with unbelievable artifacts. Very good organized museum on 2 levels. Excellent presentation. No problem to take photos. Don't forget to visit Knossos palace at the same time.

Visited this small museum. So impressd. So much to see in a small space. Great for social history about this area.

Lovely little museum (just one room but well arranged and quite eclectic) with English descriptions and explanations by the adorable and dedicated owner. Worth the try!

Very interesting visit at the Folklore Museum of Gouves with the family, during our trip on Crete island in Grece.

text.wiki:
Heraklion or Iraklion ( hih-RAK-lee-ən; Greek: Ηράκλειο, Irákleio, pronounced [iˈraklio]) is the largest city and the administrative capital of the island of Crete and capital of Heraklion regional unit. It is the fourth largest city in Greece with a population of 211,370 (Urban Area) according to the 2011 census. The population of the municipality was 173,993.The Bronze Age palace of Knossos, also known as the Palace of Minos, is located nearby.
Heraklion was Europe's fastest growing tourism destination for 2017, according to Euromonitor, with an 11.2% growth in international arrivals. According to the ranking, Heraklion was ranked as the 20th most visited region in Europe, as the 66th area on the Planet and as the 2nd in Greece for the year 2017, with 3.2 million visitors and the 19th in Europe for 2018, with 3.4 million visitors.


== Names ==
The Arab traders from al-Andalus (Iberia) who founded the Emirate of Crete moved the island's capital from Gortyna to a new castle they called rabḍ al-ḫandaq (Arabic: ربض الخندق‎, "Castle of the Moat") in the 820s. This was hellenized as Χάνδαξ (Chándax) or Χάνδακας (Chándakas) and Latinized as Candia, which was taken into other European languages: in Italian and Latin as Candia, in French as Candie, in English as Candy, all of which could refer to the island of Crete as a whole as well as to the city alone; the Ottoman name was Kandiye.
After the Byzantine reconquest of Crete, the city was locally known as Megalo Kastro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο, 'Big Castle' in Greek) and its inhabitants were called Kastrinoi (Καστρινοί, "castle-dwellers").
The ancient name Ηράκλειον was revived in the 19th century and comes from the nearby Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles's city"), whose exact location is unknown. English usage formerly preferred the classicizing transliterations "Heraklion" or "Heraclion", but the form "Iraklion" is becoming more common.


== History ==


=== Minoan Era ===
Heraklion is close to the ruins of the palace of Knossos, which in Minoan times was the largest centre of population on Crete. Knossos had a port at the site of Heraklion (at Poros - Katsambas neighborhood) from the beginning of Early Minoan period (3500 to 2100 BC). Between 1600 and 1525 BC, the port was destroyed by a volcanic tsunami from nearby Santorini, leveling the region and covering it with ash.


=== Antiquity ===

After the fall of the Minoans, Heraklion, as well as the rest of Crete in general, fared poorly, with very little development in the area. Only with the arrival of the Romans did some construction in the area begin, yet especially early into Byzantine times the area was abound with pirates and bandits.


=== Emirate of Crete ===
The present city of Heraklion was founded in 824 by the Arabs under Abu Hafs Umar who had been expelled from Al-Andalus by Emir Al-Hakam I and had taken over the island from the Eastern Roman Empire. They built a moat around the city for protection, and named the city rabḍ al-ḫandaq (ربض الخندق, "Castle of the Moat", hellenized as Χάνδαξ, Chandax). It became the capital of the Emirate of Crete (ca. 827–961). The Saracens allowed the port to be used as a safe haven for pirates who operated against Imperial (Byzantine) shipping and raided Imperial territory around the Aegean.


=== Byzantine era ===

In 960, Byzantine forces under the command of Nikephoros Phokas, later to become Emperor, landed in Crete and attacked the city. After a prolonged siege, the city fell in March 961. The Saracen inhabitants were slaughtered, the city looted and burned to the ground. Soon rebuilt, the town remained under Byzantine control for the next 243 years.


=== Venetian era ===
 
In 1204, the city was bought by the Republic of Venice as part of a complicated political deal which involved, among other things, the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade restoring the deposed Eastern Roman Emperor Isaac II Angelus to his throne. The Venetians improved on the ditch of the city by building enormous fortifications, most of which are still in place, including a giant wall, in places up to 40 m thick, with 7 bastions, and a fortress in the harbour. Chandax was renamed Candia and became the seat of the Duke of Candia, and the Venetian administrative district of Crete became known as "Regno di Candia" (Kingdom of Candia). The city retained the name of Candia for centuries and the same name was often used to refer to the whole island of Crete as well. To secure their rule, Venetians began in 1212 to settle families from Venice on Crete. The coexistence of two different cultures and the stimulus of Italian Renaissance led to a flourishing of letters and the arts in Candia and Crete in general, that is today known as the Cretan Renaissance.


=== Ottoman era ===

During the Cretan War (1645–1669), the Ottomans besieged the city for 21 years, from 1648 to 1669, perhaps the longest siege in history. In its final phase, which lasted for 22 months, 70,000 Turks, 38,000 Cretans and slaves and 29,088 of the city's Christian defenders perished. The Ottoman army under an Albanian grand vizier, Köprülü Fazıl Ahmed Pasha conquered the city in 1669. 
Under the Ottomans, Kandiye (Ottoman Turkish قنديه) was the capital of Crete (Girit Eyâleti) until 1849, when Chania (Hanya) became the capital, and Kandiye became a sancak. In Greek, it was commonly called Megalo Castro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο 'Big Castle').
During the Ottoman period, the harbour silted up, so most shipping shifted to Chania in the west of the island.


=== Modern era ===
In 1898, the autonomous Cretan State was created, under Ottoman suzerainty, with Prince George of Greece as its High Commissioner and under international supervision. During the period of direct occupation of the island by the Great Powers (1898–1908), Candia was part of the British zone. At this time, the city was renamed "Heraklion", after the Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles' city"), whose exact location is unknown.
In 1913, with the rest of Crete, Heraklion was incorporated into the Kingdom of Greece. Heraklion became again capital of Crete in 1971, replacing Chania.


== Architecture, urban sculpture and fortifications ==

Venetian constructions such as the Koules Fortress (Castello a Mare), the ramparts and the arsenal dominate the port area.
Several sculptures, statues and busts commemorating significant events and figures of the city's and island's history, like El Greco, Vitsentzos Kornaros, Nikos Kazantzakis and Eleftherios Venizelos can be found around the city.
Many fountains of the Venetian era are preserved, such as the Bembo fountain, the Priuli fountain, Palmeti fountain, Sagredo fountain and Morosini fountain (in Lions Square).
Around the historic city center of Heraklion there are also a series of defensive walls, bastions and other fortifications which were built earlier in the Middle Ages, but were completely rebuilt by the Republic of Venice. The fortifications managed to withstand the longest siege in history for 21 years, before the city fell to the Ottomans in 1669.


== Municipality ==

The municipality Heraklion was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 5 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Gorgolainis
Heraklion
Nea Alikarnassos
Paliani
TemenosThe municipality has an area of 244.613 km2, the municipal unit 109.026 km2.


== Neighborhoods ==


== Suburbs ==


== Transportation ==


=== Port ===
Heraklion is an important shipping port and ferry dock. Travellers can take ferries and boats from Heraklion to destinations including Santorini, Ios Island, Paros, Mykonos, and Rhodes. There are direct ferries to Naxos, Karpathos, Kasos, Sitia, Anafi, Chalki and Diafani. There are also several daily ferries to Piraeus, the port of Athens in mainland Greece. The port of Heraklion was built by Sir Robert McAlpine and completed in 1928.


=== Airport ===
Heraklion International Airport, or Nikos Kazantzakis Airport is located about 5 kilometres (3 miles) east of the city. The airport is named after Heraklion native Nikos Kazantzakis, a writer and a philosopher. It is the second busiest airport of Greece after Athens International Airport, first in charter flights and the 65th busiest in Europe, because of Crete being a major holiday destination with 7.974.887 travellers in 2018 (List of the busiest airports in Europe).
In April 2018, the inner space of the airport has been modernized and expanded by almost 3.000 s.m., with 11 new gates and new stores. The expansion was a donation by Hellenic Duty Free Shops.
The airfield is shared with the 126th Combat Group of the Hellenic Air Force.
A project for the new airport of Heraklion in Kasteli area is starting at the end of 2017.


=== Highway network ===
European route E75 runs through the city and connects Heraklion with the three other major cities of Crete: Agios Nikolaos, Chania, and Rethymno.


=== Public transit ===

Urban buses serving the city, with 39 different routes. Intercity buses connects Heraklion to many major destinations in Crete.


=== Railway ===
From 1922 to 1937, there was a working industrial railway, which connected the Koules in Heraklion to Xiropotamos for the construction of the harbor.
A study from the year 2000 investigated the feasibility of two tram lines in Heraklion. The first line would link the Stadium to the airport, and the second the center of Heraklion and Knossos.  No approval has yet been given for this proposal.
In the summer of 2007, at the Congress of Cretan emigrants, held in Heraklion, two qualified engineers, George Nathenas (from Gonies, Malevizi Province) and Vassilis Economopoulos, recommended the development of a railway line in Crete, linking Chania, Rethymno and Heraklion, with a total journey time of 50 minutes (30 minutes between Heraklion and Rethymno, 20 minutes from Chania to Rethymno) and with provision for extensions to Kissamos, Kastelli Pediados (for the planned new airport), and Agios Nikolaos. No plans exist for implementing this idea.


== Climate ==
Heraklion has a hot-summer-Mediterranean climate (Csa in the Köppen climate classification). Summers are warm to hot and dry with clear skies. Dry hot days are often relieved by seasonal breezes. Winters are very mild with moderate rain. Because Heraklion is further south than Athens, it has a warmer climate during winter but cooler during summer because of the Aegean sea. The maximum temperature during the summer period is usually not more than 28 - 30 °C (Athens normal maximum temperature is about 6 °C higher). The minimum temperature record is -0.2 °C
A new temperature record for February was set at 27.8 °C, reached on 15 February 2016.


== Colleges, universities, libraries, and research centers ==

== Culture ==

=== Arts ===
The Cultural and Conference Center of Heraklion is a centre for the performing arts.


=== Sports ===
The city is home to several sports clubs. Most notably, Heraklion hosts OFI and Ergotelis, two football clubs with earlier presence in the Greek Superleague, the top tier of the Greek football league system. Furthermore, the city is the headquarters of the Heraklion Football Clubs Association, which administers football in the entire region. Other notable sport clubs include Iraklio B.C. (basketball), Atsalenios (football) and Irodotos (football) in the suburbs of Atsalenio and Nea Alikarnassos respectively.


=== Famous natives ===

Heraklion has been the home town of some of Greece's most significant people, including the novelist Nikos Kazantzakis (best known for Zorba the Greek), the poet and Nobel Prize winner Odysseas Elytis and the world-famous painter Domenicos Theotokopoulos (El Greco).

The beach is nicely kept with lounge chairs and umbrellas available. As we went in early September, the north winds stirred up large waves that washed up to the first row of chairs, left debris on the shoreline and blew sand in your face. The lifeguard flag were always yellow

The beach is nice if you want to spend one day or few hours by the beach before taking your flight at Heraklion airport. We took the bus number 6 at the airport and were at the beach 30 to 40 minutes later (on the other way we took bus number 1). The cost of the ticket is 1.70e

It was very windy when we used this beach so we probably didn’t see it at its best. Even so, we experienced many nicer beaches during our holiday in the Greek islands. It is small pebbles rather than sand and of course the sea was very rough. There are lots of sun loungers
Not the best sand and not the best waters. A thermal plant behind you... there are much better options as beaches.

We took a taxi from the hotel in Heraklion. It was about 20 minutes away. It's a nice beach, not too busy and it was clean, There were beach chairs for rent and some nice sun shades. The chairs belong to the bars that are there so you also get a waiter that comes along to take
Not so exotic but close to the city and not crowded.The sand is good ,the water is very nice and when waves comes isn't so bad it can swing and it was very pleasent.

Long stretch of coarse sandy beach approximately 10 minutes from downtown Heraklion by car travelling along the major seaside road. Usually pretty wavy but nothing too dangerous and you can spend a lot of time just bobbing around out there. Past the break is a shallow rocky
Small beach , easily accessible by public bus from Heraklion city centre. It is a quiet beach , very clean with some good eating shacks. The beach is worth a visit.
Lovely beach,admittedly by coastal road,but really lovely. Good choice of good value restaurants with free beach loungers and shades if you use their facilities. Very easy access and lovely swimming.

I really love Ammoudara Beach! I always try and book flights there with Easyjet, ecah year when I have the time and money to go there, with my family. I think that it has some really good views of the coastline of the Heraklion area, and of the local coastline of Gazi, Ammoudara

We stayed at the HOTEL NEPTUNE, this was an all inclusive hotel, could not fault it, it was a perfect stay. Our flight was 1hr late so arrived at 11pm tired and hungry and what a lovely surprise, they had put on a cold buffet for the four off us. The room was clean and spacious,

I stayed 400m from the beach in the outskirts of Iraklion. I visited every day. Where I was there was lots of peace and quiet, open space and usually sun. It does get quite windy on Ammoudara Beach compared to other beaches I’ve used elsewhere. Away from the tourist centre
Plenty of free sun loungers, and excellent cafes and bars right on the beach and from the centre of Heraklion it is only 1 euro 70 each way on the bus which takes about 25 minutes.

Ammoudara was the perfect beach for us. Only a few miles from Heraklion, it was the best place for us to relax after being on the go so much in Athens the days prior. The lounge chairs were great and the food was excellent. If you're not looking to go far, this is the place.

Just ok. Not a beach you will remember but a very good idea if after you wanna visit Heraklion. Water is clean even if so close to the city.

Lovely beach in a beautiful bay. Soft sand slopes gently into the sea ideal for kids. Free sunbeds provided you buy a drink which is delivered to you while you sunbathe. Nice taverna overlooking the beach and sea.

Ammoudara Beach is actually one of the nicest beaches on Crete. This is especially true if you live in or visit Heraklion specifically. What was once the region's most popular touristic beach, has calmed down quite a bit since Malia and Hersonissos gained fame. We go to this

We go here because it's convenient and close to our home in Heraklion. It is not the best beach in the area, but the sand is fine, and there are free sunbeds with umbrellas. But you have to buy drinks and they are pricey. The beach is clean, however, the water is not the
Good solution if you like a quick(close to the city) bath or a more loud and organised(umbrellas,beach bars) beach.Nice for families because it is sandy and shallow.

Fairly standard although decent enough beach with lots of beach cafes offering sun beds. The approach to the sea is stoney underfoot which is a bit uncomfortable. The beach makes for a good day trip out of Heraklion and is about a 30 minute bus ride from the city centre (buses

We caught the bus in Elestherious square and went there getting off a the nearer end. It was early in their holiday season but was pleasant lying around on the beach although in April the water was cool. Think the nearer end is probably better than the far end but it is good

We walked from Agios Nikolaos past several small beaches and across the river and marshland, wonderful protected area for flora and fauna to-this beach for lunch relaxation prior to the return journey, wonderfully relaxing day

This long sandy beach is close to Heraklion, so it's easy to travel to. It's perfect to take walks on or to just chill with a beer. Ammoudara wasn't very crowded when we visited, so we enjoyed our day there. There are several cafes lining the beach, so plenty of options to
A long sandy beach stretching for several miles. Wo nderful for swimming or just walking along in the sea

We visited this beach a few times, it was easy to get to via the Number 6 bus from the centre of Heraklion. As beaches go it is Average. Not very clean but not filthy either. The views are OK so long as you don't look over at the power plant to the left hand side.
Well organized beach offering sun umbrellas, coffee snack etc. ten minutes drive from the city center .
A lovely beach with fine sand. Perfect for young families wanting to play safely in the sea. Great views and a cooling breeze. Free parking is handy too.
The beach is ok, but considering the beaches Crete has, this one is not the best. I would recommend exploring the island if possible, i liked very much the Voulisma beach.

Had a horrific cocktail on a broken sun lounger. Blocked out the power plant to the left and the stadium on the right. The beach was quite beautiful, the water was clear. Grated my feet into fine slices on the rocks.

We went there after reading mixed reviews on TripAdvisor but we were pleasantly surprised, the beach was really good and we enjoyed spending time there as family, so much that it was difficult to get my son to agree to go back to our apartment in Heraklion. We got bus number 6

We were here for our second visit in Crete, Heraklion. It's the perfect beach if you are staying near the city center. To get here you have a direct bus, number 6 Ammoudara. The tickets to go here are the ones on the blue line, from here if you want to go to the city center, you

A short drive from Kalo Chorio but a much clearer pleasant less crowded beach than the much vaunted Voulisma beach. Three rows of well spaced sun beds all free after your first drinks order. Lunchtime Taverna good as well. Toasties and Omelettes very good value.
Very beautiful beach for families with kids but it's a shame not to be organized. Broken toilets no showers and changing rooms.

10 minutes by bus (1.7€) from Heraklio and this nice sandy beach is awaiting. You can find some good beach bars just before the final station where it's free to have 2 deck chairs and a parasol and you pay only what you consume (2.5€/beer and 2€/frappe). The beach is really a
Excellent public beach well served with toilets, refreshments etc. Well worth a visit if nearby. nice little taverna for coffee or food

The beach was very long and had good parking We visited in tge late afternoon and it was very windy. The choppy seas made it difficult for a swim but I would recommend this beach if staying in Heraklion

Very good place, free sunbeds, umbrellas to hide from the sun, all Coffee kinds, clean water, even after yesterdays heavy rain, free Wi-Fi, water sports, shower and so on. All you will ever need :) recommended.
We walked here from our hotel the Blue Marine and had a little drink while looking at the lovely view. Reasonable priced drinks with an excellent location.

+1 for being close to Heraklion +1 for being clean enough to be swimmable +1 for service, restaurants on the beach and plenty of beach chairs, and shops for souvenirs nearby (tourist traps though) -1 for the view. There's a power plant towards the west side that reminded me of
I visited Ammoudara for last time last March. The beach was quiet without chairs and loud music. You can find quiet places to swim only 5-10 minutes away from Heraklion all the time
i would suggest visiting another beach because this beach is always crowded and not that clean. Try another beach! Greece has more beautiful beaches than this!
Nice, clean water, lots of caffes, kind people, safe guards, sandy and a little bit windy. The waves are not too big. We had so much fun

Not very far from the city center, you can take a public bus, There are numbers of restaurants and bars you can buy some food and drinks, Beach umbrella and chairs also available for rent. The ocean water is clean and refreshing. A good place to swim and just relaxing.
The electricity factory is very close to the beach and the sea so is no clean the water there. No there

Ammoudara Beach is really a nice one! There are some seats with umbrellas, the only thing you have to do is buying e.g. a beer, which is not much in my opinion for lying on the beach all day long. Especially beers and other stuff isn't that expensive and as far as I'm concerned

as Heraklion has no beach at all,there is the resort of Amoudara.a sort of suburb of Heraklion,but in fact an important resort which didn't impress me so much as there is a main street,where almost all hotels,tavernas,bars and pubs are located ;the sad thing about Amoudara is
A beautiful sandy beach with clear blue sea. Sun loungers and a proper "mama mia" moment with a bit of Shirley Valentine thrown in

Soft and clean sand, no stones and rocks and two wonderful tavernas on top of it with professional and very helpful staff serving the guests on the beach. In mid September it was not crowdy with plenty of sunbeds and umbrellas. The water in the sea is terrific, very clean and
The most popular beach at iraklion, everybody goes to work then comes to amoudara for a swim. Great place you need to visit definitely

In our vacantion, we've been here most of the time because we really enjoyed this place. It's a nice sandy beach where you cand relax, swim and even do some snorkeling (there are a few nice things to see). The place is surrounded by restaurants where you cand go to eat. If you

There are a lot of chairs, the beach is clean and wide. There are no rocks on the water ( I was expecting to find some, but actually the bottom is pretty smooth). On the beach are some bars and showers.

although Heraklion is more known for its monumental sites, the beach of Ammoudara on the side skirts of the city spans over a few kilometers and provides a good atmosphere for people of all types to walk, swim, sunbathe, eat, drink and enjoy a nice sunset

Popular beach with a number of resort type hotels springing up along the coast to the west of the capital city of Heraklion. There are also a few tavernas that offer accommodations and we chose on of those.
The beach is wide and open offering a large verity of restaurants and taverns. It was a bit windy but the beauty of the place is still impressive.
Very nice beach, big and sandy. If you are lucky you can see some events there, as the sand sculpture festival I had the opportunity to enjoy.
i really like the place but the sea is too wavy. if you dont like the waves like me, i dont recommend to go this beach.
15 mns by bus from center /You reach a nice clean beach/ Pay for a chair & enjoy a dip..I went in the morning & was back early before the summer heat gets intolerable

The view is ok but the water has a lots of sharp rocks and the worst part is that here is a common event to step on a sea urchin. Which actualy happned to one of my friends. Of course that across the road there is a medical center that can help with this for 120 euros. I would

I have been to Ammoudara beach today and thought it was a very nice beach. I think Trip Advisor has got this confused with Ammoudi beach by Heraklion. This beach is 10 min drive from Ag Nic. There are 2 bars and about 200 beds. The beds are free if you order from a bar. The sand

Our hotel leads onto the beach which is one reason we chose it. Not the nicest of beaches by a long shot but for us, convenient and nice enough.

One of the favourite beaches on the island. No subbed charges if you place one order with the bar... Seem like a good deal to me. Apart from a good beach, nice water and good basic facilities, you can also get wifi too. Nice beach. Enjoy.
amoudara is a beautifull sundy beach with a lot of things to do ... sunbeathing and read your book or do a lot of watersports
Perfect water, free sunbeds with orders at the cafe. Suitable for families. But the river brings some cold water that mixes with the sea. Can be refreshing.. Or shocking!
An ok beach, not particularly sandy, slightly gravelly, a good walk after passing through a stream, which can get quite deep in places
Breathtaking views. Clear and warm water, suitable for swimming. Beach is organised with facilities around chairs umbrellas for a reasonable price.

This beach was a nice beach near Heraklion. If you don't mind a little walking, it makes for a nice stroll with shops as you walk. If not you can also take a blue city bus inexpensively. *Be aware you occasionally may see topless females (we weren't expecting it, but did see
Amoudara beach is close to Heraklion, a sandy beach stretching out 5 kms. It is very windy out here thus it is popular with windsurfers. Not my piece of cake. I don't like open seas at all...

Came here as the Watercity waterpark was closed. The sand was OK but not amazing. The beach stretches quite far. Not too fond of a beach so close to an industrial area. We only randomly stayed at a spot where there were sunbeds and shower place beside a nice tavern with huge
Nice beach with easy access and nearby facilities. We went there as a family and we could play with our infant without feeling any danger.

A long sandy beach with lots of tourists and many places to eat and drink aftr swimming. If it is windy, then it becomes really difficult to enjoy the sea. The place swarms with hotels, most of them are relatively old but pretty ok
Nice clean sand and very quiet outside the Atlantica Akti Zeus hotel. Good for beach volleyball and sea is incredibly clear!

Great beach, proper sand as compared to some others in Crete and some good cafes. Went in Sept/Oct and most other people were locals, very relaxed people and families. Had an excellent, deep massage from Chinese therapist who is there most days at a reasonable price. Worth
This nice sandy beach is very close to Heraklion. The beach is quite long and can be rather full in the summer, so it is advisable to stay near to the end of the beach.
if you don’t want to feel like a rover between happy motionless sunbathing hotel guests, go closer to the airport: where are enough space for unorganized travelers.

While a great strip of beach, the nearby smell of sewage detracts from the experience. Yet if you sit far away you'll enjoy a beautiful long strip of beach which provides ample seating area though a very limited choice of restaurants.

Absolutely lovely beach, we walked for miles in both directions, the sea was lovely and warm with large waves. Plenty of sunbeds and umbrella's along the way, cost for 2 beds and umbrella is 5 Euro. We used to walk after lunch.
Its a very peaceful place to go and enjoy a family sunday. Restaurants and shops nearby are very good and not far from city center.

Ammoudara beach is a long beach of about 6 km, with lot of umbrellas, beach chairs , many bars where you can get soft drinks (but not only). During the day it is not crowded, so everyone can enjoy a bath in the Aegean See (very warm during August, but with some waves). Most
Nice sandy beach. There are places with hotels and apartments near and calmly places, where you can stay alone. No dislikes.

Our hotel was right on the beach. Very nice and clean. Part of the beach is very stony when you are going into the sea - tough on the feet. Apparently you have to beware of the sea urchins too. Didn't see any ourselves though.

Ammoudara beach is a nice beach with a good line up of restaurants and cafes. The beach is clean and the water was nice and warm (we visited in August). My kids love it. A few minutes from the beach, there are also many restaurants, tavernas. and shops for souvenirs, beach
Quickly into deep and warm water, few waves, little tide and very clean sea. Excellent for oldies and young alike.
Closest beach to the city center, but if you have transport would recommend to go farther away for swimming! Many beach bars and places to sit and have lunch or drink coffee/ cocktails.

We stayed at the Atlantica Akti Zeus hotel which looks onto this beach. The beach itself was very clean and had a lovely view of the island of Dia and the coastline down to Heraklion. There is a power station nearby but you only see it if you look back towards it - it is not in
Went for a long walk along this beach….not many tourists, but plenty of places to take a seat and enjoy a drink or food. Water is crystal clear.

Ammoudara area means long in English. It is about 8 kilometers ( 5 miles) most of it is sandy. A small portion on the west end is a bit rocky. We have been here 6 weeks and experienced windy and calm conditions. No rain at all. On windless days the Sea is las smooth as glass.
This is a very crowded and loud beach, probably most suitable for young pepole. Very convenient if you stay in Ammoudara area and have no accessoar to a car.
Sandy clean beach which stretches 8 miles. Spotlessly clean near our hotel and plenty of water sports facilities available. Wind can be a bit fierce at times.

A magnificent beach stretching for about 5 miles. Let down a little by tavernas which have not been modernised very much but with care and attention you an still find little gems. On a calm day you could not find a better beach but when windy the sea kicks up a bit and the

The beach in itself is nice, good sand, excellent view, warm water. But throughout our entire stay (middle of july) it was so windy that lying on the beach was really difficult (with a book or the like)
Nice sandy beach, blue flag great view to the mountains, not far from Heraklion,good transportation and infrastructure.
Great waves at this beach although a bit rocky take Aqua shoes to protect your feet clean beach with sand pebbles and shingle
Beautiful beach but fairly choppy. Beach is sand but once in the water it is very rocky, all beit not sharp just hard to manage footing.

Quite a grotty beach. Still can have good fun but not a wonderful vista and sand is coarse, fag ends etc

Not what I expected the photos were much nicer than the actual beach it was not very clean and very windy which whipped up the sand but if you like surfing or any other water sports it was ideal

Wonderful spot with fab taverna for breakfast or lunch. Right on the beach front. The sand is beautiful. Only a short walk to Agios Nicolas. By bus, by car or walking this spot in wonderful eastern Crete is well worth the visit.

Crete has many lovely beaches. The Amoudara beach seems to be about 20 meters from the hotel to the water. At the east end you reach the city of Heraklion and on the west end the electric power plant (can you say "eyesore"?!?). There seems to be a bit of trash that washes up

beach is very beautiful and clean - clear waters and great for swimming enjoyed walking from hotel straight to the beach and having a refreshing morning swim

We went to the beach. Very clean and well organised by staff. Two beautiful days allowed us to have a dip which was refreshing. Later in the evening we saw the sun set. I've seen many sun sets around the world and this one was also an amazing experience. Absolutely loved every
lovely,plenty of sun beds and parasols.unrushed beach and very clean.flags to guide you as to when and when not to swim

Ammoudara beach is also next to Agios Nikolaos ...more clean and cosi place!!There are also very nice restaurants and hotels
This is considered as the city beach for Heraklion with easy access by bus. The area has lots of restaurants, souvenir shops, shopping centres etc. as well as cineplex to keep you occupied
huge beach with so many beach bar and hotels the best is heaven beach bar the only promlem is that is always windy on the beach and there are big waves that little kids cannot deal with them safely
Avoid this place like the plague. Unless you like hot sand, warm saltwater, cool breezes, bright sun, and total enjoyment.
Excellent sandy beach ideal for walking. Great for adults and children. Snorkelling off the beach on the reef about 50m out
Nice beach. Very touristic. Amnisos beach is better. The water is clean and have a beautiful color. There is nothing else to do in the area.

Ammoudara beach (close to Heraklion = 8 km from the city center) is never full. The beach is clean and has a few good restaurants along it. The sea is mostly very calm In the morning and starts to give some waves after 11 O'clock. Nice to swim and jump into the blue water.

Unfortunately, the beach all along this area is taken up with sunbeds and umbrellas almost right down to the shoreline. This alongside noisy, loud music from the many bars made it definitely not for us. If you want a quiet stroll along the beach listening to the waves gently

I loved staying at this beach - so peaceful once the sun is starting to set. The only thing that bothered me were people who were walking up and down the beach, selling knock-off bags, watches and other things. They weren't pushy though, so that was nice. Oh and there aren't

Windy nothern coast, greek blue sea, clean water, good for snorkeling. the power-station you can see from the beach very clearly. It is a big pity and it really disturb you when watching the beautiful sea and hills..

the beach could be calm one day and the next with waves, ideal for playing with the waves or relax.... even with the waves it is safe as it is shallow

It's a beach near most amoudara hotels, so is a place where you can take a rest after going back from day trips, or spend part of the day on seaside, looking the sea, the waves and the mountain. But the beach itself is not so touristic.
The eastern strip of the beach is best, very clean but a little pebbly towards to front. Relaxing and not too crowded - perfect for a weeks tanning session
It is an area just next to hersklion , not so crowded ! But it is between hotels and the electricity factory ! Not suggested

It has some good spots here and there, but in general it is not the cleanest or the best beach you will find in Heraklion. Maybe try your luck to the east (or west) Surely you ll be better!

amoudara is an excellent beach, an excellent place to relax in front of the sea. You can stay on long chairs and take good drinks from the restaurant that is also on the beach.

you had to pay 15 euros each for a sun bed on one side of the beach and on the other you side you got the beds for free but had to but drinks.
free lounger and parasols , wind blowing in from the sea was fabulously cooling. we were there for the amoudara annual summer party and had a great time with the added entertainment. great times : )

This beach is about 10mins by bus from the city centre of Heraklion. It is a lovely clean beach with some cafes and restaurants. I recommend you go to Blue n Blum as there are free sun loungers and umbrellas for all!
Very long beach, divided to zones of hotels (but all are accessible), nothing else is special (comparing to other, beautiful, beaches is Crete)
not to busy ad beautiful veiws the strip is not too wide so you can her the music be waiter on hand and foot and the sun beds are free (well the price of a drink) would i return deffo

I know ammoudara beach isn't the best beach on Crete, but I found it to be very pleasant and clean! I don't see how people could say it isn't beautiful being that it's 7 km long and full of sand and bars everywhere!! I enjoyed it and so would anyone who knows what's good!!

The lovely long sandy beach has lots of sunbeds and parasols.These are free for the day as long you purchase one drink from the bar which provides the beds. The sea is lovely, calm and shallow for quite a way out. Be advised, though, you might feel something touching your legs
It's ok it's not the perfect beach but it's close to the city and you don't have to take a long bus ride to go to the beach.Waters are clean(most of the times)
There is nothing to do in there!!! It used to be very popular but not anymore!!! It has some very nice hotels but not night life or anything!!!!

This is one of those soft sand beaches that are all along the north coast of the island. There is relatively little tourist development and the sea is clean and safe. If there is any wind, you will have fun with the surf.
Nothing special, long sandy beach with nice and clear water! the hotels are close and that is the good thing. There are much better beaches in Crete where you can go!

Golden Beach restaurant on the beach front was lovely and had lovely staff.
The water is clear and the beach clean. It's a long beach, so enough space, but hotels claim their part of it. If you don't want to pay for a chair or a parasol, you need to walk quite a distance.

text.wiki:
Heraklion or Iraklion ( hih-RAK-lee-ən; Greek: Ηράκλειο, Irákleio, pronounced [iˈraklio]) is the largest city and the administrative capital of the island of Crete and capital of Heraklion regional unit. It is the fourth largest city in Greece with a population of 211,370 (Urban Area) according to the 2011 census. The population of the municipality was 173,993.The Bronze Age palace of Knossos, also known as the Palace of Minos, is located nearby.
Heraklion was Europe's fastest growing tourism destination for 2017, according to Euromonitor, with an 11.2% growth in international arrivals. According to the ranking, Heraklion was ranked as the 20th most visited region in Europe, as the 66th area on the Planet and as the 2nd in Greece for the year 2017, with 3.2 million visitors and the 19th in Europe for 2018, with 3.4 million visitors.


== Names ==
The Arab traders from al-Andalus (Iberia) who founded the Emirate of Crete moved the island's capital from Gortyna to a new castle they called rabḍ al-ḫandaq (Arabic: ربض الخندق‎, "Castle of the Moat") in the 820s. This was hellenized as Χάνδαξ (Chándax) or Χάνδακας (Chándakas) and Latinized as Candia, which was taken into other European languages: in Italian and Latin as Candia, in French as Candie, in English as Candy, all of which could refer to the island of Crete as a whole as well as to the city alone; the Ottoman name was Kandiye.
After the Byzantine reconquest of Crete, the city was locally known as Megalo Kastro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο, 'Big Castle' in Greek) and its inhabitants were called Kastrinoi (Καστρινοί, "castle-dwellers").
The ancient name Ηράκλειον was revived in the 19th century and comes from the nearby Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles's city"), whose exact location is unknown. English usage formerly preferred the classicizing transliterations "Heraklion" or "Heraclion", but the form "Iraklion" is becoming more common.


== History ==


=== Minoan Era ===
Heraklion is close to the ruins of the palace of Knossos, which in Minoan times was the largest centre of population on Crete. Knossos had a port at the site of Heraklion (at Poros - Katsambas neighborhood) from the beginning of Early Minoan period (3500 to 2100 BC). Between 1600 and 1525 BC, the port was destroyed by a volcanic tsunami from nearby Santorini, leveling the region and covering it with ash.


=== Antiquity ===

After the fall of the Minoans, Heraklion, as well as the rest of Crete in general, fared poorly, with very little development in the area. Only with the arrival of the Romans did some construction in the area begin, yet especially early into Byzantine times the area was abound with pirates and bandits.


=== Emirate of Crete ===
The present city of Heraklion was founded in 824 by the Arabs under Abu Hafs Umar who had been expelled from Al-Andalus by Emir Al-Hakam I and had taken over the island from the Eastern Roman Empire. They built a moat around the city for protection, and named the city rabḍ al-ḫandaq (ربض الخندق, "Castle of the Moat", hellenized as Χάνδαξ, Chandax). It became the capital of the Emirate of Crete (ca. 827–961). The Saracens allowed the port to be used as a safe haven for pirates who operated against Imperial (Byzantine) shipping and raided Imperial territory around the Aegean.


=== Byzantine era ===

In 960, Byzantine forces under the command of Nikephoros Phokas, later to become Emperor, landed in Crete and attacked the city. After a prolonged siege, the city fell in March 961. The Saracen inhabitants were slaughtered, the city looted and burned to the ground. Soon rebuilt, the town remained under Byzantine control for the next 243 years.


=== Venetian era ===
 
In 1204, the city was bought by the Republic of Venice as part of a complicated political deal which involved, among other things, the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade restoring the deposed Eastern Roman Emperor Isaac II Angelus to his throne. The Venetians improved on the ditch of the city by building enormous fortifications, most of which are still in place, including a giant wall, in places up to 40 m thick, with 7 bastions, and a fortress in the harbour. Chandax was renamed Candia and became the seat of the Duke of Candia, and the Venetian administrative district of Crete became known as "Regno di Candia" (Kingdom of Candia). The city retained the name of Candia for centuries and the same name was often used to refer to the whole island of Crete as well. To secure their rule, Venetians began in 1212 to settle families from Venice on Crete. The coexistence of two different cultures and the stimulus of Italian Renaissance led to a flourishing of letters and the arts in Candia and Crete in general, that is today known as the Cretan Renaissance.


=== Ottoman era ===

During the Cretan War (1645–1669), the Ottomans besieged the city for 21 years, from 1648 to 1669, perhaps the longest siege in history. In its final phase, which lasted for 22 months, 70,000 Turks, 38,000 Cretans and slaves and 29,088 of the city's Christian defenders perished. The Ottoman army under an Albanian grand vizier, Köprülü Fazıl Ahmed Pasha conquered the city in 1669. 
Under the Ottomans, Kandiye (Ottoman Turkish قنديه) was the capital of Crete (Girit Eyâleti) until 1849, when Chania (Hanya) became the capital, and Kandiye became a sancak. In Greek, it was commonly called Megalo Castro (Μεγάλο Κάστρο 'Big Castle').
During the Ottoman period, the harbour silted up, so most shipping shifted to Chania in the west of the island.


=== Modern era ===
In 1898, the autonomous Cretan State was created, under Ottoman suzerainty, with Prince George of Greece as its High Commissioner and under international supervision. During the period of direct occupation of the island by the Great Powers (1898–1908), Candia was part of the British zone. At this time, the city was renamed "Heraklion", after the Roman port of Heracleum ("Heracles' city"), whose exact location is unknown.
In 1913, with the rest of Crete, Heraklion was incorporated into the Kingdom of Greece. Heraklion became again capital of Crete in 1971, replacing Chania.


== Architecture, urban sculpture and fortifications ==

Venetian constructions such as the Koules Fortress (Castello a Mare), the ramparts and the arsenal dominate the port area.
Several sculptures, statues and busts commemorating significant events and figures of the city's and island's history, like El Greco, Vitsentzos Kornaros, Nikos Kazantzakis and Eleftherios Venizelos can be found around the city.
Many fountains of the Venetian era are preserved, such as the Bembo fountain, the Priuli fountain, Palmeti fountain, Sagredo fountain and Morosini fountain (in Lions Square).
Around the historic city center of Heraklion there are also a series of defensive walls, bastions and other fortifications which were built earlier in the Middle Ages, but were completely rebuilt by the Republic of Venice. The fortifications managed to withstand the longest siege in history for 21 years, before the city fell to the Ottomans in 1669.


== Municipality ==

The municipality Heraklion was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 5 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Gorgolainis
Heraklion
Nea Alikarnassos
Paliani
TemenosThe municipality has an area of 244.613 km2, the municipal unit 109.026 km2.


== Neighborhoods ==


== Suburbs ==


== Transportation ==


=== Port ===
Heraklion is an important shipping port and ferry dock. Travellers can take ferries and boats from Heraklion to destinations including Santorini, Ios Island, Paros, Mykonos, and Rhodes. There are direct ferries to Naxos, Karpathos, Kasos, Sitia, Anafi, Chalki and Diafani. There are also several daily ferries to Piraeus, the port of Athens in mainland Greece. The port of Heraklion was built by Sir Robert McAlpine and completed in 1928.


=== Airport ===
Heraklion International Airport, or Nikos Kazantzakis Airport is located about 5 kilometres (3 miles) east of the city. The airport is named after Heraklion native Nikos Kazantzakis, a writer and a philosopher. It is the second busiest airport of Greece after Athens International Airport, first in charter flights and the 65th busiest in Europe, because of Crete being a major holiday destination with 7.974.887 travellers in 2018 (List of the busiest airports in Europe).
In April 2018, the inner space of the airport has been modernized and expanded by almost 3.000 s.m., with 11 new gates and new stores. The expansion was a donation by Hellenic Duty Free Shops.
The airfield is shared with the 126th Combat Group of the Hellenic Air Force.
A project for the new airport of Heraklion in Kasteli area is starting at the end of 2017.


=== Highway network ===
European route E75 runs through the city and connects Heraklion with the three other major cities of Crete: Agios Nikolaos, Chania, and Rethymno.


=== Public transit ===

Urban buses serving the city, with 39 different routes. Intercity buses connects Heraklion to many major destinations in Crete.


=== Railway ===
From 1922 to 1937, there was a working industrial railway, which connected the Koules in Heraklion to Xiropotamos for the construction of the harbor.
A study from the year 2000 investigated the feasibility of two tram lines in Heraklion. The first line would link the Stadium to the airport, and the second the center of Heraklion and Knossos.  No approval has yet been given for this proposal.
In the summer of 2007, at the Congress of Cretan emigrants, held in Heraklion, two qualified engineers, George Nathenas (from Gonies, Malevizi Province) and Vassilis Economopoulos, recommended the development of a railway line in Crete, linking Chania, Rethymno and Heraklion, with a total journey time of 50 minutes (30 minutes between Heraklion and Rethymno, 20 minutes from Chania to Rethymno) and with provision for extensions to Kissamos, Kastelli Pediados (for the planned new airport), and Agios Nikolaos. No plans exist for implementing this idea.


== Climate ==
Heraklion has a hot-summer-Mediterranean climate (Csa in the Köppen climate classification). Summers are warm to hot and dry with clear skies. Dry hot days are often relieved by seasonal breezes. Winters are very mild with moderate rain. Because Heraklion is further south than Athens, it has a warmer climate during winter but cooler during summer because of the Aegean sea. The maximum temperature during the summer period is usually not more than 28 - 30 °C (Athens normal maximum temperature is about 6 °C higher). The minimum temperature record is -0.2 °C
A new temperature record for February was set at 27.8 °C, reached on 15 February 2016.


== Colleges, universities, libraries, and research centers ==
University of Crete

=== Arts ===
The Cultural and Conference Center of Heraklion is a centre for the performing arts.


=== Sports ===
The city is home to several sports clubs. Most notably, Heraklion hosts OFI and Ergotelis, two football clubs with earlier presence in the Greek Superleague, the top tier of the Greek football league system. Furthermore, the city is the headquarters of the Heraklion Football Clubs Association, which administers football in the entire region. Other notable sport clubs include Iraklio B.C. (basketball), Atsalenios (football) and Irodotos (football) in the suburbs of Atsalenio and Nea Alikarnassos respectively.


=== Famous natives ===

Heraklion has been the home town of some of Greece's most significant people, including the novelist Nikos Kazantzakis (best known for Zorba the Greek), the poet and Nobel Prize winner Odysseas Elytis and the world-famous painter Domenicos Theotokopoulos (El Greco).

text.wiki:
Voulismeno Aloni (Βουλισμένο Αλώνι, Greek: sunken threshing floor) is a sinkhole located at the feet of Mt Stroumboulas, next to the old national road, at the 14th kilometer from Heraklion to Rethymnon, on the island of Crete (35°19′48″N, 25°01′05″E).
It is a ground subsidence with a circular shape up to 90 meters in diameter. Its slopes are steep and vertical reaching up to 60 meters of height from the bottom of the formation. Descent into the interior is feasible on foot from the South-West side following a certain pathway.
Geologists believe that it is a sinkhole, formed by the depression of a cave, during the Pleistocene period.
In spite of what its name implies, it is believed that it was never used as a threshing floor.
